TAB.EMPHASIS: (At 10.30 a.m., the sitting continuing, the balance of the report follows)

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR SMALL BUSINESS AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the member for Cunningham moving forthwith that this House calls on the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs to come into the House immediately and explain the latest startling revelations that he lobbied at least two additional Bunbury councillors, Councillor Major and Councillor Comito, to stop a retail shopping development going ahead for `parking reasons', in the knowledge that if parking was a problem, Target would have not likely gone to the Eaton site.
This latest allegation has to be defended in this place. It is an outrage that the minister is not here.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Reith ) put:
That the member be not further heard.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. Corruption is a sackable offence—

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Reith) put:

BREAK.PARA: That the member be not further heard.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Mr Martin's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR SMALL BUSINESS AND CONSUMER AFFAIRS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley, Kim, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith that this House censures the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs—

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I rise on a point of order. This motion has already been moved this day—it is a continuation of yesterday's proceedings. As such, it cannot be repeated. I suggest to you that it is, therefore, out of order.
—I respect the views of the right honourable member for New England, but this is a different motion with a different base, and it is in order.
—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition moving forthwith that this House censures the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs for:
(1) knowingly misleading the House again and for his contempt for it;
(2) his actions which constitute a corruption of his office;
(3) new revelations today which show that he actively lobbied at least two additional Bunbury councillors to prevent the Crossland development "going ahead for parking reasons";
(4) the revelation that councillors associated with the Minister had questioned car parking for the rival city development so that Target would be forced to go to the Eaton lot;
(5) the Minister having done this knowing that "if parking was a problem then Target would have most likely gone to the Eaton site;"
(6) the revelation that these councillors said that the Minister had lobbied them with an end result in mind and they knew the significance of the end result;

(7) his successful lobbying as shown by the minutes of the Bunbury City Council meeting on 25 March which show that council voted to grant an approval for Crosslands given one month before by requiring substantial additional car parking;
(8) failing in his statement yesterday to disclose the full story;

(9) his misleading statement yesterday saying that he had not used his ministerial position for personal gain is directly contradicted by a statutory declaration and statements to the media by councillors involved;

(10) his false and misleading statement yesterday in which he claimed non‐involvement in the day‐to‐day affairs of the company except by the ridiculous school boy definition of the Acting Prime Minister;
(11) his at least 119 admissions of influence‐peddling which show him having:
(a) used his public office to secure private benefit in blatant breach of the requirements of the Prime Minister's code of conduct;
(b) phoned Mr Nick Greiner, Vice Chairman of Coles Myer to influence a decision to get Target as a lead tenant on the vacant Eaton lot owned by a company of which the Minister is an active Director;

(c) failed to disclose the full details of the telephone conversation between himself and Mr Nick Greiner in particular as it related to the Minister's attempts to thwart development on an opposing site;

(d) repeatedly failing to table the letter between his brother and Mr Nick Greiner, written following the telephone conversation between the Minister and Mr Greiner, which provides further evidence of collusion to advantage his private business interests in serious contravention of the Prime Minister's code of conduct;
(e) misled the House about his involvement in regard to the Eaton site;

(f) directly canvassed a Bunbury City Councillor, Mr John McCourt, about another development or another site owned by him in Bunbury which would give his company a financial advantage in direct breach of the Prime Minister's code of conduct;
(g) failed to answer truthfully questions regarding that particular development despite being invited repeatedly to do so in this House this week;

(h) in the words of Councillor Wayne Major, tried to wreck the Bunbury city site leaving the way for Target to go ahead to the Minister's private company Eaton site north east of the city, thus constituting a further breach of the Prime Minister's code of conduct;
(i) having misled the parliament and the public on a number of aspects of his inappropriate approaches to councillors in direct contravention of the Prime Minister's code of conduct; and
This House calls on the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs to resign immediately or for the Acting Prime Minister to sack the minister forthwith.
At the very heart of this situation, Mr Speaker, lies corruption.

PARA.TAB: Motion (by Mr Ruddock ) put:
That the member be not further heard.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the motion. Where is Geoff Prosser? Is this his day on at the shops?

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Ruddock) put:

PARA.TAB: That the member be not further heard.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Mr Beazley's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.DATA.PARA: (Mr Speaker—Hon. R. G. Halverson OBE) Ayes 41

PARA.TAB: Noes 75

TAB.TAB: Majority 34

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Industrial Relations; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALKER.NAME: Mr REITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That standing order 399 be suspended for the remainder of this sitting, except when a motion is moved, pursuant to the standing order, by a minister.

This motion requires an absolute majority of 75. So, whilst government members may leave the chamber, they would be advised not to go too far as their support for the motion will of course be necessary. I move the motion because, I do not know about everybody else in this place, basically I am ready to go home. With the exception of a number of matters, it is important for the parliament to complete its consideration of the matters before the chamber. For example, the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) will shortly be addressing the House on the excellent aged care legislation for which she has been responsible.

It is important that that legislation goes through today. We have amendments that the House needs to consider. I understand that the Labor Party would be embarrassed by further debate on the aged care, given the shameful scare campaign being run against the government by the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), who shamefully used the concerns and anxieties of older Australians for her own cheap, personal political benefit—a disgraceful performance by the shadow minister. Not surprised was I to hear her the other day start to back‐pedal and to apologise for the disgraceful campaign she has been running.

That legislation needs to come back from the Senate. These matters need to be dealt with today. In fact, some aspects of the program will come into effect on 1 July. On that basis, the legislation needs to go through the chamber today.

Whilst for the rest of Australia today is Friday, 27 June, in the technicalities of the parliament, today will be recorded in the Hansard as Thursday, 26 June. I know you are often a day behind things, but the reason for that is the sitting today is not a new day but an extension of the sitting of the parliament from yesterday. The reason that we do that, in accordance with the convention and the practice, is so that the House in its sitting today can deal with any final amendments coming across from the Senate so that matters are completed by the end of the session. For that reason, we have followed past practice—we do not have a question time today because in fact today is an extension of yesterday.

As I demonstrated to the House, what the government is doing in its management of the House today is exactly what the Labor opposition did when it was in government. As I demonstrated yesterday with many examples, this is the conventional manner of conducting the House's business on this Friday being an extension of yesterday's Thursday sitting.

As far as the motion that I have moved is concerned, the motion to suspend standing order 399, again, this is a conventional approach by this government. We are following the precedent and practice of the former Labor government. In fact, on a number of occasions they threatened standing order 399. Former member Mr Wal Fife used to say that he was responsible for first threatening the use of it, although I have a suspicion it was the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair).

However that may be, the fact is that it was used on a number of occasions by the previous Labor government when it was in power—for example, on 19 August 1993 and at the end of a session on 19 December 1991. They gave notice of it on a number of occasions when we, as a responsible opposition, took account of any such notice given and, under those circumstances, did not act unreasonably, nor did we act in the feral way in which this opposition today acts. Given that the purpose of this motion is to facilitate the orderly conduct of today's business, I will not use the full time allocated to me, which will not, of course, stop the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Crean), but the approach I adopt for him is the sooner we get him over and done with, the better.

Members would be interested to know, as far as the sitting hours for the balance for today are concerned, there are noises coming from the Senate that they may not sit until midnight. With that, there is, therefore, some prospect of our adjourning earlier, but I do not want people to start packing their bags as yet.

TALK.START.PARA: —Geoff has!
—The Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) is addressing a seminar in Melbourne on small business. He is doing what he should be doing.

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate standing orders would normally see them rise at a quarter to four. If the Senate so decides, it will sit on beyond that time to deal with outstanding matters. If it were to rise at around 4 o'clock, you could expect the House to sit probably until 6 o'clock or 7 o'clock in the expectation that it often takes some hours for the paperwork to be transmitted from the Senate across to the House for us to deal with matters. I am told by Deputy Speaker Nehl that one of the longest transmissions was six hours. So there is a transmission period between when the Senate gets up and when the House can deal with matters.

That is the best information I have. Obviously we will advise the House and all members of any developments. We appreciate that people would like to be able to get home tonight, if possible. But people should be mindful that, if necessary, to deal with important matters to ensure that legislation is in place by 1 July, we obviously have to continue sitting today as long as it takes, as long as it is necessary, for us to fulfil our duties in that regard. I have moved this motion in accordance with longstanding practice. It does thereby ensure that we can actually do that which we need to do today to complete the business of the House. I do not do it for any other reason.

BREAK.PARA: We already have had a number of debates in respect of the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, who will be the subject of the predictable comments from the Manger of Opposition Business when he rises to speak. The minister has been very up-front in the chamber. He has provided a full explanation.

The Labor Party finds it objectionable that he should have family business interests which he has built up over a long time. Looking at the other side, it is no surprise that that would be the view that you would take. He has answered the matters that you have raised. You had a full question time yesterday in which you floundered around and had a lot of trouble getting your attack up. Your censure motion was pathetic and half‐hearted.

It is no wonder you want to go again after the failures you had yesterday. You would be disappointed with the press this morning. You are worried about the long winter. Of course, Jacques Economique is off to Bordeaux, and he wants to leave a good impression on the backbench before he does so. Jacques Vulgaire is what we on this side call him. He has a range of nicknames.

We look forward to his presentation. As usual, it will be sharp and incisive, full of rhetoric, full of misleading statements, full of baseless allegations and full of the exaggerated claims for which he is now infamous in this parliament. I commend the motion to the House. We will need an absolute majority of 75 to get it through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following words be added: `or by the Manager of Opposition Business'.

This is a government that is trying to protect the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser), whose corpse has been dangling for two weeks, a corpse which now has not even got the breeze to sustain it. The breeze is not even giving it the appearance of life. This is a minister who is so dead even the maggots are dropping off. This is a minister who has so corrupted his office, has so consistently misled this parliament, that there is no leader in the world who could defend the minister in these circumstances.

BREAK.PARA: But where is he being defended from? The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is defending him from the other side of the world. We have a Prime Minister who avoids press conferences on the issue and who has been so caught out by his misjudged and ill‐timed trip, being in all the wrong places at the wrong time. The Prime Minister should have taken the step to cut this minister down, but he himself has been misled; he has stuck with this minister and is now going to pay the price.

The Acting Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer) has scurried out of this House today after that dissembling interview on AM this morning where he said that we had to do one of two things yesterday for Geoffrey Prosser: we either had to have a full explanation or a cover‐up. Can you believe the Acting Prime Minister on national radio saying that we needed to have a cover‐up? I tell you what: he got neither. We neither had a full explanation nor, certainly, an effective cover‐up.

That is because more is emerging. The reason we have tried to move censure motions this morning, following insisting upon the minister coming into the House to explain himself, is that what was not included in the statement yesterday—damning as it was in terms of the minister continuing having day-to-day activities and the minister admitting using public office to curry private favour—was today's new revelations—things that were not contained in his statement yesterday.

The two new revelations come from two additional councillors from Bunbury—not Councillor John McCourt, who has sworn a statutory declaration saying that the minister has lobbied him. Would the minister himself be prepared to swear a statutory declaration? We know he will mislead this parliament, but will he swear a statutory declaration saying that he has not lobbied for his development site? I doubt it. Would he be prepared to have his claims tested in a court of law, as Councillor John McCourt is prepared to do? I suspect not. That is why he is not here today, and that is why this government is using every device possible to prevent him being brought before the House and required to explain himself.
The two new pieces of information that have come today are from two additional councillors—Councillor Major and Councillor Comito, both of whom have said:
We discussed . . . going to the inner-city site and Mr Prosser's advice was against the development going ahead for parking reasons.
This is the direct discussion with Minister Prosser. Minister Prosser was lobbying them to make sure that the development site did not go ahead for parking reasons. Councillor Major said:

. . . councillors associated with Mr Prosser had questioned car‐parking for the rival city development so that Target would be forced to go to the Eaton site. Cr Frank Comito said Mr Prosser spoke at a separate meeting about parking.
He went on to say:
If parking was a problem then Target would have most likely gone to the Eaton site.

Let us understand what we have here. We have a minister who has admitted ringing Nick Greiner—a Liberal mate, a former chairman of Coles Myer—and asking, `Can we get the Target site on to my Eaton development—me, Minister Prosser?' Nick Greiner presumably said something like, `We've got a problem; we've already committed it to the CBD—Bunbury, eight kilometres away.'

So this inventive mind of the small business minister says, `I've been involved in a lot of these things. We know how we can nobble the opposition. We will get the council to up the ante for parking spaces. We will get our supporters on that council to insist upon additional car parking spaces.' Then the lobbying campaign begins. But it is nothing formal; no formal presentation. Who would be stupid enough to run a campaign like that in writing? Informal? Yes—the phone calls, the social gatherings, the meetings of people. All these councillors are now fessing up that Geoff Prosser lobbied them to up the ante for the car parking site.

This was no unsuccessful lobby, because on 25 February the council had approved the Crosslands Shopping Centre, the opposition shopping centre, for development, with, I think, 65 car parking spaces. One month later they amended the approval to require an additional 200 car parking spaces. In other words, they lifted the ante three times—this was a pretty effective lobbying campaign—in the space of one month.

I would like to know, and I am sure the public would too, when Geoff Prosser made the call to Mr Greiner. I suspect that it was between 25 February and 26 March. I would suspect that it was closer to 26 March because we are told that out of the blue came the request from the developer, under pressure from Coles, to increase the number of parking spots.

So what we have here is a minister who has lobbied Nick Greiner and others not just to get a Target store onto his site but to make sure that the opposition site, which has already secured the Target tenancy, gets nobbled. That is why he was so evasive this fortnight in the parliament in detailing the question. Remember the dissembling responses—no formal presentations, only in relation to the Eaton site. He did not want to tell us about the little games he was playing at Bunbury, but we flushed him out.

The work that was done by the member for Cunningham (Mr Martin) has been outstanding in this exercise. He has ferreted this information out and as a result we have people coming out of the woodwork everywhere. These people are the enemies that Geoff Prosser has made, because they want his carcass to be cut down too. It will not stop here, because these are the revelations that have come out less than 24 hours after this so-called comprehensive statement by the minister.

The government members try to say, `Oh, you know, it was just a phone call to Nick Greiner.' This was no ordinary phone call. We all know that the reason Geoff Prosser's site in Eaton has not gone ahead is because it has not got its lead tenant. The idiotic Acting Prime Minister thinks that engaging in everyday business means that you have to be engaged every day. Presumably that means you have to be working Christmas Day too. This is the dictionary definition—Tim Fischer's version. How ridiculous! How ineffective and incompetent was that defence! But that is what Prosser left him doing.

This was no ordinary phone call. The only reason the Eaton site has not gone ahead is because it does not have the lead tenant. We know that the shopping centre that gets a lead tenant like Target is a guaranteed cash cow. We know that if it gets that tenancy, it means millions of dollars more to this multimillionaire. This was no ordinary phone call; this was a $20 million phone call. What were the phone calls worth to the council? What were they worth in terms of the lobbying and the underhanded—
Motion (by Mr Reith) put:
That the question be now put.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the motion be put.
—The amended version.
—No, it now lapses because we have failed to achieve a seconder. The minister has called for the motion to be put.
—The noes have it, Mr Speaker.
—A division is required. Ring the bells.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PARA.TAB: Original question put:
The motion (Mr Reith's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.DATA.PARA: (Mr Speaker—Hon. R. G. Halverson OBE) Ayes 75

PARA.TAB: Noes 40

TAB.TAB: Majority 35

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a message from the Senate acquainting the House that Senator Crowley has been discharged from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Senator Faulkner has been appointed a member of the committee.

TITLE.XREF: SOCIAL SECURITY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (ACTIVITY TEST PENALTY PERIODS) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration forthwith.
Senate's amendments—
(1) Clause 2, page 1 (line 16), omit "subsections (2), (3), (4), (5), (6), (7), (8) and (9)", substitute "this section".
(2) Clause 2, page 2 (after line 4), after subclause (3), insert:

PARA.TAB: (3A) Schedule 1A commences, or is taken to have commenced, on 20 October 1997.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (3) Page 38 (after line 28), after Schedule 1, insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Schedule 1A—Amendments relating to relief from activity tests

PARA.TAB: Add ", unless the Secretary determines otherwise, having regard to the continued existence, or likely continued existence, of the special circumstances on which the last preceding determination was based".

PROCTEXT.PARA: Insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 603AAA Pre-natal and post-natal relief from activity test

PARA.TAB: (1) A pregnant woman is not required to satisfy the activity test for the period that starts 6 weeks before the woman's expected date of confinement and ends on the day on which the woman gives birth to the child (whether or not the child is born alive).

(2) If a woman gives birth to a child (whether or not the child is born alive), the woman is not required to satisfy the activity test for the period that starts on the day on which she gives birth to the child and ends 6 weeks after that day. Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973

Add ", unless the Secretary determines otherwise, having regard to the continued existence, or likely continued existence, of the special circumstances on which the last preceding determination was based".

PROCTEXT.PARA: Insert:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 78AA Pre-natal and post-natal relief from activity test

PARA.TAB: (1) A pregnant woman is not required to satisfy the activity test for the period that starts 6 weeks before the woman's expected date of confinement and ends on the day on which the woman gives birth to the child (whether or not the child is born alive).

(2) If a woman gives birth to a child (whether or not the child is born alive), the woman is not required to satisfy the activity test for the period that starts on the day on which she gives birth to the child and ends 6 weeks after that day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RUDDOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.

These amendments give effect to measures relating to activity test exemptions announced in the 1997-98 budget and make minor technical changes to the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Activity Test Penalty Periods) Bill. The Social Security Act 1991 and the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 are amended as follows. First, amendments are made to enable newstart allowance and youth training allowance customers to be exempt from the activity test for longer than the currently permissible period of 13 weeks in special circumstances. These circumstances would include, for example, empanelment of a jury and temporary caring duties. Second, a new activity test exemption is introduced for expectant mothers. Under the new rule, expectant mothers would be exempt from the activity test from six weeks prior to their expected date of confinement to six weeks after the birth of the child.

These amendments introduce greater flexibility in the administration of the activity test for certain customers who, due to special circumstances of a temporary nature or pregnancy, cannot reasonably be expected to satisfy the requirements of the activity test. The new rules will provide for a better service for people who are unable to look for work or otherwise meet requirements of the activity test because of pregnancy or other special circumstances by removing the need for them to transfer to special benefit. The special benefit has a dollar for dollar reduction income test that is less favourable than the income test applicable to newstart and youth training allowance customers.

These amendments are to commence on 20 October. They are very welcome. In a sense I am surprised that, after Labor having been in office for 13 years, these amendments were never thought of or actioned before, because they are obviously very evidently required.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I think those last comments were rather unnecessary, particularly given the fact that there was a need for the opposition to sit down and negotiate a much better system of activity testing than the government first proposed. Given the comments by the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (Mr Ruddock), it might be useful for us to just have a brief look at the history of the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Activity Test Penalty Periods) Bill, because we have not got to this position without a little bit of trauma.

SPEECH.PARA: The government announced their proposal for a new activity test regime in the 1996-97 budget. That consisted of a six-week non-payment penalty for the first breach and a 13-week non-payment penalty for second or subsequent breaches. We did make our point clear at the time of this debate on the Social Security Bill 1996 in the Senate in December 1996. While we do support tough measures with regard to fraud and compliance, we do not believe that people should be cut off payments without good reason or for inordinate or indefinite periods. We believe that the government's initial activity test regime proposed was excessively harsh and unreasonable, particularly in the absolute absence of positive measures by the government to assist the unemployed to return to the labour force.

I am pleased to say that during the debate the government did withdraw the provisions that would have given effect to that proposed penalty regime and they made an alternative offer: five weeks non-payment for the first breach and eight weeks non-payment for the second or subsequent breaches, as I recall it. Senator Newman did undertake to negotiate with the opposition and minor parties an agreed position. It is pleasing that we have come to an agreed position. But we have not come to that agreed position because of the generosity of the other side. In the 1997 budget, the government announced a revised penalty regime which was actually more severe than the offer made by Senator Newman in December, especially for the third or subsequent breach. The penalty for this reverted from eight weeks to 13 weeks non-payment—no money, nothing.

Subsequent negotiations, which could have taken place before March this year and avoided all this toing and froing had the government been reasonable, have led to the breach regime that we have before us today. The government amended the bill in the House of Representatives to give effect to a much more reasonable penalty regime: an 18 per cent rate reduction for 26 weeks for the first breach—and, as the government knows, fortunately it is the case that most people breach only once—a 24 per cent rate reduction for 26 weeks for the second breach and eight weeks non-payment for third and subsequent breaches.

We do recognise and appreciate that the government has seen the strength of our arguments. The result will be less need for the unemployed to beg, borrow or steal. That is what we were facing. We are also pleased to support the other government amendments that are before us today. They give effect to a beneficial measure announced in the 1997-98 budget, which will allow prenatal and postnatal women relief from meeting the requirements of the activity test in some circumstances. I am very pleased to support the amendments before us today.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate with a request for amendments.
Ordered that the requested amendments be taken into consideration forthwith.
Senate's requested amendments—

ROW.ENTRY: you stop holding as trading stock and acquire under section 70‐110
the amount worked out under section 70‐110

BREAK.PARA: (2) Schedule 1, item 9, page 175 (after table item 10), insert:

ROW.ENTRY: you start holding as trading stock and you sell under section 70-30
the amount worked out under section 70‐30

BREAK.PARA: (3) Schedule 1, item 13, page 269 (line 16), omit "for purposes of manufacture, sale or exchange", substitute "that is held for purposes of manufacture, sale or exchange in the ordinary course of a *business".
(4) Schedule 1, item 13, page 271 (line 24), omit the link note, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 70‐30 Starting to hold as trading stock an item you already own

PARA.TAB: (1) If you start holding as *trading stock an item you already own, but do not hold as trading stock, you are treated as if:

TAB.TAB: (a) just before it became trading stock, you had sold the item to someone else (at arm's length) for whichever of these amounts you elect:

PARA.TAB: • its cost (as worked out under subsection (3) or (4));
• its market value just before it became trading stock; and
(b) you had immediately bought it back for the same amount.

Example: You start holding a unit of depreciable plant as part of your trading stock. You are treated as having sold it just before that time, and immediately bought it back, for its cost or market value, whichever you elect. (Subdivision 42‐F provides for the consequences of selling depreciated property.)

TAB.TAB: The same amount is normally a general deduction under section 8‐1 as an outgoing in connection with acquiring trading stock. The amount is also taken into account in working out the item's cost for the purposes of section 70‐45 (about valuing trading stock at the end of the income year).

Note: Depending on how you elect under paragraph (1)(a), the sale may or may not give rise to a capital gain or a capital loss for the purposes of Part IIIA (Capital gains and capital losses) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 . It does not if you elect to be treated as having sold the item for what would have been its cost: see subsection 160ZB(7) of that Act. However, it can if you elect market value.

EMPHASIS.TAB: When you must make the election

BREAK.PARA: (2) You must make the election by the time you lodge your *income tax return for the income year in which you start holding the item as *trading stock. (If you do not make the election by then because you do not realise until later that you started to hold the item as trading stock, you must make the election as soon as is reasonable after realising that.)

PARA.TAB: However, the Commissioner can allow you to make it later (in either case).

EMPHASIS.TAB: How to work out the item's cost

BREAK.PARA: (3) The item's cost is what would have been its cost for the purposes of section 70‐45 (about valuing trading stock at the end of the income year) if it had been your trading stock ever since you last acquired it. In working that out, disregard section 70‐55 (about acquiring live stock by natural increase).
(4) However, if you last acquired the item for no consideration and the acquisition involved:

PARA.TAB: (a) a disposal of the item to you for the purposes of Part IIIA (Capital gains and capital losses) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 ; or
(b) the item passing to you as someone's *legal personal representative, or as a beneficiary in a dead person's estate;,

BREAK.PARA: its cost is taken to be its market value when you last acquired it. (This does not apply if the acquisition did not involve a disposal of the item to you for the purposes of Part IIIA (Capital gains and capital losses) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 .)
(5) Subsection (1) does not apply if you start holding any of the following as *trading stock because they are severed from land:

PARA.TAB: (a) standing or growing crops;
(b) crop‐stools;
(c) trees planted and tended for sale.
(This does not prevent subsection (1) from applying to a severed item that you later start holding as *trading stock.)
Note: A transaction that this section treats as having occurred is disregarded for the purposes of these provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 :
subsection 47A(10) (which treats certain benefits as dividends paid by a CFC)
paragraph 103A(3A)(c) (which affects whether a company is a public company for an income year).

BREAK.PARA: (5) Schedule 1, item 13, page 280 (line 5), omit "or were".
(6) Schedule 1, item 13, page 280 (line 6), omit "or was".
(7) Schedule 1, item 13, page 281 (after line 15), at the end of subsection 70-100(1), add:
Note: If the transferor is the item's sole owner after it stops being trading stock on hand of the transferor, section 70‐110 applies instead of this section.
(8) Schedule 1, item 13, page 284 (line 21), omit the link note, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 70‐110 You stop holding an item as trading stock but still own it

PARA.TAB: If you stop holding an item as *trading stock, but still own it, you are treated as if:
(a) just before it stopped being trading stock, you had sold it to someone else (at arm's length and in the ordinary course of business) for its *cost; and
(b) you had immediately bought it back for the same amount.

Example 1: You are a sheep grazier and take a sheep from your stock to slaughter for personal consumption. You are treated as having sold it for its cost. This amount is assessable income, just like the proceeds of sale of any of your trading stock.

TAB.TAB: Although you are also treated as having bought the sheep for the same amount, it would not be deductible because the sheep is for personal consumption.

PARA.TAB: Example 2: You stop holding an item as trading stock and begin to use it as plant for the purpose of producing your assessable income. You are treated as having sold it for its cost. This amount is assessable income, just like the proceeds of sale of any of your trading stock.

TAB.TAB: You are also treated as having bought the item for the same amount, which is relevant to working out the item's cost for depreciation purposes: see Subdivision 42‐B.

PARA.TAB: Note: A transaction that this section treats as having occurred is disregarded for the purposes of these provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 :

TAB.TAB: subsection 47A(10) (which treats certain benefits as dividends paid by a CFC)
paragraph 103A(3A)(c) (which affects whether a company is a public company for an income year).

BREAK.PARA: (9) Schedule 5, item 1, page 402 (line 11), omit the link note, substitute:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 70‐5 Treatment of items that become trading stock because of the change of definition

PARA.TAB: If:
(a) immediately before the 1997‐98 income year you owned an item that was not trading stock as defined in subsection 6(1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 as in force at that time; and
(b) at the start of that income year you hold the item as trading stock as defined in section 70-10 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 (the 1997 Act );
section 70‐30 of the 1997 Act applies as if you had started to hold the item as trading stock as defined in section 70-10 of the 1997 Act immediately after the start of that income year.

PARA.EMPHASIS: 70-10 Accounting for your disposal of items that stop being trading stock because of the change of definition

BREAK.PARA: (1) This section explains how to account for your disposal of an item if:

PARA.TAB: (a) immediately before 1 July 1997, the item was an item of your trading stock, as defined in subsection 6(1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 as in force at that time; and
(b) the item has not been an item of your trading stock, as defined in section 70-10 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 , after that time; and
(c) the disposal occurs on or after 1 July 1997; and
(d) subsection 36(1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 would have applied to the disposal if it had occurred before 1 July 1997.

Example: This section applies to your disposal on or after 1 July 1997 of an item you produced, manufactured, acquired or purchased before that day for manufacture, sale or exchange, but did not hold for that purpose immediately before that day or since the start of that day.

BREAK.PARA: (2) Sections 70-90 and 70-95 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 (dealing with disposals of trading stock outside the ordinary course of business) apply to your disposal of the item as if it were an item of your trading stock (as defined in section 70-10 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 ).

PARA.TAB: Note: Applying those sections ensures that your assessable income includes the market value of the item on the day of disposal. This counters your deduction under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 for your expenditure to acquire the item as trading stock.

Insert:

PARA.TAB: (10A) Subsection (10) does not apply to a transfer that is taken by section 70‐30 or 70‐110 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 to have occurred.

BREAK.PARA: (11) Schedule 5, page 423 (after line 13), after item 79, insert:
Insert:

PARA.TAB: (3C) Paragraph (3A)(c) does not apply to an acquisition that is taken by section 70‐30 or 70-110 of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 to have occurred.

Omit "throughout the period when the asset was owned by the taxpayer", substitute "at the time of the disposal".
Omit "throughout the period when the asset was a partnership asset of the partnership", substitute "at the time of the disposal".
Add:
(7) When an item already owned by a taxpayer becomes trading stock of the taxpayer:

PARA.TAB: (a) a capital gain does not accrue to the taxpayer; and
(b) the taxpayer does not make a capital loss;
if the taxpayer elects under paragraph 70‐30(1)(a) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997 to be treated as having sold the item for its cost (as worked out under that section).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the requested amendments be made.

These amendments relate to three areas. One group is to clear up the tax position where assets move into or out of trading stock. The second group removes from the bill rewritten provisions that deal with the exemption of education and training payments. This is being done because of the changes to be made to those provisions by Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997. The government proposes to remove the rewrite of the current provisions at a later date. The provisions of the 1936 act will be rewritten to reflect the law as of 1 July 1997. The third block of amendments ensure that the rewritten provisions that allow deductions for tax related expenses correctly reflect the existing law.

Requests Nos 1 to 12 relate to the change of the use of trading stock. This group of amendments is by way of requests. They comprise specific rules to deal with assets that are put into trading stock and, conversely, with trading stock that is taken out for non-trading use. When this bill was introduced in the House of Representatives, it contained provisions dealing with these events. However, as a temporary measure, the government moved in the House to remove the provisions. This was done so that there could be further consultation about the technical expression needed to give effect to the proposed treatment. There is now broad agreement on the appropriate wording to implement the proposal.

The requests pick up recommendations on the change of use provisions made by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts in its report No. 348. One of the committee's recommendations, to add certain clarifying words to the definition of trading stock, has been modified in a positive fashion as a result of a suggestion which emerged from the recent consultations.

Amendment No. 1 relates to tax related expenses. This amendment will ensure that the rewritten provision allowing deductions for tax related expenses will continue to allow a deduction for expenditure, even if it is related to a tax issue that did not involve capital expenditure. Amendments Nos 2 to 17 relate to exempt income for educational training payments. The bill rewrites the exempt income provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 and transfers them into the new Income Tax Act 1997.

A number of the provisions in the 1936 act are the subject of changes by the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1997. For this reason, the rewrite of the relevant 1936 act provisions are being removed from the bill. This means that the 1936 act provisions in relation to the exemption of educational training payments will continue to apply. A number of other amendments are necessary to give effect to the removal of those rewritten provisions. Each of the alterations that I have just commented about is explained in more detail in the supplementary explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Tax Law Improvement Bill is the second tranche of the complete rewrite of the income tax legislation which was embarked on by Labor through the tax law improvement project in 1994. The passage through the Senate of the first package of three bills commencing the rewrite occurred on 17 March to take effect on 1 July. This legislation, which also commences on 1 July, has been lying in the Senate since 26 March and is being passed at this hour to ensure that it is not retrospective. The bill has been amended by the government in the Senate and the Senate has also made a series of requests for the House to amend the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Labor supports this legislation and the object underpinning it, as it is essential that the enormously voluminous and complex income tax legislation be simplified. Hopefully, this will reduce compliance costs for taxpayers and administrative costs for the tax office. In addition, the rewrite will also improve certainty in some cases where there is currently considerable uncertainty in the operation of the law.

BREAK.PARA: This whole process is necessary because the old legislation, the 1936 act, has been amended and expanded so often that it has lost an overall coherent structure. It is surely the most complex piece of Commonwealth legislation on the statute books and it is continually being amended, quite properly, by governments of both persuasions. Because of the sheer enormity of the task, the rewrite has to occur in tranches. This partial ongoing rewrite process provides its own challenges, as it is not possible to repeal the 1936 act and replace it in its entirety.

Labor does not criticise this process. We understand that it was the only realistic option. The particular tranche being rewritten in this bill includes assessable and exempt income, deductions, trading stock, depreciation and gifts. The more specialised areas include entertainment expenses and primary production. It runs to about 550 pages.

The government, with opposition support, amended the bill substantially in the House. In addition, the government now has agreement from the relevant stakeholders on some contentious matters, such as the trading stock provisions, and has further amended the bill to implement the agreed position. Labor supported these changes in the Senate and will be supporting this amended bill.

I acknowledge that there continues to be some criticism of the tax law improvement process from the tax profession. These views are noted by the opposition. However, we do not think they warrant the termination of the process. It should be put on the record that there is also a substantial body of opinion which supports the rewrite process.

In closing, I mention that this legislation has been dealt with as a non-controversial bill because some of the contentious provisions relating to taxation arrangements for some educational payments were removed by the government. I acknowledge their actions to enable the swift passage of the legislation through the Senate earlier. The opposition supports the rewrite of the law and the amendments and requests made by the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to thank those people who have worked on this tax law improvement. It is a very large task which has been going on for quite a number of years now. There is a substantial amount of work involved, and, on behalf of the government, I thank the people who are involved in doing that. At the same time, I present a supplementary explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mrs MOYLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to indicate to the House that the government proposes that amendments Nos 1 to 11 and 13 and 14 be agreed to, and that amendment No. 12 be disagreed to and that an amendment be made in place thereof. I suggest, therefore, that it may suit the convenience of the House to first consider amendments Nos 1 to 11 and 13 and 14 together, and when those amendments have been disposed of to consider amendment No. 12. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Senate amendments Nos 1 to 11 and 13 and 14 be agreed to.

These amendments add to the provisions already in the bill relating to care. They also outline the review process, which I foreshadowed in my second reading speech when the Aged Care Bill first came to this place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is pleasing to see that the government has agreed to a number of the opposition amendments. I will just go through the different groups. Amendments Nos 1 to 3 are extremely important because they will prevent this government transferring responsibility for aged care to the states without any reference back to this parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: It is critical that we do not see the transfer of aged care away from the Commonwealth. The last time aged care was run by the states, pre‐1985, we saw an appalling system in place in this country in terms of the quality of care, differential access to standards of care and varying differences in the way in which people could actually get into nursing homes. It is very important that this matter not proceed. So I am very pleased that the government has agreed to these amendments.

The second group of amendments, Nos 4 to 11, actually go some way—not, in my view, all the way that is necessary—to recognising the critical need for there to be an adequate number of nursing staff employed in nursing homes. You would be aware that the opposition's argument against this bill has very much revolved around the fact that people who live in nursing homes are frail and ill. We have continued to have considerable concerns about there not being any requirement in this new bill for nursing homes to employ nurses.

Unfortunately, the opposition has only been successful in getting some of its amendments on this matter agreed to by the government. What we were also seeking was to require the government to actually set aside in the principles a level of the residential care subsidy paid to an approved provider which must be used for the provision of nursing care.

I think the government will rue the day that they did not agree to that amendment, because I have, unfortunately, no doubt that without strong controls over the quality of staffing we will see a decline in the quality of care in our nursing homes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the Democrats support the government on that?

—The Democrats supported the government. I hope it does not come to pass because it will be very unfortunate for those older Australians who do live in nursing homes. Unfortunately, the Democrats only supported the opposition on those amendments which are now before the House, which do see a requirement on nursing homes to list in their key personnel those who hold a recognised qualification in nursing. But, as far as I am concerned, it does not go far enough.

BREAK.PARA: We have to recall the appalling standard of care that existed in nursing homes before 1985. The reason the government at the time introduced changes to insist on a proportion of the government subsidy being spent on care rather than on whatever else the nursing home might have decided was its priority was that care was the fundamental issue. That is what people go into nursing homes for.

It is very sad that we see those regulations removed from this legislation, because we cannot be sure that adequate levels of nursing care will be provided by nursing homes in the future. Nevertheless, we will support the amendments before us today. They are a small step in the right direction, but certainly do not go anywhere near far enough.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time given to me there are a number of things I would like to say on the Aged Care Bill. The amendments that have just now come forward have been grudgingly supported by the government. It has taken a lot of hard work, and I commend our shadow minister, the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), for the hard work she has done in getting at least some changes to this piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I do believe that in the 15 months that this government has been in office this would have to be the most mean‐spirited piece of legislation introduced by them. They have sought to do nothing but divide the community. I believe the minister at the table now, the Minister for Family Services (Ms Moylan), and her government have nothing at all to be proud of in this legislation. The elderly of Australia will certainly not thank you and their children are not going to thank you for it. The only people who are rubbing their hands together this morning are the Doug Morans of this world. The government has handed the sick and the frail elderly of Australia to them on a silver platter.

Rather than coming back to some of the things I said when I first spoke in debate on this bill, I would like to deal with a couple of obvious points. What we are really talking about in this piece of legislation, even with the amendments before us now—which still leave it as a bad piece of legislation as far as the frail aged are concerned—is that it is a money bill, really. In its 1996 budget this government took $577 million from aged care over four years. They took $244 million out of capital commitments in the bill. They removed $253 million from subsidies to nursing homes. The user‐pays system they started to introduce under the home and community care program was another $72 million saving.So what they have had to do now is to try to put into operation something that is going to make up the shortfall because of their own actions. The people out there are not going to be fooled by this.

The relevant date is 1 October: the Manager of Government Business got his dates wrong. Maybe the minister had not conveyed to him that there was a delay because she was not sure of the bill and there were certain groups that she had not met, groups such as the people who are running the nursing homes in this community, who were queuing up outside this parliament, and outside every other place which might be an avenue for them, to put their point of view forward. There was not consultation to the depth that we were led to believe in this parliament. There was not adequate consultation with some of the church groups who run about 54 per cent of nursing homes around Australia. They did not even know, as of last week, how this bill is in the end going to affect them.

What do we see? We see a measly little payment of $5 a day that this government proposes to give to the people who are looking after those who would have to go into a nursing home with no other income but their pension. They have increased that by a miserable few dollars. That is not going to be enough.

One of the things I do agree with the minister on—she might find it hard to believe that I would agree with her—is that there are nursing homes out there where capital works are needed, and possibly urgently needed. But it is not the role of the people who need those nursing homes to start paying for it. It should be a government responsibility to look after the frail aged of our community. We are talking about Australians who have contributed to their country for 70 or 80 years of their lives. We are talking about Australians who do not go into a nursing home by choice; they go into a nursing home because they are unable to look after themselves; they are ill; they have just come from hospital; they have no way to make a provision on who is going to care for them. These are the people who use nursing homes.

It is not some panacea for the problems of public housing—from which you have cut another $400 million, by the way. What we are talking about is people in the community whom we have an obligation to look after, people in the community who are now saying, `What is going to happen to me?' And what is this government saying? They are saying, `If you have got no money, bad luck, because we are going to introduce a two‐tiered system into our nursing homes and it is going to be the haves and the have‐nots. So, if you have got a quid, you can have a bed; if you haven't got a quid, tough luck.'

What we are also going to see in our community is a division between the aged and the young. Instead of proudly having older people being adequately looked after in nursing homes, you are going to have a divide where they are going to try to be kept at home.

Worse still—and I would hate ever to see it occur here—go to America and look at some of the places where elderly people are literally dumped. They are being treated like bag people without money. Do we want our elderly to have nowhere to go, lying over heat vents in the winter and sleeping in parks in the summer? Is this what we want to see for the people in our community who have now reached a time in their life when they need government to step in and say, `We will provide adequate services for you. We will provide the facilities in which you can now spend the last of your days at least with adequate provisions and at least with adequate care'? This is a ridiculous bill. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ellis, Annette, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The tragedy of this whole thing is that during this debate on the Aged Care Bill I have sat here and have watched the Minister for Family Services (Ms Moylan) shaking her head with a wry expression on her face, as if to say, `How dramatic can those people over there become?' The reality is that, if we do not become dramatic, who on earth is going to? What we have to face here is the reality of what you are doing. The tragedy is your lack of acknowledgment of what you are doing. Maybe it is through ignorance, maybe it is through lack of care; I do not know. But you have to face up to what you are creating.

SPEECH.PARA: Hostels and nursing homes are different. Stop telling us that you are doing what we did. You are not. You are creating a whole new ball game. We do not agree with it. I tell you what: no scare campaign has been run by us. You have been running the scare campaign because of what you are creating. People out there are coming to me and saying, `What is this government attempting to do to me and my family?' I then sit down and try and explain it to them and tell them to try to relax, that we will see whether we can get change through.

With the great assistance of the aged care sector—not you—some of those changes have started to occur through the amendments we are looking at today. Thank heavens the strength of the aged care sector has won through on some of those things. You have blamed us for running a scare campaign—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the honourable member for Namadgi to address her remarks through the chair, and then we will get all the `yous' right.
—Absolutely, Mr Deputy Speaker. The minister and the government have been running the scare campaign, not the opposition and not the shadow minister. They are absolutely terrifying measures.

SPEECH.PARA: The additional $40 million that has come through has been, primarily, as a result of the campaign run by the aged care sector. In my speech in the debate in this place on another day, I paid credit to the amount of representation that I personally had received from a very wide range of people involved in the aged care sector who were screaming for assistance in getting that amendment through.

I agree with previous speakers. I do not know whether this additional $40 million will be sufficient. However, at least it is better than the measly $5 per day that they were going to be getting. On top of that, the government have already removed $500 million out of the nursing home budget. Yet they have the nerve to say, `We have to raise money and somehow make the residents who are lucky enough to get into these nursing homes pay for the capital upkeep.' This is outrageous.

The member for Barton (Mr McClelland), on a matter of public importance a day or two back, made very good reference to the user‐pays system. I think he used the words `user pays has gone berserk'. If you have the money, you can be a user who pays. If you do not have the money, you might be facing a pretty dim future. I tend to agree with that summation. User pays in that sense has gone absolutely insane.

The reality we are looking at here is that these people have contributed all of their lives to our community. Their families and their family unit are now concerned; they are worried. I have heard stories about it. One of my colleagues mentioned this morning that a dear old woman is living in a home that her husband built. She does not want to sell that house. She does not have money outside that capital. Yet if she finds herself facing the health requirement, not the lifestyle choice, of having to move into a nursing hope, that home will have to go. There is absolutely no other choice that she will face.

I find it alarming that this government can sit here in security and believe that this is fair and equitable; it is not. The pressure that is being put on our aged population as a result of this proposal is outrageous. I will continue to say that to my constituents because it is the truth. I have never seen a more mean-minded piece of legislation go through this place.

While joining the shadow minister in welcoming the changes that are being made, I absolutely agree that they are inadequate. They are not going to do what we would like them to do. If we think we are getting heavy representations now, I imagine that they will be nothing to what we will be getting in our offices a few months after 1 October.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Contrary to what some on the other side have said, I will look throughout this parliament and see what this government is doing. What the government is doing in aged care is what we ought to be doing in so many other areas. It is about a long-term vision. It is about making some often difficult decisions to set in train a system of funding residential aged care that will ensure there is one available for us when we need it and that it is of some quality.

SPEECH.PARA: Politics being what it is, I understand that members on the other side will rail against these amendments in particular. But they need to understand that, at the moment, the aged dependency ratio in Australia is 5.3:1. That is 5.3 Australians between the ages of 15 and 64 for every person over the age of 64 or under 15. In 40 years, it will be 2.6:1. The National Commission of Audit report states that, over the next 40 years, we will have to spend 10 per cent more of our GDP on the health and welfare costs of ageing alone above and beyond real growth from where we currently are to maintain the level of care that we currently have.

The member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin) says that the bill ought to mandate nursing care levels. The fact is that the Aged Care Standards Agency and the standards that will be developed by the industry and consumer organisations with the support of the department will mandate standards. How those standards are achieved will be the subject of discussion between providers and consumer organisations. It is a nonsense for the government to mandate levels of nursing or other care from Canberra and the department. Unlike just about every member on the other side, I have spent a long time working in nursing homes. I have looked after a lot of people in them. I have been to nursing homes with hot and cold running nurses in which I would not want my mother to be living. I have also been to others that do not have similar levels of nursing appointments but about which I would be very comfortable with the care.

The other piece of misinformation being put by the opposition is that $575 million is being taken out of aged care. That is about the forward estimates. You know as well as I do that it is not about taking money out of aged care. In fact, there was almost a six per cent increase in allocations for aged care in the recent budget. The member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) essentially runs the Labor Party dogma line, which is that the government should pay for the care of all people. The fact is that the government cannot afford to pay for all things for all Australians. The same people who are here today arguing about people who can afford to make some contribution to their care and who are opposed to them doing so are the very same people who refuse to examine the income or taxation base of the Australian government. They rail against taxation, industrial relations, communications and transport reform, which are the very things that create the wealth the government then distributes to people in need. They then come in here and tell us that the government, 20 years from now, ought to be paying for the care of all Australians.
If you look beyond your own political self‐interest and political opportunism, you know that, half way through the next century, one‐third of the people in this country will be over the age of 65.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. When the honourable member uses expressions such as `your political opportunism' and `your' this and `your' that, I think he should be asked to direct his remarks through the chair.
—The honourable member for Bradfield will refer his remarks through the chair.

—Yes, Mr Deputy Speaker. Finally, the member for Namadgi (Ms Ellis) says that there is quite a difference between hostels and nursing homes. So stupid are some of the other speakers that they do not realise that this legislation is stopping them from being different. It is recognising that 40 per cent of people in hostels at the moment have care needs which mandate that they ought to be in the equivalent of a nursing home. That is what this legislation is about. It is about commonsense. It is about social and fiscal responsibility. It is about saying to some young people that they need to make sure they make some provision for their aged residential care instead of simply relying on the government, irrespective of their means and income. People have suffered in nursing homes because of the policies of the previous government and lived in circumstances that I would not. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In consideration of these amendments today, I want to revisit some of the winners and losers out of the Aged Care Bill. The losers will be older Australians needing nursing home care—and their families. They will no longer be able to rely upon having nursing home care on the basis of need. We are now moving to a system where nursing home care will be given on the basis of wealth and not health. Older Australians will be forced to sell their homes to get the care they need and, when older Australians go into nursing homes and are told that they have to sell their family home, that will tell them that they are never going to return. The government may as well nail the coffin lids down because that is the impact this legislation has.

SPEECH.PARA: There are winners. The government is one winner, because it has ripped half a billion dollars out of the aged care budget. A second winner is the government's adjunct, the Moran Health Care Group—the Liberal government's retirement home for failed politicians. On the basis of providing private health care and on the basis of his political connections, Doug Moran—Mr $250 million—is No. 40 with a bullet on the BRW Top 200 list.

How appropriate that we have this legislation before the House today, given that we are continuing to discuss the discredited Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser). We know that the Moran Health Care Group picked up Bob Woods. They corralled him between this place—where he was the member for Lowe—and the Senate. We know that Dr John Hewson works for the Moran Health Care Group. We know that backbenchers in marginal seats—the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly), for instance—have come in here, one after the other, to support the Moran Health Care Group. They are taking out insurance so that they can get on Doug Moran's payroll if they lose their seats.

BREAK.PARA: Doug has been pretty busy recently, since this legislation was mooted. In anticipation of the windfall profits to come from the forced sale of the houses of older Australians, he is in big time expansion mode. I have here a press release dated 25 June 1997. It is headed, `Moran awarded Victorian aged care privatisations.' It points out that the Moran group has been selected to privately develop Victorian state government operated nursing homes—and the Moran group get to keep the profits. There are to be five new purpose built homes with 295 beds in them. Three homes will be in the Melbourne suburbs of Altona North, Broadmeadows and Mill Park and two will be in Warrnambool and Mildura in regional Victoria.

The Moran Health Care Group employ over 6,000 staff. It is a big operation with over 50 health and aged care facilities across Australia. They have moved in, just days before this legislation goes through, in anticipation. The government will say, `This is Labor scaremongering', but who is the media release from? In their own words, it is from none other than the assistant to CEO, Media Inquiries—Mr Shane Moran!

TALK.START.PARA: —Another brother.

—It is interesting that there are brothers involved, because they have been getting into Western Australia as well. They have bought the Westland Healthcare Ltd group of companies, which is the largest—
—I rise on a point of order. Could you please ask the member for Grayndler to return to the substance of the amendments we are debating.
—The honourable member for Grayndler is stretching my agreement that he is within relevance. I hope he will return to the amendments before us and relate his comments.

—I certainly will. I understand the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) taking out insurance, but I should remind him that his seat is safe. He will not need a job with the Moran Health Care Group, so he should relax.

BREAK.PARA: But the Moran Health Care Group has bought the largest provider of aged care services in WA—Westland Healthcare Ltd. That has been snatched up by the Moran Health Care Group. One wonders, once again, where the connections are. We have brothers, we have Western Australians and we have business which is related to legislation. We know that the real estate industry, the minister's former profession, will do very well out of the sale of older Australians' homes. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to cut through a lot of the rhetoric I have heard in this debate on the amendments to the Aged Care Bill. The fact remains that the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) has struck a deal with the Australian Democrats which, by any judgment, makes these sound amendments. Community Services Australia, Anglican Australia and the Australian Catholic Health Care Association have signed off on the amendments. Today we are just finetuning one of the amendments to satisfy the requirements of the government.

SPEECH.PARA: A fortnight ago I attended a `hypothetical' in Orange. All the heavyweights of the health care industry were there. They chose to disagree strongly with the act as it stands at the moment. They have now signed off on these amendments. I have studied the legislation from every angle, particularly as it pertains to my electorate, and I have no problem with the concept of a users‐who‐can‐pay philosophy in the delivery of aged care services.

The reality is that we are not talking about Doug Moran or about doing special favours for anyone. We are talking about a proportion of our population that, by the year 2030, we cannot afford to sustain from the public purse. That is what this legislation is all about. At the end of that function in Orange a couple of weeks ago, the representative of the Uniting Church said to me, `The government should find $250 million per year for the nursing home sector.' That is going to push out to $1 billion per year before 2020‐30. We cannot sustain that from the public purse.

I had major problems with the $5 concessional payment, because that was patently absurd. It would have meant that those nursing homes with a majority of concessional residents could only hope to get $9,250 over five years, which would be way short of the $13,000 you could draw from a bond. That has been rectified at that $12 rate. I still have some problems about the $7 figure—perhaps it should be $12 for all.

The one area I do have problems with is multipurpose services in rural areas, which I have spoken to you about. There are some people in the House from Yeoval Community Service Centre today hoping to see you at some point. They entered into a recurrent funding contract and I would like you to address that point if you could because they have committed themselves to a spending program which still has a couple of years to run. They really do require the ability to access that contractual arrangement because 90 per cent of the people they care for are concessional clients and they fear that they will not, in any way, meet the aged care spending needs of that little community. It is a gem of an aged care facility. So I urge you to think seriously about the proposition—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I remind the honourable member for Calare to address his remarks through the chair.

—Through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I would urge the minister to address that particular point as it pertains to multipurpose services. Yeoval, by any standard, is the sort of thing we should be looking at as an example of health care delivery in the smaller areas.

SPEECH.PARA: There is no selling of the family home required. When the partner is left there is a carer there or a relative. We are not talking about forcing people to sell their homes. Bob Ellis, in the Sydney Morning Herald a couple of weeks ago, talked about the little place up the coast near Murwillumbah that was sitting there empty, for heaven's sake. What is it but a monument to family life and a piece of nostalgia? It is nothing more than that.
As has been mentioned many times in this debate, if I choose to move from Adelaide to Sydney, I sell my home in Adelaide.

TALK.START.PARA: —What if you go to hospital?

—Let us be realistic. Once you move into a nursing home it is probably your last move in life. That is what people are afraid to say. They are not going back to the family home in the vast majority of cases. That is reality. Those who are in such a situation on farms or anywhere else—
—That is why it is different to a hostel too.
—Why is it different to a hostel?
—Because they go to a hostel by choice.
—Sure, but we are talking more here—(Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilton, Greg, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The thing that irks me about this most of all, and what also irks the callers who contact my office on average some two or three times a week, is the fact that homes owned by potential nursing home patients and clients will need to be sold. One can only ask once again those opposite, who have been afforded to this day many opportunities to state clearly and categorically that homes need not be sold, to state that for the first time because to date, despite vague homilies about economic responsibility of the act and the Aged Care Bill, no concrete statement has been made to the effect that there will be no requirement of individuals to sell their homes.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the requirement to sell homes, one really only has to observe the facts of this matter and they are that service providers can charge some $2,600 per annum from the bond and in addition they get to retain the totality of the bond that they earned from the deposit of that bond. In reading from section 57‐18 from the bill entitled `Approved provider may retain income derived', subsection (1) of that section states:
An approved provider may retain income derived from the investment of an accommodation bond balance in respect of an accommodation bond paid to the approved provider.

There is no requirement, at any stage, for the provider to spend any of this money on nursing home maintenance or on investment or interest in health care. As the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) says, `absolutely zip'. That is a matter which appals my constituents as much as it appals me.

There is no obligation to account for it in nursing home care. It is overwhelmingly and purely and simply profiteering. So one can only ask: who are these profiteers—the nursing home service providers—really going to let in their doors? Are they going to allow in their doors those people who do not get that $2,600 draw down and for whom they can subsequently earn profit on the interest? Of course they will not let those people in the door. The less privileged who cannot come up with that kind of money will not get in the door. Contrary to even our own assertions early this year of there being different levels of care in terms of orange juice, orange drink or orange cordial depending on standard of the wing that you occupy in a nursing home, we are talking now about people who will not be able to get in the door to get basic cordial let alone freshly squeezed orange juice.

The undisputed evidence is that the market will prevail. Given that demand overwhelmingly exceeds supply it will be the frail and the aged, who clearly are in the majority in terms of seeking nursing home care and who will be required to negotiate on their own behalf in terms of financial arrangements before entering the home, who will have the least opportunity to determine the amount of money that they pay and therefore the quality of service that they receive.

As the member for Namadgi (Ms Ellis) said, those opposite have put to the House that we on this side of the House are being overly dramatic. In fact, we would contend that that is not the case because 60 per cent of people enter a nursing home after what we might deem to be a reasonably serious illness such as a stroke. So in that context it is not being dramatic at all. People are forced to go into these homes, sit down and ask: what do I have to pay? That is basically the first and foremost question asked. The answer to that question is that you have to pay everything except $22,000.

If the government were fair dinkum in this regard they would give nursing homes the ability to charge $13,000, which would be the $2,600 for a year over five years. Why should they not simply impose a bond of $13,000 and let the nursing homes draw down on this particular amount of money rather than impose a much larger bond determined by the provider, the interest reaped from which will be totally retained by them as an up‐front profit. I condemn this bill as being a mean and miserly attempt to recoup money from those who can least afford to pay. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nelson, Dr Brendan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is nice to hear that the Labor Party supports the accommodation bonds; it is only the level that is now in argument. There are a couple of points I would like to make. The first is that we have just heard about the $2,600 draw down which amounts to about $7 a day. What does the opposition believe the $7 a day concessional payment minimum, if not the $12 concessional payment subsidy from the government, in total a cost of $100 million a year, is going to do? You might well argue it will make sure that there is now as much if not more incentive to take in financially disadvantaged people than there would be incentive to take in those who are eligible to pay an accommodation bond. In other words, the amendments to which the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) and the government have agreed are negating the very spurious argument which you put up earlier when the Aged Care Bill 1997 was being debated.
