SPEECH.PARA: The member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) used some intemperate language. He talked about nails in coffins and things like that. I suggest that, as the years pass and he gains a bit more wisdom, he will not use that language. He said that what we are doing as a government `is telling them that they will never return'. At the moment about four per cent of people who go into nursing homes leave those homes. For 96 per cent of people going in, it is the last resting place, the last residence in which they will live. Of that four per cent who leave, almost all of them leave to return to their own families or to the family home, which is usually empty, to die. The fact is that the home does not have to be sold. The arrangements will work in the same way that the arrangements—which you developed in opposition—work for hostels. At the moment, about 40 per cent of those who are eligible to pay an entry contribution or accommodation bond to hostels do not pay one at all, although that is likely to decrease under these arrangements.

One significant consequence of the entry contributions has been a marked increase in standards and the capital that has been available to people who are living in hostels. I challenge the opposition: if and when the opposition do regain government, will they repeal this? I am less concerned about the view of the member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin). I am much more interested to know whether the Leader of the Opposition—it is easy for us to have cheap shots about this across the chamber, but this is about our future—will stand at the dispatch box, perhaps today, and guarantee that in government you will not repeal this. I guarantee that you most certainly will not repeal it because in your hearts—and certainly in the hearts of members on the other side, whose chairs are vacant—they know that this is sensible policy.

I have heard the remarks of the Anglican Church, the Catholic health care providers and the not‐for‐profit providers. To hear a man such as the member for Calare (Mr Andren) express the view that he has should say as much for the support that is required of this bill as anything.

Finally, I remind the House of a remark that was made to me, not long after last year's budget when I was addressing this bill, by a woman who had some reservations about this until she heard her son discussing it with her husband. Her husband asked her son, `What do you intend to do with the family home after we have gone?' The son said, `Well, of course I will sell it. I'm going to have an overseas trip, pay off my car and put the rest in the bank,' to which she replied, `If my husband and I are now required to spend a very small part of what we have on seeing that we get better care when we need it most, then I am prepared to support this.'

One of the things the opposition did in government was allow us to become a selfish country where we are much more interested in what we are going to get out of life rather than what we are going to put into it. Most Australians are more than happy, over a five‐year period, to put $13,000 into their own care when they need it most. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Price, Roger, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Both the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) and the member for Calare (Mr Andren) run the mantra that Australia is ageing and that we are going to need to spend more on health. The member for Calare signs off on the Aged Care Bill 1997 and the actions of the government, even though the government is withdrawing half a billion dollars. I say to the honourable member for Calare: tell me how you can go back to your constituents and guarantee that these dollars are going to be spent on extra beds. If what you are saying is that we need more, how can you say that there is going to be one extra dollar out of accommodation bonds spent on constructing new nursing homes? You cannot.

SPEECH.PARA: When you go back to your constituents, explain to them how you are going to guarantee that one dollar of these accommodation bonds is going to be put into improving nursing home accommodation. You cannot. Not even the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan), on radio, was able to give that guarantee. All she said was, `We're going to have an accreditation process.' How often, Minister, does that occur?

That is not going to guarantee that this death money that you are imposing through this bill is actually going to go through and improve nursing homes. I see the member for Bradfield has skedaddled out of the chamber. He tries to say, `Look there's no difference between the staffing you require for hostel accommodation where residents have choice—it's their home—and nursing homes where of course they suffer under medical conditions and are assessed so before they get the place.'

Again, I ask the member for Calare: what is the penalty in this bill when a couple are faced with an awful dilemma—that is, they do not have the accommodation bond money and they know one of the spouses needs to go in but there is no available bed? Do you have a penalty in this bill for proprietors who accept an accommodation bond under those circumstances? Is it gaol? Is it a fine? Do they lose their licence, or is this merely another accreditation issue? Again, the member for Calare has signed off on this bill.

What is the prudential supervision of this money? Let us say we have a nursing home where 50 residents put in $50,000 each, and that is an awfully conservative figure—over $2½ million. What are the prudential requirements of the nursing home? Are they like the solicitors trust fund? Is the minister guaranteeing that, if any proprietor skedaddles with $1 of an accommodation bond or money put in, it will be fully restituted like the solicitors fidelity fund? Is that what you are saying, Minister? Can you guarantee that about the aged Australians? Are you guaranteeing that, Minister? If some proprietor runs off with $2½ million of frail aged people's money, are you guaranteeing that that money will be replaced, that they will be recompensed? Of course you are not.

But people like the member for Bradfield, who has skedaddled into the House again, and the member for Calare are signing off on this bill. They think it is a wonderful bill. They think it is wonderful that they cannot guarantee improvements to nursing homes, that they cannot guarantee as a result of this bill that there is one extra nursing home place. They cannot even guarantee the safety of the money of the frail aged. What hypocrisy! There is no guarantee. I ask the member for Bradfield to tell me what the penalty is. Is it a gaol sentence? This is a vicious thing.

Labor in government tackled hard issues—for example, HECS. When we said we needed more university places, we put a HECS charge on. But do you know what we did? We guaranteed that every dollar went into an extra place. Every dollar had to go into an extra place, not like what you are proposing where you can get rid of nurses out of nursing homes, put on executives and it all goes to the bottom line of nursing‐for‐profit nursing homes. That is what you are allowing under this bill.

You are not doing anything for the long term. As the honourable member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) says, you are doing things for the bottom line, for some of your mates who are so well connected. This is a disgraceful bill. It does nothing for the long term. It does nothing for the frail aged, but it enriches very few Australians who run nursing‐for‐profit nursing homes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The first thing we have to remember about the Aged Care Bill is that it is going to go through because of a sordid deal between the Australian Democrats and the Liberal and National parties.
—Sleazy deal.

—It is a sleazy deal, as the member for Grayndler interjects. It is a sleazy deal between Cheryl Kernot, John Howard and Judi Moylan to introduce up-front fees for entry into nursing homes. We are not going to let the Democrats forget it. We are not going to let any Liberal and National Party backbenchers, who have already voted and are continuing to vote for this legislation, forget it.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not doubt the sincerity of the member for Calare (Mr Andren), who raised a number of issues about ensuring that financially disadvantaged people are looked after in multipurpose facilities in his electorate. No doubt we might happen to disagree with him about the effectiveness of the up-front accommodation bond, but we do appreciate some of the concerns he is raising on other issues. He will have to accept that we will have to agree to disagree on the accommodation bond.

The reason why we believe the government has misled the member for Calare and the Australian people about this issue is that it is not about trying to improve the quality of nursing homes. That has been the mantra of the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) day after day as this debate has been raging since it was announced in last August's budget. It is not about improving the quality of nursing homes around Australia because this government with this package is taking $500 million out of aged care. It is reducing the federal government's effort. That is why we say this is really an attempt to punish people.

BREAK.PARA: If it were just about hitting people who are well off, as the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) argues, the government might have a stronger case, but people forget that the means test cuts in when a pensioner earns only $50 a week. That is part of the reductions that are part of this package, and that is one of the reasons why we believe this package is flawed, despite the amendments that are before the House at the moment.

The other point to remember is that we do not yet have an answer from the government as to what happens under Australian Corporations Law. If a publicly owned company happens to own a nursing home and it has one bed spare and two people are competing to get that bed, if one person is able to pay the $88,000 up front and the second person either cannot pay as much or cannot pay anything and they get the financially disadvantaged person subsidy, under Australian Corporations Law the directors are bound by law to give the bed to the person who can pay the highest up-front fee.

Minister, you know we have raised this question occasion after occasion. As yet, we do not have an answer. Perhaps in today's debate you can tell us what your legal advice has been. I would be very surprised if your legal advisers can tell you that Australian law does not apply to the directors of companies who own nursing homes. As each month passes, we are going to see directors of companies having to enforce Australian law, which will mean we will end up with a two‐tier system in Australian nursing homes: a better system of nursing home care for those people who can afford the higher entry fees and a lower level of quality for those who are in the other nursing homes.

There are two messages this government is sending out to the people who are participating in this debate. The first message, which this minister repeats like a mantra, is that you will not be forced to sell your home. The other message we get from people like the member for Bradfield is that it does not matter if you have to sell your home because your children should not get an overseas holiday if your home is sold. We have had other people in this House saying that, when you move into a nursing home, it is very unlikely that you ever go back to your family home and, by implication, therefore, it is okay to sell the family home.

Minister, you know very well that it is much more likely that people will be looking for entry into a nursing home when they are in hospital, when their health is in difficulty and when they and their families are under enormous pressure. They cannot be expected to negotiate with Doug Moran or a company director to decide whether they should pay $88,000 or more for entry into a nursing home.

It is interesting that the member for Robertson (Mr Lloyd) has flitted in and out of the chamber this morning. We know he has been a strong supporter of this minister's reforms. We would like to ask where he is. Is he missing with the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs, Geoff Prosser? Or is he going to come in and defend the minister and defend the introduction of this $88,000 up‐front fee for entry into nursing homes? We know that his constituents strongly oppose these measures. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wilton, Greg, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —What the people of Australia are looking for as much as anything else from this government is some level of consistency in their overall approach to social issues in this country. They are asking that the government apply consistency in an equitable way to all Australian citizens. Yet, for example, we have a situation where unemployed people who receive social security payments have to account for their activities.

SPEECH.PARA: ATSIC has been subject to both audits and slurs about its use and, in some cases, alleged misuse of public money. Yet this bill proposes to afford nursing home proprietors the opportunity to reap absolute bucket loads of money—and private money—without any clear requirement to determine how it is being spent. The member for Dobell (Mr Lee) has gone into that matter in some detail. This money may be placed in, for example, a trust fund run by a solicitor. We can only cringe at the fact that, almost daily, we read in our newspapers that solicitors are before our courts charged with misuse and mismanagement of those same trust funds.

We cannot be expected to support a bill which, in its current form, does not guarantee safe staffing levels and quality of life in nursing homes. As long as there is no requirement for the up-front payment to be used in any way, shape or form for capital improvements and as long as there is no requirement for establishing levels of nursing staff which are appropriate to providing quality care, then this bill ought be opposed.

One other group in our society who I believe are adversely impacted on by the application of this bill are the 40 per cent of residents who move into nursing homes for stays of no longer than six months. For example, where a person enters a care facility and stays for less than six months, that same facility is entitled to a total—I stress total—amount equal to three month's retention, an amount equal to three months worth of income on the accommodation bond, and resident fees for the actual time spent in the facility.

Based on a bond of $50,000—which the member for Chifley (Mr Price) has quite rightly stated is a conservative estimate—the minimum fee for a person who stays from one day to three months is a total of $650, which equals up to three months retention; $1,225, which is equal to three months income on the accommodation bond; and a $147.70 per week minimum. Consequently, a one week stay could cost $2,022.70—or more, depending on the amount of the negotiated bond.

I also put to the House the fact that this bill is a tragedy. The tragedy is that we seem to be returning to the days when those who can most afford to pay, those who can most afford to purchase the best, are those who are going to get the best. Clearly, those who are disadvantaged and who need aged care are those who are going to suffer. This can only be described as an unfortunate reality, as the member for Barton (Mr McClelland) so succinctly submitted in his speech on a matter of public importance earlier this week.

There is no doubt that the long and sound tradition of our senior citizens being entitled to care on the basis of need has been abso lutely distorted and thrown out the window by this government. We now have a situation where senior citizens are assessed on the basis of their means, not on their need for care. That is really an abhorrent situation. It is an absolute tragedy. It is something for which I am sure the government will be held to account and condemned for many years to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a shame that the honourable member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson), who was the only person on the government benches prepared to defend the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) and the Aged Care Bill in the House, has now run out—as the cliche goes—with his tail between his legs. There are a couple of points that we are dealing with in the amendments that are before the House at the moment. One of them deals with the transfer of power to the states. I hope the minister, in her reply to the numerous debates on the amendments that are coming forward today, will congratulate the hard‐fought for and hard‐won amendment which we are now discussing, as the government has agreed.

SPEECH.PARA: With this bill the Commonwealth government washes its hands completely of aged care, passing it all over to the states. In other words, `Let's transfer it. We don't want anything more to do with it. It's a bit too hard. We will now put a bill in place where all those who have the ability to operate these nursing homes can do so at a far greater profit than was ever expected in the past. But, in case it goes wrong along the line, we want to make sure that we, as the Commonwealth, now give those responsibilities to the states.' Fortunately, one of the amendments that we are debating today says that that cannot happen without any reference to this parliament. I commend the movers of that amendment.

Another point I want to touch on, particularly after the comments made by the member for Bradfield, is that these amendments, which were hard fought for, should also contain the obligation that a nursing home at least have in it a person with nursing qualifications. I found it offensive that the member for Bradfield, a failed member of the doctors' profession—he turned from being a physician to come in here as a politician—would have the audacity to say that he has found the nursing homes running hot and cold with nurses and he virtually would not put a dog in them. How dare he say that.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's an insult to the nurses.

—It is an insult to the nurses. We are talking about a profession that not only gives of its time but does so caringly. At the same time, this government in this bill wanted to have no reference to nurses in nursing homes. What is going to happen in the middle of the night? If an aged person needs medication, assistance, help, changing or whatever, are we going to get the janitor or the person who comes in to do the cleaning?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Prosser, the minister for small business, said that he does not really get involved in his businesses. He only goes to pick up the rubbish from his shopping centres every weekend when he is in town, but he does not really run the place. You cannot do that with a nursing home. Nursing home residents need professional care. At least the amendments that we are debating now have included that the obligation is on the nursing homes to at least have a qualified nurse in attendance. The number of nurses present should really be as a proportion of the number of patients you actually have in the nursing homes.

A number of my colleagues on this side of the House have raised the problem that we are also experiencing with regards to those bonds. I appreciate the member for Chifley (Mr Price) stating that there is nothing in the bill in this regard. The member for Bradfield wanted to make out that there was. I can assure him that there is not. I often wonder why, because, as the minister would say, even real estate agents have to have proper trust accounts and have to be accountable for the rents they collect on behalf of their clients; and a reference was also made to lawyers.

Yet nowhere in this bill is proper accountability going to be given of the money that is now going to be invested by the individual coming in to pay the up‐front fees to get into a particular home. I think that is appalling. I do not think we can have the minister or this government come into this House, in reply to the debate, with the amendments before us today, and say, `Don't worry about that. We'll fix it up. It will be one of those things; don't worry about it. I am sure we meant to put it in. I am sure we will bring some regulations in. But don't you get upset.'

I say to the people of Australia that we all have a right to be upset. Why bring in a half-baked piece of legislation when you can drive a tank through some of the faults in it and when the obvious faults have been brought to the attention of this government, who does not give a damn anyway? When they have time to bring in their own amendments to what were the obvious faults in the bill, they say, `No, don't worry about that. We're going to rush it through.' They do not have to rush it through. They have postponed the date now from 1 July to October, so there is no big rush in that respect.

If you are going to have so-called fiscal responsibility, which is what the member for Bradfield wants to put down our throats, I say, `Make sure your so-called fiscal responsibility will stand up and will stand up so that the people know that they are getting correct supervision of their money being invested.'

As for those people in need, we are going to hear the minister say, `Oh, don't worry about it. Twenty-seven per cent of nursing home beds are going to be allocated around Australia for those in need.' They may all be put in one town and maybe 27 per cent of beds for those in need may be put in the area of the member for Calare (Mr Andren), but it is not going to help my constituents in Prospect. I want to know how that is going to be allocated.

When you go to talk to the nursing homes, their understanding of it is, `Well, I don't have to provide all of the 27 per cent. It has to be total, surely.' I said, `Well, have you got in contact with the minister and the government to find out where you are on this?' (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Albanese, Anthony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill really goes to the heart of this government's ideological push to reduce the size of government and to rely upon market forces. It essentially suggests that nursing home owners will be benevolent and that they will put the interests of the residents before the interests of their profit margins. The fact is that when you have someone such as Doug Moran and the Moran Health Group rising to number 40 on the BRW Top 200, we know that they are obsessed by profit.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill is also of considerable concern to smaller nursing home operators who have been squeezed out by this process. How do we know? Because they are talking to us, they have written to us and they have phoned us. They are concerned that this bill is about promoting the interests of the larger nursing home operators. They are concerned at the favourable treatment given to the Moran Health Group by Jeff Kennett and the links between the former Liberal Party failed politicians and the Moran Health Group.

If you look at the details that have occurred recently with the expansion of the Moran group into Victoria, it is interesting because every year there is a number of extra nursing home places allocated. That number is tightly controlled because it varies, along with population increases and changes. Because they attract a large Commonwealth subsidy, they are tightly controlled.

Yet this year, it would appear from the Moran press release, that all the new nursing home beds in Victoria, and maybe also in WA, given their expansion into WA, were allocated to the Liberal Party's friend Dougie Moran. When you look forward to the next series of press releases in September, there is no doubt that there will be another rush from the Moran Health Group to get further into nursing home care.

I want to quote from the government's own member, because they have no backbenchers to defend them here today. That could be because the backbench does not like them. Senator Eggleston said to a Senate committee hearing:
One of the things that concerns me is that the entry fees are apparently uncapped and that residents or entrants can only keep $22,500 in assets.
He went on to say:
It seems to me that there is a whole lot of potential for financial abuse in the fact that there is no cap on the nursing home entry fee.

Yet the government fails to address this. As we all know, the Moran Health Group does not want a cap. We all know that Dr John Hewson, Dr Bob Woods, the member for Lindsay (Miss Jackie Kelly), who is queuing to get a job, and the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson), who has taken out his job insurance here today, do not want a cap either because that would cut into the profitability of these extraordinarily wealthy individuals.

In that context, we do not have appropriate safeguards in this bill in respect of the circumstances raised by the honourable member for Dobell (Mr Lee) and in respect of the situation whereby if you have two people competing for one bed and one person can pay the $88,000 and the other person does not have that amount of money, we know who will get access to that nursing home bed.

I think it is that sort of two-tiered system which is scaring people out there. People are scared because of the content of this bill. People are scared because, in spite of the government putting back the time for the introduction of this bill from July to October, the government is still intent on pushing this bill through today even though they now cannot find a single backbench MP to defend their position. That really shows how much that they care about elderly Australians.

The member for Lowe (Mr Zammit), the member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron) and these other marginal members should come into the House today and defend their government's position. They know that the phones in their electorate offices have been ringing since the government introduced this bill; they know that older Australians do not support this bill; and they know that this shows just how mean-spirited this government and this minister really are.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andren, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Any government that is responsible for pitching old people out onto the streets or for denying access to nursing home care deserves to be swept away at the next election, but I do not believe that will happen with this legislation at all. There has been much made of the $500 million being taken out of the nursing system, but the fact remains that we are injecting funds from users who can pay into the sys tem. That is exactly the thrust of what this legislation is about.

SPEECH.PARA: Concessional spaces are provided for an average of 27 per cent across the country, and I assume that will be modified if the need is there. I think there are enough provisions within this legislation and within the principles to ensure that happens. There is talk about the sort of deal done between the Democrats in the Senate and the government, but I believe there is nothing remotely approaching sordid deals in these amendments. Senator John Woodley has negotiated them in good faith. He is a minister of the cloth with a long career in the aged care industry and he more than anyone in this parliament knows what aged care is all about.

I do not know what this flood of calls to electorate offices has been about. The main concerns in my electorate were from aged care deliverers who had grave doubts about the poor communication of this legislation out in the marketplace. That has been addressed rapidly over the last few months. The feedback I am getting now is positive—apart from, as I said, concerns of smaller communities such as Yeoval and such as Carcoar with their Uralba nursing home that the $40 million set aside for regional and remote care will not be enough, because our rural communities are ageing at a far greater rate than the rest of the nation. We must support what, in many cases, is about 90 per cent of concessional residents in these remote and rural aged homes. As I said earlier, I think we must look at the grants provisions of this bill to see if we cannot review the specific and unique requirements of the smaller communities. But for the larger communities in my electorate—such as Orange, Bathurst and Lithgow—I have no grave concerns with this process.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bevis, Arch, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —A number of my colleagues have referred to the Aged Care Bill 1997 as being the meanest piece of legislation that this government has introduced, and I thought that was a pretty big call. Up until now, I had considered the government's decision to remove dental support for low income aged people to be about as low as you can go. It is still a bit of a toss of the coin when you take away the rights of low income elderly people to a proper dental care program—
—Have teeth.

—As the shadow minister points out, to have teeth and to have them cared for—that is a pretty low effort. Whilst the practical effect of this bill is not as obvious as the nasty, mean-spirited removal of dental care for aged people, it is dramatically more disadvantageous to those elderly people. The introduction of up-front fees—in the way in which it is proposed in this bill and through the government's decisions not to support other amendments to this legislation—will produce only one outcome; that is, it will dramatically increase the charges to those people going into nursing homes without any guarantee that one cent of those additional funds will go to improving the quality of care for elderly Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: The member for Calare (Mr Andren), I think quite rightly, pointed out that, when people go into nursing homes, that is very often the last home they have before they depart this earth. Sadly, that is the fact. That is also one of the reasons why nursing homes need to be treated differently by the government from the situation in hostels. For some people, hostels are a lifestyle choice. Nursing homes are not a lifestyle choice; people go there because their medical circumstance requires them to do so. When elderly people go to nursing homes, they are now going to be confronted with the requirement to pay a fee which is not capped. The people operating these centres will have the total freedom to determine what fee it is they think they should charge.

Again I want to put to the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) the proposition which has been put by some other speakers on this side of the House, and I would be interested to hear her clear rebuttal of this when she sums up. When a nursing home proprietor who charges $50,000 up‐front is confronted with a limited number of beds and with many more people wanting to get into that nursing home and those people wanting to get in have differential income rates—that is, there are some people that can afford to pay $50,000; there are some that might offer $70,000; and there are some that might struggle to offer $20,000—what is there in your legislation to prevent that nursing home selecting not according to need but purely on the basis of income?

Moreover, what is there in your legislation that would allow the directors of that company to do anything but that? The directors of the company are obliged by law to ensure a maximum return on the investment to their shareholders. That is their obligation under law and to do otherwise is negligent on their part. If there is a clause in this piece of legislation that somehow absolves those directors of that responsibility they have in company law, then state it clearly and refer to it directly in your response to this debate. But, in the absence of a clear statement to the contrary, that is absolutely the responsibility that the directors have. The result of that will be that access to nursing home care will go effectively to the highest bidder. It will be selection by wealth, not health.

A number of speakers have referred to the concessional places, including the member for Calare, who places some weight on that. The simple fact of life is that I understand those concessional places are going to be determined by region; that is, certain nursing homes will have no obligation whatsoever to provide concessional care. You will establish without doubt a two-tiered system. It will be the `for profit' private providers who will say to the people coming in, `We want $50,000 up‐front' or `We want $80,000 up‐front' and they will not be obliged to have any concessional care. People on low incomes will not get a chance to get into those places.

When this bill went through the House of Representatives originally, I made a number of comments in support of an increase in the payments to concessional care places. I received a phone call that afternoon from someone who had been listening to the debate to tell me how wrong I was, because he is involved in a very substantial nursing home which has a large number of concessional places and they run a very handsome profit without having to charge any up‐front fee whatsoever. He pointed out to me that those people who want to charge the up-front fee are the ones you will see having $500 lunches at Conrad's or at the Sheraton or at the Hilton. This individual has a long record of involvement in this industry and in public life, and he knows the people directly—he is probably at lunch with them. But he has the good decency to run a nursing home without charging a cent in up-front fees and operating more than 90 per cent occupancy for concessional places. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Aged Care Bill 1997 has probably been the most deceitful and dishonest piece of legislation not just in this current parliament but in my experience in parliament. I have not heard an issue argued so badly, so wrongly and so falsely in my time here. People out in the community are being led to believe that this legislation is going to unleash access to a massive amount of funds to help upgrade, repair and extend our nursing home systems. That is absolutely dishonest, and it is wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: To even get square, to just catch up what the government is ripping out of the budget, $130 million a year is required to be raised for starters; that is, to stand still requires $130 million a year to be raised under this legislation. But the fact is it will not even raise that. Yet we have had member after member of the government falsely—and knowingly falsely because if you talk to them privately they will admit they are doing it because they have to; they think it stinks but they have to support it—trying to pretend that this is all about improving what they inherited, this dreadful system. We all know that what John Howard as Treasurer left us in 1983 was a nursing home system with no controls and no accreditation. As I have said previously, one of my constituents who was a pensioner was eating dog food because he was paying $40 a week out of his pension for his wife in a nursing home. She had been there for eight years, and he was paying the extra costs. That was in 1983. We are going back to that 14 years later.

What is being put forward is dishonest. The industry needs $130 million a year to compensate for what the government has cut out of the budget. If we in government were so bad, why was the budget so big; if we had done it so wrongly, how is it they could save $½ billion on the forward estimates? Because the budget had grown so much. It had become a big ticket item under Labor governments; it has been reduced to a small ticket item under the conservatives. That is the first dishonesty.

The second part is that we hear a lot about social engineering. This is probably the most substantial and massive bit of social engineering that we will ever see, because it is going to the very heart and the very nature of our society. We as a country have long prided ourselves on substantial home ownership. More than 70 per cent of our community own their own homes or are paying them off. It has been an absolute cornerstone of our domestic relationships. In recent years we have been going through trauma, as have other countries, with large numbers of family breakdowns and marriage separations, but the family home has been kept on.

Let me tell those opposite what constituents are saying to me in case they are not hearing it themselves. They are saying, `I will die first,' because so many of them see their visit to a nursing home as temporary. I had a constituent telling me the other day how his wife has gone into a nursing home and he said, `But she is only there temporarily. She is coming back home.' You tell her that there is no home to come back to before she even goes in. The whole nature of that family home will change. It will now be transitory; it will be a temporary home because at the end of the day it has to go. What people are saying to me is: `I will die first. I will die in my home.'

For so many people, their visit to a nursing home is like their visit to a hospital: it is temporary. Many people die in hospital. They do not go there to die; they go there because their doctor tells them to. If you want an equivalent with nursing homes, it is not hostels, it is hospitals. People go to hospital because they have to. Many die there not wishing to; they expect to go home again from hospital. So many people expect to go home from nursing homes. This legislation is social engineering. It is changing the nature of the family home to transitory, temporary accommodation.

Let me tell members opposite about those women in my electorate who are widows and who have lived in their family home for 30, 40 or 50 years. In many cases, their late husband helped build it. They will not sell their home; they will not go to a nursing home; they will stay there. You try to tell them that this is optional. What you are doing is trying to change the nature of our society. It is disgraceful; it is dishonest; and it should be blocked. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Another couple of concerns I would like to raise in the debate here today and dealing with the amendments are in relation to comments that were made previously by the member for Calare (Mr Andren), when he said that most of the organisations coming up to him were saying they are very satisfied with the Aged Care Bill. Can I assure him, in words directly from the Australian Catholic Health Care Association, that, `Health care is a right, not a commodity offered for sale.' There are many other comments I could read to him to really let him know how the groups which are now running our nursing homes feel about this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I am also concerned that the member for Calare feels everything is going to be all right because the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) has given us assurances that at least 27 per cent of the beds will be provided to those who have limited means or no means whatsoever to enable them to get a bed in a nursing home. The member for Calare said that he is worried about some of these smaller areas, while the larger towns like Lithgow or Bathurst may be all right. We know the minister is going to get up and say, `But, wait a minute. This is going to be dealt with on a regional basis.'

I do not know about the rural areas as much as I know about my own area. If we are talking about a regional basis, the regions are all different. The area that I represent in south-west Sydney is an area which has, I would dare say, the most underprivileged people living in one selected area in the whole of Australia—where poverty affects a great many of the 1.1 million people living there.

The electorate I represent has now gained the unfortunate title of being the largest unemployed electorate in Australia. This electorate of mine is very similar to the electorates of my colleagues who represent south-west Sydney. When we talk about a regional basis and an allocation for nursing homes of 27 per cent, are we going to say to the aged in my area, `You may have to get to the end of the queue. You may have to go to the North Coast if there is a bed allocated there. You may have to go down to Wollongong'?

The minister says, `If you happen to have an elderly son or daughter who wishes to visit you and they are also on a pension'—and do not think this is not happening, because I will give you some examples of where it has come about—`you should forget about that, because we have said it's going to be allocated in the region. Unfortunately, the couple of beds in the nursing homes available to you have now gone to the highest bidder. Therefore, the allocation in that region has reached its 27 per cent, and we're terribly sorry that we cannot meet our true commitment we gave as a government.'

There are another couple of points I want to raise. What concerns me not only with this legislation but with some of the legislation coming through this House is what I label the drip effect. In other words, this legislation was announced in August 1996 so, if we keep talking about it for long enough, people in the end will say, `Not that again. I don't want to worry about it.' All of a sudden now, it is starting to hit the electorate at large that they had better start worrying about it because it is about to come into force.

We are seeing the same type of thing now as we saw in the situation where 18‐ to 20‐year‐olds will be denied unemployment benefits because our government wants to call them children who should still be dependent on their parents—but again that does not come into effect until July 1998. So if we keep talking about it now, it will start penetrating and people will say, `It's really not going to happen because it's not in force at the moment.' As for this drip effect of legislation of bad news, the electorate at large will wake up to this, because within the next 12 months or so this government has to go back to the people and get their confidence to see where it is going to go in the future.

I do not believe we can continue to have pieces of legislation like this which are just talked about. In August 1996, we were given assurances in one of the minister's press releases to the effect, `It's really only a bond. Don't worry about it. The average price that anyone will have to pay will certainly be no more than $26,000.' All and sundry have now come out with indisputable facts that the beds are going to go to the highest bidder. We know they are going to go from $50,000 to $100,000 to $150,000.

One of my colleagues got up and gave an analogy which said, `It is the difference between whether you can have orange juice or orange cordial.' I can assure you that in an electorate like mine you will be lucky to get water because, in the first place, you will not be able to get in; in the second place, you will not have the means because it would go to the highest bidder; and, in the third place, you would have a very limited income.

I have a case in my electorate of a 92‐year‐old woman who, although she still has her faculties, is very, very frail. She has now had to have her son come in and look after her. Her son is 70 years of age, and the minister knows that you cannot look after someone who is suffering from incontinence and other personal problems associated with that when you are that age.

She rang up in tears the other day and said, `Are you telling me I have to try to get into a nursing home and I may have to pay for that bed? I can't throw my 70‐year‐old son out, he has only just moved in with me.' This bill says that you have to have a carer looking after you in your home for at least two years. Where does that leave them?

Where does it leave another constituent of mine? He fought in the Second World War; he is a veteran. He has returned here and now knows he needs nursing home care, but because his son is not married, he lives at home. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fitzgibbon, Joel, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I could see the wheels turning over then. I want to speak very briefly to the amendments from the Senate to this appalling bill before the House, the Aged Care Bill 1997. I had an opportunity to raise my major concerns during the debate on the Aged Care Income Testing Bill 1997, and thank goodness for that, because I was denied the opportunity to speak to this bill at the second reading stage because the government saw fit to apply the gag. And why wouldn't they? Not a day goes by where an organisation in the area of the provision of aged care does not come up with another appalling example of how this bill will affect them.

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to give an example today of one of those organisations. I will read into the Hansard a letter from the chief executive of the Upper Hunter Village Association in my electorate, Mr Bob Russell. The letter was written to Senator Sandy Macdonald and is dated 19 June 1997. He said:
I write with reference to the Aged Care Bill 1997 which you will be debating today or tomorrow.
For the past three days my senior nursing staff have been going over and over the new weightings and categories.
Based on the available information I estimate that we will be worse off under the operational funding by $752,000.

I have not had the time to estimate what it will cost regarding prudential arrangements and accreditation. Costs which are in addition to the above figure. However, given the above figure it is almost irrelevant if we can no longer function as a Nursing Home.
The concessional Residents Supplement of $5 a day is inadequate even based on Minister Moylan's figures. A Supplement of $12 per day would be a more accurate reflection.
And I do recognise that the government has accepted that change. He continued:

Having said all the above I believe that in the short term our Nursing Home and Hostel will not survive more than 12 months if the Bill goes through in its present form. This is not an emotional statement it is simply stating a fact.
I urge you to look at the attached supporting documents and delay or amend the Bill to reflect reasonable levels of funding.

If the Bill goes through in its present form who would you suggest tells the community of Scone that their Nursing Home is to close within 12 months and that their relatives will be transferred out of town and over 100 people will lose their jobs.

I would like to hear today what the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) has to say about that. The constituents of my electorate, and particularly the residents of the Scone area, want the answers to those questions. I seek leave to table the letter from Mr Bob Russell and the attached documents.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Just to finish our contributions on these amendments, I want to draw the House's attention to amendment No. 13, which now will require an annual report on the operation of the act. I will just make some remarks about the importance of the specific issues that we have now agreed with the government will be reported on.

SPEECH.PARA: It is going to be extremely important that the parliament and the people—particularly the older people—do know the extent of unmet demand for nursing home and hostel places. We will particularly be looking at the number of beds allocated to concessional residents to make sure they do get access to nursing homes, as the government has promised.

Just as importantly, we will be very interested to see when the annual report comes out what the adequacy of Commonwealth subsidies looks like when we are talking about meeting the care needs of residents. It is the case that there has been a major change to the classification instrument, and it is very important that we see the details of how that care instrument is working.

Not surprisingly, this side of the House and the vast majority of older Australians who only have one asset—their family home—will want to know the amount of accommodation bonds people will have to pay to get into nursing homes. What we will know when we get the first annual report is how much in actual fact people have had to pay. Associated with that, we will get information about how long people have had to wait to get into a nursing home.

BREAK.PARA: As the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) said, what we want to know is, if you have $88,000, how much faster you will get into a nursing home compared with someone who has $50,000, $20,000 or nothing. That is exactly the purpose of this amendment—to make sure we will have that information and older people will have that information so this government is held accountable for this appalling legislation.

This amendment also will require the government to actually describe the extent of building, upgrading and refurbishment of aged care facilities because, as other speakers on this side have said, that has been the whole reason for this disastrous change to aged care arrangements in this country. What we want to make sure is that this bill does see some improvement to aged care facilities.

Finally, this amendment will actually require reporting on the imposition of sanctions. I do understand it is a very difficult issue because the care of older people is at stake. It is, nevertheless, going to be extremely important that information is provided to the community about the imposition of sanctions and that we know that the care of our elderly is properly maintained.

We do welcome this amendment that was moved by the opposition in the Senate. It will see a decent reporting system about the operation of this act to the parliament. There are very, very radical changes being proposed by this bill and we want to know what their implications will be. The parliament has the right to know. Australians have the right to know.

We believe it will be the case that those without a lot of money will have to go to the back of the queue. As the member for Prospect said, they will not have the same level of access to nursing home care as those with lots of money—the people whom the member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) seems to know a lot about.

The people in the member for Prospect's electorate are the ones who are going to find it the hardest of all. Those who have the least money will have to wait the longest, and it will be very important that we get that infor mation through the annual report when the minister presents it to the parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mrs MOYLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Senate amendment No. 12 be disagreed to, but that in place thereof, the following amendment be made:
(1) Clause 57‐2, page 221(lines 9 to 11), omit paragraph (n), substitute
The approved provider must use the income derived from the accommodation bond and the retention amount in the following ways
(i) to meet capital works costs relating to residential care;
(ii) to retire debt relating to residential care; or

(iii) Where no capital expenditure is reasonably necessary to comply with matters specified in the certification principles for the purposes of 38‐3(3) and meeting accreditation requirements—to improve the quality and range of *aged care services

This further amendment deletes the reference to capital expenditure being required or likely to be required. The intention is to provide approved providers with flexibility within limits in how they use the income derived from the accommodation bond and the retention amounts drawn from it.

This means that providers must invest on an ongoing basis in the physical fabric of their buildings in order to meet and continue to meet the requirements of both accreditation and certification. They will need to put in place a program of continuous upgrading, maintenance and improvement in order to be able to continue to charge accommodation bonds.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to continue my remarks but particularly focus on this amendment. The Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan) is aware of at least one nursing home in my electorate—and I do not doubt there are others across the country—which received grants in previous times. The case in question is the Maroba Nursing Home at Waratah. They received a $400,000 grant two years ago to extend and upgrade their existing nursing home. The grant was to be payable over 10 years, but the total expenditure was to be $1 million. In other words, there was $400,000 of Commonwealth funds and $600,000 of their own funds payable over 10 years, and that has been done. They have spent the money.

SPEECH.PARA: They were told late last year that, with these changes that have now come forward, they can take the money or the gun. They can take up‐front fees or the outstanding eight payments to come. So having spent their $1 million to upgrade and extend their nursing home, they are now being required to forgo up‐front fees if they want to get the rest of their grant; or if they take up‐front fees, then the expectation will be that those fees will be used to extend and improve the nursing home, which they have already done. This whole situation is one of breach of faith. It is a breach of contract, and it is just appalling that the government can sit and tell us how they are improving the system.

Another example is Learmonth Lodge, a privately owned nursing home in Newcastle which has closed down. Its residents were all required to leave by 30 June, and something like 25 nursing home residents needed to find a bed. Some of them had been in the home for years and years; some had family and some had no family. It is very difficult to suddenly find 25 beds for people who were in some cases long‐term nursing home residents. Of course, what has happened when these people and families have approached alternative nursing homes is that the nursing homes are saying, `Have you got any money, because it will make it easier?'

This leads me to my final point, about social engineering. What this means for people is that, if there is a family home in the possession of the family, the spouse or the carer, they do not have to sell it; they will get a place. It is not legally required. But people are asking me—and I do not doubt they are asking members of the government: `If we had the money, could we get a place faster, because we are being asked by nursing homes how much money we have and whether we can put in up‐front fees or not?'

This means that the children and spouses of aged people are now faced with the choice of selling their house, moving in with their kids or renting somewhere so that they can get their aged parent or spouse into a nursing home faster. That is what is happening right now. The pressure is now being put on carers and spouses to be prepared to sell the family home to raise the money for these so‐called bonds to get access to a nursing home. Legally they do not have to do so.

We have heard that all that nonsense and all those fabricated figures about how many beds will be available for people who do not have the money or who have a spouse or carer living in the family home. But the spouse or carer is facing a very stark choice: sell the house, find alternative accommodation for yourself and you will get a bed; stay in the house and you will not get a bed. That is social engineering of the very worst kind, because it means the commercialisation of a family relationship. It means that pressure and guilt is being placed on those family members, because if they do not sell the house the aged relative does not get a bed. That is the kind of criteria, that is the kind of society, this government now sees as being normal—the commercialisation of the family relationship.

What is happening here is social engineering of the very lowest and worst possible kind from those opposite, who pretend to stand for the family and who pretend that they care about family values and keeping families together. This bill tears families apart. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crosio, Janice, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I have re‐read this amendment and listened to the Minister for Family Services (Ms Moylan) when she read it out again. The amendment states:

SPEECH.PARA: The approved provider must use the income derived from the accommodation bond and the retention amount in the following ways
(1) to meet capital works costs relating to residential care;
(ii) to retire debt relating to residential care; or
(iii) Where no capital expenditure is reasonably necessary. . .
The amendment continues and others in the House can read it as well.

I must admit that, cynical as I am, the first thing that comes to mind is: so what? Basi cally, where is the protection in this bill to make sure all this is going to happen? I know that the amendment we moved in the Senate was modified and changed to a certain extent regarding the obligatory amount of money that will be taken from the bonds which must be used on capital costs. There has to be certain protection in there.

One of the questions that keeps going through my mind—and after reading and re‐reading this bill, I have become so cynical about it—is: what protection is there to say that the approved provider will not use it for running costs? In other words, surely to God the government's obligation should be to look into the care of people in these homes and to ensure that this money is not the first step of the way and they will gradually go out of this altogether.

We already saw that they want to pass it all over to the states and now we have prevented that. Now this amendment was forced upon the government; it was not willingly accepted. This amendment will now make sure that the provider will use the income derived from the accommodation bond and retention amount in specific ways set out. It does not have a fourth or a fifth clause saying, `If you do not do that, you will loose your licence, and if you do not do that, we will make sure that the accreditation,' et cetera. I feel sure that all of these reasons will be given by the minister. But, as I said before, reasons given in the past by the minister have amounted to zilch, because the bill has come up with one thing and yet it really says another.

The health providers out there are saying that it is not going to meet requirements and the community at the moment is so befuddled they do not know whether they are Arthur or Martha. One person who certainly knows where he is going—as the member for Grayndler (Mr Albanese) reminded me and other people in the debate here today—is Doug Moran. It was very interesting when Kerry O'Brien did an interview with him on 1 April on the 7.30 Report. Doug Moran said that the new nursing home he is building at the moment can be compared to a five‐star hotel for the residents going in there. There is one interesting point made further on during that interview and anyone who wants to have a copy of it is more than welcome to it. He said:

Certainly. Well, a wealthy suburb you'll find that the homes are worth probably twice as much as others. The cars that people drive are worth three times, four times more than the other. I mean, people have to have a choice. This is what democracy is all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's what the minister thinks.

—I know what the minister thinks. This is her way of thinking. This is the person who runs health care centres in New South Wales and now we are being told that he is buying up half of Victoria. Good luck to him. He and his family have become multi, multi‐millionaires through looking after the aged. There is no requirement on people like this who will be using this type of money. There is no requirement in this legislation, even with this amendment that we have put forward, although I hope there will be through annual reporting. I know that the minister will probably get up and say, `Well, they have an obligation which is forced upon them as well to report annually to the parliament.' I believe that is the intention of this amendment. I am pleased that our shadow minister is informing me with a nod of her head that it is the intention that an annual report comes into the parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: I can tell the minister in the chair that annual reporting is not worth the paper it is written on either. One of the people who was actually fudging figures during this government's term and putting X number of staff in a particular nursing home in my electorate had annual reporting or accreditation, but no‐one picked it up. Finally, it took years of delving to find out that it was done by a little trick of the hand. Four more staff were supposed to be working on a night shift, but they did not exist. All of these workers where ghosted and he was making a sizeable profit.

I know that people like Doug Moran probably wrote this legislation. He does not have to worry about the bill's measures, because he was in at the very beginning. He has already got the door open. He is already putting the paintings on the wall and knows that the profit will come from nursing homes in the future where the up‐front fees will be anything up to $100,000 or $200,000. As he said, `You have got a rich home. You've got plenty of money. Why shouldn't you pay?'

My concern is for those who have not. Even now this bill will go through by force of numbers of this government and not because of what the community needs. But this is what the community is going to get. It will be rammed through because the government will marshall all its numbers and just ram it through. In fact, we were told by the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) that if we do not shut up, they will gag it anyway. That is a disgrace.

I was thrown out of the House during the debate on this bill—something that has never happened to me before in this parliament—because I believe it is a deceitful bill put in by a deceitful government. It is about time that we had far more adequate debate in future than being told now, `If we haven't got this bill back to the Senate by 2 o'clock, you are going to be gagged.' The government has the numbers to gag us here in this House and the numbers to shut me up, but I will tell the government that it does not have the numbers to shut me up out there in the electorate. For every person who has to sell their home to get a bed in a nursing home, I will be rolling out the media; I will be rolling them out of their beds; and I will be informing the minister and this government what this means to the community and informing the community what the government is doing to them with this bill. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendment we are considering at the moment will go some way to calling this government and nursing homes to account. In fact, the opposition amendment that we sought to move in the Senate was going to require providers and nursing home owners to actually spend the money raised from accommodation bonds on capital works.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that the government cannot in fact agree to that amendment, even though every single speech that we have heard from government members has been that the reason we need to force people to sell their homes is because we need this money to spend on upgrading nursing homes, on capital works. But when it actually comes into the parliament as an amendment from the opposition, to make sure that this money which comes from the sale of people's homes will be spent in the right and proper way, no, the government cannot agree to such an amendment.

Let us make it very clear what the government is doing: it is going to use this money to pay for recurrent subsidies. It is another way of this government getting out of its obligations to provide care for older Australians. I have been pilloried from one end of this parliament to the other and I am not ashamed of it for one minute. I will continue—along with the member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio)—to make it very clear to older Australians that they will be selling their homes because this government is not prepared to make the contribution that is required to look after them.

What will happen is that the standard of accommodation will be different depending on what you pay. As we know, nursing home owners themselves have already made it very clear that if you pay $88,000 you will get a single room; if you do not you will be in a multibed ward. They have been telling the truth and letting us all know what is going to happen.

When this amendment goes through it will not just be the standard of accommodation that is different for residents of nursing homes: those who pay a higher accommodation bond will also be contributing to the care of those residents. Those who pay higher bonds will insist that they get a higher quality of care.

What will happen in the homes that the member for Prospect just talked about, that is, in homes where they either do not pay accommodation bonds, they pay very low accommodation bonds, or where some people in a nursing home pay higher bonds and some people pay much lower bonds? As a result of this amendment we will see the quality of care being completely different depending on your wealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—That is a shameful situation and one which we would never want to see in our hospitals. At the election we had 18 months ago the government said, `We will stand firm for Medicare. We believe in access to health care on the basis of need.' It was a fairly recent belief, of course. Now we know the truth. Now we see the first inkling of truth from this government, particularly in this amendment.

BREAK.PARA: It does not matter what your wealth is as far as we are concerned. Quality of care and access to care, nursing care or medical care should be based entirely on your health needs; not on the basis of how much money you have, how many cars you own or how wealthy your home is. The member for Bradfield (Dr Nelson) might have plenty of people in his electorate who can pay $150,000, who can secure a decent and better standard of care and who can afford to have roast dinners every night. The people in the electorate of the member for Prospect are not in that position. I want them to know that they will get the same standard of accommodation and care as the people in the electorate of the member for Bradfield.

We will be opposing this amendment because we want to maintain an equal standard of care and access to nursing homes. This government will rue the day that it introduced this bill, because we will continue to argue in the community what this legislation will do to the access of older Australians to nursing home care. It is a very sad day for older Australians—a very sad day indeed.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Mrs Moylan's ) be agreed to.
Noes 40

TAB.TAB: Majority 38

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration forthwith.
Senate's amendments—
(1) Clause 3, page 2 (after line 5), before the definition of hostel resident , insert:
CEO means the Chief Executive Officer of the Services Delivery Agency.
employee , in relation to the Services Delivery Agency, has the same meaning as in the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency Act 1997 .
(2) Clause 3, page 3 (after line 7), after the definition of service pension , insert:
Services Delivery Agency means the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency established by the Commonwealth Services Delivery Agency Act 1997 .
(3) Clause 9, page 5 (line 30), after "resident", insert ", or a person acting for or on behalf of the resident,".
(4) Clause 10, page 8 (line 4), after "person", insert ", or a person acting for or on behalf of that person,".
(5) Clause 11, page 8 (line 7), after "section 5", insert ", or a person acting for or on behalf of that person,".
(6) Clause 11, page 8 (line 17), omit "person's".
(7) Clause 11, page 8 (after line 20), after subclause (4), insert:

(4A) If the Secretary needs further information to reconsider a determination, the Secretary may give the applicant a notice requesting the applicant to give further information within 28 days after receiving the notice.
(4B) The application is taken to be withdrawn if the applicant does not give the further information within the 28 days.
(4C) The notice must contain a statement setting out the effect of subsection (4B).
(8) Clause 11, page 8 (after line 26), after subclause (5), insert:
(5A) The Secretary's decision to confirm, vary or set aside the determination must be made:

PARA.TAB: (a) within 90 days after receiving the request; or
(b) if the Secretary has requested further information under subsection (4A)—within 90 days after receiving the information.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (9) Clause 11, page 9 (lines 3 to 6), omit subclause (7), substitute:

(7) The Secretary must give written notice of the Secretary's decision to the person, or a person acting for or on behalf of that person, within 5 business days after making the decision. The notice must include reasons for the decision.
(10) Clause 11, page 9 (after line 8), at the end of the clause, add:
(8) In subsection (7):
business day means a day that is not a Saturday, Sunday or public holiday in the place concerned.
(11) Clause 17, page 13 (line 7), after "Social Security", insert ", the CEO".
(12) Clause 17, page 13 (line 9), after "Secretary", insert "or the CEO".
(13) Clause 20, page 14 (lines 23 to 26), omit subclause (4), substitute:

(4) If the Secretary delegates a power mentioned in paragraph (3)(a) to the Secretary to the Department of Social Security, the Secretary to the Department of Social Security may, by writing, sub‐delegate the power to any or all of the following:

PARA.TAB: (a) an officer of that Department;
(b) subject to subsection (4A), the CEO;
(c) subject to subsection (4A), an employee of the Services Delivery Agency.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (4A) A sub‐delegation under paragraph (4)(b) or (c) must not be made before 1 July 1997.
(14) Page 15 (after line 15), after clause 22, insert:

PARA.TAB: This Act ceases to be in force on 1 January 1998, unless it is sooner repealed.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mrs Moylan) agreed to:
That the amendments be agreed to.

TITLE.XREF: VETERANS' AFFAIRS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (1996‐97 BUDGETAND OTHER MEASURES) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration forthwith.
Senate's amendments—
(1) Schedule 1, Part 3, page 12 (line 2) to page 14 (line 22), omit the Part.
(2) Schedule 5, page 21 (line 2) to page 24 (line 11), omit the Schedule.
(3) Page 49 (after line 5), at the end of the bill, add:

PARA.EMPHASIS: Schedule 10—Amendments of the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Further Budget and Other Measures) Act 1996 relating to the means test exemption for superannuation assets in certain cases

PROCTEXT.PARA: Repeal the Schedule.
Repeal the Schedule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be disagreed to.

The bill before the House, and it has just recently come from the Senate, introduces budget measures of last year. There is a very strong expectation within the veteran community that this bill will be enacted and take the force of law as of 1 July this year.

What we have seen in the Senate is quite a disgraceful performance by the Labor Party and the Democrats to tack on to this bill legislation relating to superannuation assets and the way they are treated. It really is a cheap shot, it is cheap politics and, worst of all, this bill, if enacted after passage through both Houses, could take effect as of 1 July, in a few days time.

So I call on the shadow minister to listen to the veteran community out there and what they are saying in relation to this bill. The opposition should not be playing games with the veteran community, because the veterans affairs portfolio has almost always received bipartisan support of the parliament.

I would just like to read for the benefit of the House some letters from the ex‐service community in support of this bill. I hope that the shadow spokesman is listening because I really would like to see him show some leadership on that side of the House. They intend to see that this bill will not pass and will not bring substantial benefits to the veteran community commencing on 1 July. Let me read what the RSL have said in relation to these measures contained in this bill:

These two initiatives are of great importance to the veteran community and I would be grateful if you could press for the passage of these through the parliament. There is an expectation throughout the veteran community for early implementation of these initiatives.
The Australian Veterans and Defence Services Council said:
This bill has real benefits for the veteran community and I hope that your colleagues will put their support towards securing early passage of the bill.

One particular measure in the bill which is of particular importance to the Vietnam veterans community is the vocational rehabilitation scheme. It has very strong support from the Vietnam veterans and the veteran community generally. It will help them restore their self esteem. It will help them restore their personal independence. They have fought for a long time to have a measure such as that contained in this bill implemented and passed through the parliament. They struggled for years to get this initiative up and what we are witnessing now is a very cheap political shot in the Senate by the Democrats and the Labor Party in that unholy alliance or coalition that we see up there.
I will read what the Vietnam Veterans Association of Australia say in relation to the delay in the passage of this bill:

This delay puzzled me a little, as the normal bi‐partisan attitude towards veteran issues generally guarantees a speedy passage for such legislation. This legislation is important to the veterans and ex‐service community, particularly that in relation to the vocational rehabilitation scheme.

The government will not be accepting the amendments from the opposition. The bill does require passage in this sitting of parliament. It has substantial measures which will benefit the veteran community. Amendments to implement these measures were introduced in the budget of 1996, so it is long overdue to be passed through this parliament.

The amendments that have come from the opposition relate to a superannuation issue that was decided by both houses of parliament in December of last year, and this is just a disgraceful performance by the Labor Party, in coalition with the Democrats, to delay a substantial measure that is going to bring major benefits to our veteran community, ones which they have struggled to get for a long time. The government will not be supporting the amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It might be difficult for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) to believe, but we actually very strongly agree with him in relation to a variety of very worthwhile measures in this legislation. This is because the legislation with regards to Vietnam veterans and their ability to take up work and have options in life arises from the previous government, as the minister well knows.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister has got on the phone to a few veterans groups and attempted to misconstrue the situation by saying that we are undermining these very necessary changes. The minister talks about hurting veterans and how ignoble it is of us to work against them, but the reality is that this legislation does stem from the previous government. It was our initiative. We are in total support of the vocational training changes, and he is indeed very well aware of that.

Coming in here today and trying to put forward the proposition that veterans organisations support the desirable parts of this legislation is not dealing with the fundamental problems with the legislation. Amongst those is the issue of rental assistance. It is interesting to note that the minister has said at various RSL conferences around the country that the gold card is not in the too‐hard basket for him and that he will fight in relation to that issue. One has to question his ability to persuade this country's Treasurer (Mr Costello) to go anywhere down the line of having a gold card for veterans or widows when we see in this legislation the government trying to victimise a mere 340 veterans in this country. They are bringing in a special provision in this legislation to hit a mere 340 veterans to save a mere $21,000 by changing rental assistance arrangements for single veterans.

When the minister talked about the opposition and the Australian Democrats standing in the way of this vocational measure for veterans and standing in the way of simplification of payments between the veterans' affairs department and the social security department, he left out the downside of this legislation. As I say, it is very questionable why so many resources, so much activity and so much verbiage is put into trying to slash a mere $21,000—and not $21,000 a year but $21,000 over four years. One has to assume that this government's mean mindedness and its victimisation mentality leads them to try to push this measure through the parliament. The government are also attempting to change the superannuation arrangements applying to people between 55 and 65 years of age. We know very well that the government have undermined, in a very real sense, superannuation as a concept in this country ever since they came to power. They are attempting to include superannuation entitlements for the purposes of social security income and assets tests where the person concerned is, as I say, between 55 and 65 years of age. People getting the service pension or income support payments for at least 39 weeks after reaching 55 will have their superannuation and rollover fund assets included in income and assets test.

Once again, it is all right for the minister to say that we are standing in the way of the very noble measures in regards to training for Vietnam veterans, but included in this bill, as I say, are very substantial attacks on veterans. The minister gets up here like Pontius Pilate and says we are against the RSL and veterans and how dreadful that is, but the fact of political life is that there are measures in this bill that are going to hit veterans.

BREAK.PARA: The government are saying we should agree to all of the measures in this legislation and their mean mindedness has led to their trying to threaten the opposition, the Democrats and the Senate that, if we do not agree to every measure, they will throw the whole thing out the door. The responsibility clearly rests with the minister and the government. They are the ones who make the ultimate decision. Because they want to ram through these very undesirable measures in regards to rental assistance and superannuation, they are saying that, if we will not roll over for them in relation to these two measures, they are going to throw all the measures out. Quite frankly, it is very clear it is their responsibility.

I also note in passing the minister's snide references to a so‐called evil alliance between the Democrats and the Labor Party. I seem to recall his leader boasting in the House the other day about their being the first ones to embrace the Democrats and `dance' with them. Both parties have very substantial objections to the measures.
