They hit older Australians, they undermine superannuation, they undermine savings and they hurt people in regard to their ability to live and to essentially finance their rental accommodation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I really should respond to the shadow spokesman's assertion that the costs associated with the opposition's amendment is a cost to the Department of Veterans' Affairs of $21,000. The fact of the matter is that the consequential flow-on cost to the Department of Social Security is a cost of $300 million to revenue. That is why it is a tacky attempt by this opposition to introduce measures that have consequential flow-on effects for the Department of Social Security and will affect revenue to the tune of $300 million.

SPEECH.PARA: This issue was decided by both houses of parliament in December last year. I remind the opposition that they are attempting to delay the passage of this bill by this tacky attempt to introduce, in cooperation with the Australian Democrats, an amendment which is going to delay major benefits flowing through to the veterans community—benefits that they have long sought—when the opposi tion know they started the process of negotiation with the veterans community when they were in government.

I ask them to pass this legislation without amendment. They know that more than a $21,000 cost is involved. There would be a $300 million cost to revenue because of the consequential flow-on effects to the Department of Social Security. I had to point that out because I think the shadow spokesman was attempting in his explanation to paint a picture that we were delaying the passage of amendments that may be seen as sensible all for the sake of saving $21,000. That is quite incorrect.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin, Jenny, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I address these questions through you, Mr Deputy Speaker, to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott). Minister, in your first contribution you said that you had letters from veterans asking that these changes to rent assistance not be made; is that correct? You also suggested that you have had letters from veterans asking that these changes the government has proposed to superannuation continue; is that correct?

SPEECH.PARA: I find it extremely hard to believe, Mr Deputy Speaker, that any veteran would have written to this government and said, `Minister, we think it's a very good idea to have our rent assistance cut by a third.' Can you imagine anybody doing such a thing? They should write, `Minister, I've lost my job through no fault of my own. As a result of the changes in this bill, you're going to force me off unemployment benefits which are my right. You're going to force me to use my superannuation long before I retire.' Minister, are you seriously telling me that you had letters from veterans asking you to do these things? I do not believe it for a minute. I certainly do not believe that there is one social security recipient—

TALK.START.PARA: —That is a very unreasonable accusation to make against one of your colleagues.

—I have asked him to bring the letters. We would be very happy to see them. I do not believe him. If he would like to table them, we will give him leave to do so. I have had hundreds of inquiries about this matter all calling on the opposition to do exactly what we did in the Senate last night and what we will do again in the House today.

SPEECH.PARA: This $320 million that the minister spoke of is money that is being stolen by this government from low income earners' superannuation—mostly men who have lost their jobs through no fault of their own and have no hope whatsoever under this government of getting another job. What does this government say to them? It says, `We're just going to write you off. We don't care about you. We're certainly not going to help to retrain you. There are no longer any retraining programs for you. You're going to be written off and told to use your superannuation.' I have never heard of a more short‐sighted policy than this one.

They have the option to retire if they want to; that is correct, they do have that option. But this legislation is saying to veterans, to those unemployed people or to people on other forms of payment, `Bad luck for you. You've got to use your superannuation. You can't go on to a training program. You can't keep looking for work, because if you do your unemployment benefits will be reduced or your disability payments will be reduced.' This is yet another outrageous attack on older workers who want to continue to participate in this community, whether or not they are veterans. Either way, they should not be forced to retire before they choose to. This government is all about choice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Not anymore. You say `Hear, hear' all you like. This legislation shows that that is absolute rubbish. That mantra you preach out there is meaningless. When it comes down to it, you want to get people out of the system. You want to get them off the unemployment queues. You do not want just the young people off the unemployment queues by taking their rent assistance and the youth allowance off them. You are going to say to them, `You've got to use your super, or your unemployment benefits will be reduced.' This is going to apply to veterans and to social security recipients if this Liberal-National Party government gets its way. We will not be agreeing to it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson, Laurie, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As the previous speaker, the honourable member for Jagajaga (Ms Macklin), indicated, it is absolutely preposterous for the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) to come in today and selectively read a letter from the RSL saying that they essentially support the government's moves with regard to training, most particularly for Vietnam veterans, and measures to ensure that they are encouraged to undertake these programs because of their previous concerns that they might be reduced in benefits if they undertake these kinds of courses. As the previous speaker indicated, we are seeing a selective reading of documents to try to say that veterans organisations in this country—the minister might even have letters from individual veterans for all I know—agree that there are very good measures in this bill.
—Hear, hear!

—No-one is disputing that. I am glad the member for Parramatta reinforces the point that the opposition is essentially in agreement with the very worthwhile measures in this field. But what we are seeing, as indicated earlier, is an attempt to hit a minimal number of people in this country—340 people. People are running around the place intending to inspect how big the bedrooms are, what the house looks like et cetera. These 340 people, who have served this country in armed conflict and have worked in the armed forces, are the targets of a measure to reduce their rental assistance. The minister well knows that there is no rationality to it. Essentially there is a difference between two individuals who have to, in most cases, rent accommodation with two bedrooms and a couple renting accommodation which probably has one bedroom.

SPEECH.PARA: The other part of this measure is to hit older veterans through changes to superannuation. I heard the member for Parramatta (Mr Ross Cameron) talking about creating jobs. He well knows, coming from my region, that unemployment in the Auburn municipality, just next to his electorate, is about 16 per cent. We see 30,000 people—the member might correct me; I might be a thousand or so off—getting the punt from the Public Service in this country. We are seeing an attempt by this government to essentially undermine industrial relations and undermine conditions by having a surplus labour force out there.

These people who are being put off employment, these people who are being retrenched and sacked, are also being hit by this measure with regard to their superannuation payments and being denied access to unemployment benefits. It would be less scandalous if we had a government that was dedicated to job creation, that did have a broad expanse of labour market programs, that did seem to have some initiatives with regard to industry policy, that did not discourage research and development assistance to companies and that did not undermine companies and this country's ability to compete in export markets.

If we had a government that was actually doing those kinds of things—trying to help industry, trying to help job creation—then it would not be so scandalous that here today, in this legislation, it is saying to those people, `You are part of the process of sacking, of being pushed out the door and being forced onto the unemployment scrap heap. As well as doing this, as well as having policies to put you on the scrap heap, we are also going to make sure that, when you are on the scrap heap, you cannot get access to unemployment benefits because of the changes we are going to make to superannuation.'

The legislation also, quite obviously, undermines this country's ability to marshal savings. What it is going to essentially do is make sure that people who have saved their superannuation money are forced to spend it earlier. It is thereby going to undermine the country's ability with regard to financing its infrastructure and undermine its need to borrow money overseas.

In conclusion, it is absolutely ridiculous for the minister to come in here today and selectively say that there is an attempt by the opposition to defeat the good measures that are in this legislation. It is the government's decision. It is a threat of the minister in the Senate to basically say that the whole thing is out the door if we do not agree to these measures. Fundamentally, we very strongly oppose the superannuation changes. We very clearly oppose the rental assistance changes.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Mr Bruce Scott's ) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Bruce Scott) agreed to:
That Mr Tuckey, Mrs West, and the mover be appointed a committee to draw up reasons for the House of Representatives disagreeing to the amendments of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott, Bruce, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr BRUCE SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Veterans' Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the committee appointed to draw up reasons for the House disagreeing to the amendments of the Senate, I present the reasons, which are being circulated to honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons read as follows—
The Amendment proposes Schedule 1, Part 3 be omitted.

Schedule 1, Part 3 will provide for a reduced rate of rent assistance to be paid to certain single pensioners who, through shared living arrangements, are able to reduce the living expenses from those which they would incur if they were living alone.

The proposed provisions direct income support according to the needs of people. It is inequitable if there is no differentiation in the rent assistance for the accommodation costs borne by single people living alone, and those of single people who, for a range of reasons, share accommodation and so reduce their individual costs of living.

The amendment will allow the payment of a higher rate of rent assistance to single people who have achieved lower living costs and this will continue to put these people at an advantage over others who cannot defray these costs.
Accordingly, the House of Representatives opposes this Amendment.
The Amendment proposes Schedule 5 be omitted.
Schedule 5 allows the means testing of superannuation investments held by certain pensioners who are under pension age, but over 55 years of age.

The amendment would continue an exemption that allows people to draw on the public purse for income support after they have permanently left the work force and to keep their superannuation investments aside for use at some later date.
The amendment would continue to exempt these payments and so continue to allow income support payments to be determined not according to actual need, but according to investment choices.
Accordingly, the House of Representatives does not accept this Amendment.
The House does not accept the Senate amendment relating to removing Schedule 1 of the Social Security Legislation Amendment (Further Budget and Other Measures) Act 1996 .
The reasons are:

This measure was considered last year and was passed by parliament in December 1996. Using a Veterans' Affairs Bill, with a range of beneficial measures for veterans, as a vehicle to try and undo legislation which was agreed to only seven months ago is unacceptable.

People have already started to rearrange their financial affairs based on the fact that legislation has already been passed. To repeal the measure now would create further uncertainty and would disadvantage people who have already withdrawn their savings from superannuation funds.
This amendment is estimated to cost around $300 million in outlays over the next four years. It would seriously affect the government's fiscal objectives.

People with modest superannuation savings will not be affected by this measure. It is targeted at those with substantial superannuation assets, who have the capacity to contribute to their own sup port. The House believes strongly that all financial investments held by retired people should be treated equally and assessed under Social Security means tests.
Motion (by Mr Bruce Scott) agreed to:
That the committee's reasons be adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following bills were returned from the Senate without amendment or requests:
Aged Care (Compensation Amendments) Bill 1997, and
Aged Care (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1997

TITLE.XREF: ABORIGINAL LAND RIGHTS (NORTHERN TERRITORY) AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALKER.NAME: Mr WARWICK SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 provides for two ways a grant of unalienated crown land can be made to an Aboriginal land trust that holds title on behalf of Aboriginal people. Land can be granted as a result of a hearing by the Aboriginal Land Commissioner or through a statutory grant of land by including specified land in schedule 1 of the act.

This bill provides for the inclusion in schedule 1 of the act of three parcels of land which were the subject of the Bauhinia Down land claim, the Brumby Plains land claim and the Western Desert (North) land claim in the Northern Territory. In all cases, the Northern Territory government, the relevant land council and the claimants have reached a negotiated agreement which settles the land claims without the need for a hearing by the land commissioner.

There are a number of benefits by proceeding to schedule the land. Most importantly, the claimants will secure title to the claim areas more expediently. In addition, proceeding by way of scheduling eliminates the need for a costly land claim hearing and reflects the growing commitment of the parties to settle claims. Accordingly, it deserves the full support of the Commonwealth and the parliament. There are no financial implications arising from this bill. I therefore have pleasure in commending the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Leave granted for second reading debate to proceed forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition enthusiastically supports the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill. It will pass through the parliament in record time. It was introduced in the Senate yesterday and has been expedited by the government with the consent of the opposition. This bill involves three handbacks under the Aboriginal Land Rights Act in the Northern Territory. It is the way forward. It shows and stands in stark contrast to other matters that the government is bringing forward, which I will talk about later.

SPEECH.PARA: The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Act 1976 provides a mechanism whereby traditional Aboriginal land in the Northern Territory, referred to in schedule 1 of the act, may be granted to Aboriginal land trusts to hold title on behalf of Aboriginal people. Since the act came into operation in 1977, a total of 60 separate parcels of land have been scheduled under the act.

The amendment arises from three settlement agreements reached in relation to land claims. They are: firstly, an agreement between the Northern Territory government, the claimants to the Bauhinia Downs land claim No. 150 and the Northern Land Council; secondly, an agreement between the Northern Territory government, the claimants to the Brumby Plains Station land claim No. 149 and the Central Land Council; and, thirdly, an agreement between the Northern Territory government, the claimants of the Kartangurruru, Warlpiri and Walmejeri Repeat land claim No. 27 and the Central Land Council. Each of these agreements includes a clause in which the Northern Territory government agrees to request the Commonwealth to effect the grant of an estate in fee simple in the land which was the subject of the land claim.

I think it is worth while to go to each of the land claims and give a bit of an outline in relation to each one. Bauhinia Downs is located in the Gulf region of the Northern Territory. It is some 110 kilometres from Borroloola and 520 kilometres south‐east of Katherine. Darwin is around 700 kilometres away by road. The property is accessed by 80 kilometres of formed gravel road from the sealed Carpentaria Highway.

The lease occupies an area of 1,450 square kilometres. The western boundary is contiguous with the eastern boundary of Broadmere pastoral lease. In the north it bounds Nathan River and Lorella pastoral leases. To the east and south it shares boundaries with Billingarrah and Carpentaria Downs pastoral leases respectively.

Numerous tracks connect the homestead with various yards, watering holes and watering points. One main track connects the homestead and watering areas‐yards in the lease's centre and north. The most convenient northern access is the Roper Bar‐Borroloola road, which crosses the lease's north‐eastern corner. The few tracks in the south and the south‐west are vague and are restricted to four‐wheel drive use. The north‐west corner is accessible by helicopter only, as is much of the mountainous eastern area.

The claim area's outstanding topological feature is the mountain escarpment which dominates the north‐west and eastern parts of the lease. This area contains many springs and waterholes, a result of the Limmen Bight River‐Eastern Creek drainage system. The permanent waterholes and spring‐fed creeks that dissect the lease here were the foci of traditional Aboriginal occupation and cosmological interest. The west and south‐west of the lease have fewer Aboriginal sites and water sources.

The region's climate is monsoonal, with hot, humid summers and mild, dry winters. Average rainfall is between 700 and 800 millimetres a year, mostly falling in the summer months. Average relative humidity is a major factor in determining the level of comfort by the people in the area. Humidity is high for over half the year.

The lease's pastoral potential is hampered by the terrain, even though it is classified as the most economic of the small Gulf pastoral properties. Forty per cent of the lease is considered to be good pastoral land, that is, the majority of the northern half. The south‐west corner has some grazing potential but is of little use due to its inaccessibility.

The lease has a strong potential tourist attraction through the sandstone column foundations in the north, thermal springs and pools, waterfalls and pools adjoining the escarpment and flora and fauna areas of interest. The lease was an area traditionally associated with Alawa, Mara, Kurdanji, Wilingara and Binbinga people. Some have stressed Alawa interests above others. Usually the lease is described as a region where people of different tribal language affiliations meet up for ceremony, holiday et cetera and then go back to major centres like Roper River, Tanumbirini and the old McArthur River homestead. A particularly noted ceremony and camping area was the Manaburru site complex, where ritual bosses would send out men with message sticks inviting various groups and individuals for ceremony. The anthropological sources support the assertion that the lease was associated with a number of different tribal groups.

The next one I will deal with is the Brumby Plains land claim No. 149. The Brumby Plains pastoral lease of 1,170 square kilometres is located adjacent to the Western Australian border in the north‐west region of the Northern Territory. A land claim over the area was lodged in August 1994 on behalf of traditional Aboriginal owners. Anthropological research and field work began in 1995 in preparation for the land claim. Many Aboriginal people who gave strong evidence in the Mistake Creek land claim were also involved in the preparation of this claim, as the area lies immediately to the north of Mistake Creek station.

The land claim was set down for September 1995 but just prior to the hearing the Central Land Council and the Northern Territory government reached agreement regarding settlement of the claim. The terms of settlement provide for the land under claim to be granted as Aboriginal land by way of addition to schedule 1 of the land rights act. They also deal with a number of practical matters, including the maintenance of existing give and take fences with adjacent pastoral leases.

In relation to the Western Desert (North) locality, that land claim is the Kartangurruru, Warlpiri and Walmejeri (Repeat) land claim No. 27. The area represents the last portion of vacant crown land available for claim in the Tanami region. It is some 2,400 square kilometres in size. It was an area of land not recommended for grant in the original Western Desert land claim.

At the beginning of 1996, negotiations were begun with the Northern Territory government with a view to settling the claim without the need to proceed to a full rehearing of the matter. Negotiations revolved around accommodating the interests of the Parks and Wildlife Commission of the Northern Territory in the region. These negotiations were finally concluded in May. Terms of the settlement provided for the land to be scheduled in the land rights act as Aboriginal land with traditional owners and the Parks and Wildlife Commission of the Northern Territory forming a joint committee to oversee flora and fauna surveys, feral animal control and bushfire management within the region. Additionally, traditional land owners agreed not to run cattle in the area for at least five years.

The terms of settlement represent a sensible and practical conclusion to the claim. Traditional land owners will obtain title to the land at an earlier stage than could be expected if the claim had to be fully heard by the commissioner. Both the Central Land Council and the Northern Territory government were spared much expense. The Parks and Wildlife Commission of the Northern Territory and traditional owners both stand to benefit from each other's land management expertise. Exploration companies active in the region gain certainty in that the title to the land is determined now rather than at some later date.

These are shining examples of what can happen when stakeholders negotiate in good faith. It is the Labor Party's view that this is the shining example and the way forward. The government is to be congratulated for now bringing this legislation through the parliament and the handbacks occurring.
I think it does nail a few of the myths about the land rights act. Part of the problem has been the intransigence of the Northern Territory government in relation to a number of these things.

I propose to now give a bit of history to the Aboriginal Lands Rights (Northern Territory) Act, because I think it is important. This is a much stronger act for indigenous people in the Northern Territory, yet settlements are occurring with good will. No-one is losing out. There is mineral development occurring, a number of representative bodies are well resourced and mining companies know who to deal with. It stands in stark contrast to what the government is proposing through its amendments to the Native Title Act.

In Milirrpum v. Nabalco, Justice Blackburn rejected the claimants' arguments that their traditional laws and customs pertaining to their land were capable of recognition by the common law. Twenty-one years later, the High Court, in Mabo, corrected that view. However, Justice Blackburn's comments on the system of traditional laws and customs give us the philosophical basis on which the land rights act was built. It was only after Justice Blackburn wrote these words that the Woodward royal commission into Aboriginal land rights was commissioned. The crucial words of Justice Blackburn, which appear at page 267 of the judgment, were as follows:

I cannot complain of any lack of evidence, and I am very clearly of the opinion, upon the evidence, that the social rules and customs of the plaintiffs cannot possibly be dismissed as lying on the side of an unbridgeable gulf. The evidence shows a subtle and elaborate system highly adapted to the country in which the people led their lives, which provided a stable order of society and was remarkably free from the vagaries of personal whim or influence. If ever a system could be called "a government of laws, and not of men", it is that shown in the evidence before me.

The Woodward royal commission was set up to find a way for the Australian nation to accommodate those systems of laws and to give legal protection to those laws and cus toms. Justice Woodward's report provided the basis on which the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia enacted the land rights act.
Justice Woodward's terms of reference asked him to investigate—this appears at page 183 of the report—the following:

The appropriate means to recognize and establish the traditional rights and interests of the Aborigines in and in relation to land, and to satisfy in other ways the reasonable aspirations of the Aborigines to rights in or in relation to land . . .

In particular, Justice Woodward was to look into ways of vesting in appropriate bodies title to land then reserved for the use of Aboriginal people and the desirability of establishing a claims process for Aboriginals seeking to assert their traditional rights.

The Woodward report showed us the way and left the nation in no doubt why it was the right thing to do. Justice Woodward set out the aims of Aboriginal land rights by saying this in his second report, the Aboriginal Land Rights Commission—Second Report—April 1974, at page 2:
In order to achieve recognition of land rights for Aborigines in the best possible form, it is necessary first to be clear as to the aims underlying such recognition. I have assumed these to be:
(i) the doing of simple justice to a people who have been deprived of their land without their consent and without compensation,

(ii) the promotion of social harmony and stability within the wider Australian community by removing, so far as possible, the legitimate causes of complaint of an important minority group within that community,
(iii) the provision of land holdings as a first essential for people who are economically depressed and who have at present no real opportunity of achieving a normal Australian standard of living,
(iv) the preservation, where possible, of the spiritual link with his own land which gives each Aboriginal his sense of identity and which lies at the heart of his spiritual beliefs, and
(v) the maintenance and, perhaps, improvement of Australia's standing among the nations of the world by demonstrably fair treatment of an ethnic minority.

It is now appropriate to give a broader background to the Aboriginal land rights act of the Northern Territory. It was passed by the Fraser government in 1976 and came into effect in January 1977. It was started by the Whitlam Labor government. A watered down version of that act was then passed by the Fraser government. Malcolm Fraser and his government are to be congratulated, because I think that was the right thing to do. On these issues and on apartheid, Malcolm Fraser stood above his party and took his party with him. He showed leadership. He was right.

Until recently, for the last 30 years, these issues had cross‐party support. The Liberal Party could quite properly claim a high moral ground on these issues. But, sadly, since the High Court's decision in Mabo, cross‐party support has crumbled. Since the election of John Howard to the leadership of the conservatives, the conservatives have gone backwards at a rate of knots.

The land rights act was drafted by the previous Whitlam government following on from the Woodward commission into Aboriginal land rights, the report of which, as I said, was tabled in 1974. The freehold tenure provided by the act offers traditional owners the greatest security of tenure of any form of land title available in Australian law. It also allows them to control developments on their land. Under the act, Aboriginal people have regained ownership of approximately half of the landmass in the Northern Territory.

There are four land councils in the Northern Territory: the Northern Land Council, covering the top end of the Northern Territory; the Central Land Council, covering the southern half of the Northern Territory; the Tiwi Land Council, covering Bathurst and Melville islands near Darwin; and the Anindilyakwa Land Council, covering Groote Eylandt. Despite claims that the act would lock up land and be detrimental to the Northern Territory economy, all Australians, and particularly Territorians, now benefit from the act. More than 80 per cent of the value of minerals extracted in the Northern Territory comes from Aboriginal land. This is more mineral exploration activity on Aboriginal land than on non-Aboriginal land in the Northern Land Council region. Almost 16 per cent of Aboriginal land in the Northern Land Council region is now covered by exploration agreements, and a similar area of land is now under negotiation for exploration, with promising prospects. The international tourism dollar attractions—Uluru, Kakadu and Nitmuluk national parks—are on Aboriginal land.

The act provides certainty for business through established processes for dealing with traditional Aboriginal landowners and native title holders. It has been conservatively estimated that the Northern Territory government has spent $10 million to $15 million opposing every major land claim under the act. They have lost almost every legal challenge they have lodged. This money would have been better spent on addressing the chronic state of Aboriginal employment, health and education in many parts of the Northern Territory.

The trade‐off offered to Aboriginal people for the imposition of a sunset clause in the act was the enacting of the Northern Territory's community living areas legislation which would allow Aboriginal people to negotiate small areas of land as excisions on pastoral leases. This law, aimed at providing living areas for Aboriginal people displaced by the pastoral industry, has largely failed Aboriginal people, with the Northern Territory government again obstructing the process. Many Aboriginal people—and, for that matter, most other Australians—are locked off pastoral leases. Successful claimants usually win only small parcels of land on huge pastoral operations.

Recently a book edited by Galarrwuy Yunupingu was launched. The first part of the book's title is Our land is our life: that summarises the association Aboriginal Australians have with their land. Land is critical to their culture, to their stories, to their paintings and to their dreaming. That is why it is critical that this government responds correctly to the High Court's decision on Wik. In revisiting the Mabo High Court case and the Native Title Act, they need to be sensitive to that fact. What we have seen to date is turning the clock back.

The book, the full title of which is Our land is our life: land rights—past, present and future, should be read by everybody. It is non‐threatening. It gives ordinary Australians an understanding of the issues. The irony is that no‐one will lose their backyard, their farm or their pastoral lease as a result of the Mabo High Court decision, the Wik judgment of the High Court and the Native Title Act. That is the reality. There have been misconceptions, misinformation and scaremongering.

The Labor Party stands ready to support amendments that improve procedures under the act, but it is not necessary for the government to rip the heart out of the Native Title Act, which is what is proposed in the 213 pages of amendments that have been produced today. I now put the government on notice that the Labor Party will not walk away from the High Court's decisions in Mabo and Wik and the Native Title Act. The 10‐point plan is the final act of dispossession, and those amendments are crazy amendments because they will create division in our community. I do not think the government has the numbers in the Senate to get those amendments up in their present form. Even if they do, I believe what we will see is litigation in the High Court, because this parliament cannot legislate just willy‐nilly.

We are celebrating the 30th anniversary of the 1967 referendum when another conservative government took a proposal to the people to change the constitution so as to give the Commonwealth parliament the constitutional obligation and the moral obligation to protect indigenous people from the states. That legislation went through this parliament with cross‐party support. Only a yes case was put, and over 90 per cent of the Australian electorate voted for that proposal. Up until the Mabo decision, this was an area where there was cross‐party support. What happened was that the conservatives lost the 1993 election, and politics crept in.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Liberals.

—The conservatives lost the 1993 election and politics crept into this area. The facts speak for themselves, because there is no‐one who can point to one centimetre of land being taken away from people's backyards, or their farms or leases. It is ironic, because the current Prime Minister (Mr Howard) was a cabinet minister in the Fraser government.

SPEECH.PARA: I understand there is a problem with the National Party because Rob Borbidge is looking for an election and Tim Fischer had to find an issue to reconnect with his backbench after the issue of guns, but what is required is a generosity of spirit from this government. And we will support them. The Native Title Act can be improved to the benefit of all parties.

The people who were really affected as a result of the Wik decision were the miners, because they were required to negotiate with indigenous people on pastoral leases. They are happy to do that. That is a way in which Aboriginal people can achieve economic independence apart from government. In the current climate of hostility, we have just seen the Century Zinc project approved. How did that happen? The company utilised the provisions of the Native Title Act.

Today is a day of celebration when we are handing back three areas of land to these people—and we should all be proud of that, because there were negotiations in good faith, and it did not have to be a knock‐down drag‐out situation that went all the way to the courts. But, in stark contrast, on the same day that we are doing this, there is sadness because the government has produced 213 pages of amendments that rip the heart out of the Native Title Act and further dispossess indigenous people.

In effect, you have a conservative government in power that says, `Let the marketplace rule', and yet these amendments come down on the side which is against Aboriginal people in the negotiations with mining companies. There is no need for that. I can understand the fear of the farmers, the pastoral leaseholders and those in rural and regional Australia, because they are acting on misinformation. The Labor Party will go through these amendments line by line clause by clause. We will cooperate with the government on procedural aspects to improve the act for all the stakeholders.

This is the irony of it—the government's own platform. This is the mandate. This is the coalition's policy in the lead‐up to the last election, with the fingerprints of the John Howard all over it. It said the coalition's approach to Aboriginal land rights were based on the following:
(a) the fact of Native Title where it has survived;
(b) the Constitutional protection given to all property interests against Government resumption without compensation;
(c) the prohibition of racially discriminatory measures or laws; and
(d) the special relationship between Indigenous people and land which is at the core of Indigenous culture.

I urge the Prime Minister to stick to that policy because this native title amendment act is discriminatory against Aboriginal people. It is the equivalent of overriding the Racial Discrimination Act.
In his policy platform the Prime Minister also said that in government the coalition would:
(a) retain the Native Title Act;
(b) reserve the right to amend the Native Title Act to ensure its workability—
and that can be done without attacking indigenous people's rights and without attacking the right to negotiate—
(c) respect the provisions of the Racial Discrimination Act—
and that is the most important thing of all—
(d) ensure that any amendments to the Native Title Act are preceded by wide consultation.
Sadly, this amendment to the Native Title Act does not fulfil those promises. There is no need to go down that path.

It is tremendous that we have cross‐party support on this bill before the parliament today. That is the way it should be and that is the way it has to be. We are all diminished if we start playing politics with indigenous people because it is not only a domestic issue—the world is watching. So I congratulate the minister and his office and I congratulate the government on the amendments that we are debating here today because that is the way forward.

Australia does not have a white Anglo‐Saxon history alone. We have a rich 50,000‐ to 60,000‐year history where indigenous people have had an association with land. We should be respecting the High Court's decisions in Mabo and Wik because they are non‐threatening; they are win‐win situations. If we cannot respect the culture of our first Australians, how can we respect the culture of other Australians from overseas? How can we go to Asia or other countries and engage their cultures when we have no respect for the culture of the first Australians? It will affect the economics of our trade around the world because if the government continue with their amendments they will end up with a situation where we will be pariahs on the international stage. I again say to the government: do not think we will walk away from indigenous people because we will not. If we do, then we as a Labor Party are diminished and we as a nation are diminished.

This is a moral question. It is not about land rights; it is about human rights. That is why I have said this today, because of the inconsistencies. We want consistency in the argument. I commend the bill to the House; it deserves unanimous support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Speaking in 1925 as President of the American Bar Association, Charles Hughes, who later became Chief Justice of the Supreme Court of the United States of America, said:

SPEECH.PARA: The most ominous sign of our time as it seems to me is the indication of the growth of an intolerant spirit. It is the more dangerous when armed, as it usually is, with sincere conviction. It is a spirit whose wrath must be turned away by the soft answers of sweet reasonableness.

The Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill 1997 is a voice of reasonableness. It is a means whereby issues between the native title holders and pastoralists and other interests can be negotiated to achieve a satisfactory outcome. I hope all those in this parliament have regard to the existence of the bill as a way forward through these controversial issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALKER.NAME: Mr WARWICK SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—In summing up the Aboriginal Land Rights (Northern Territory) Amendment Bill to reach the timetable of a 3 o'clock close off, I would like to thank the shadow minister, the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham), and his colleague for their comments. This is a bill that enjoys bipartisan support and the government certainly welcome this. This is a matter that has been negotiated by all parties. It is a demonstration of what can be achieved and I think we are all very pleased about that. I am a little disappointed that the shadow minister sought to go into some other matters but, having myself been a former shadow minister for Aboriginal affairs, I know the nature of the intractable problems that are dealt with by all of us on these particular issues. A little bit of goodwill goes a long way and that has certainly been the case today.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Warwick Smith) read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members, I present a schedule showing government responses to House of Representatives and joint committee reports for the period 14 December 1996 to 27 June 1997 and reports presented to which responses are outstanding. Copies of the schedule have been made available to honourable members and it will be incorporated in Hansard .

SPEECH.PARA: The schedule read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES AND JOINT COMMITTEE REPORTS AND REPORTS PRESENTED TO WHICH RESPONSES ARE OUTSTANDING FOR THE PERIOD 14 DECEMBER 1996 TO 27 JUNE 1997

SPEECH.PARA: On 19 June 1997, the Government presented its response to a schedule of outstanding Government responses to parliamentary committee reports tabled in the House of Representatives on 12 December 1996. The Government affirmed its commitment to respond to relevant parliamentary committee reports presented during the present Parliament within three months of their presentation and to clear, as soon as possible, the backlog of reports arising from previous Parliaments.

The Government's commitment follows the undertaking by successive Governments to respond to parliamentary committee reports in a timely fashion. In 1978 the Fraser Government implemented a policy of responding in the House by ministerial statement within six months of the tabling of a committee report. In 1983, the Hawke Government reduced this response time to three months but continued the practice of responding by ministerial statement. The Keating Government generally responded by means of a letter to a committee chair, with the letter being tabled in the House at the earliest opportunity.

The attached schedule lists Government responses to House and joint committee reports made since the last schedule was presented on 12 December 1996. It includes actual Government responses to ten reports of the Procedure Committee tabled between 1988 and 1996. These were included in a document presented to the House on 19 June 1997, and are shown in footnotes to this schedule under the heading `Government Response, 19 June 1997. It also lists reports for which the House has received no Government response. It is intended that a Speaker's schedule of outstanding responses will continue to be presented at approximately six monthly intervals, in the last sitting weeks of the winter and spring sittings.

The schedule does not include advisory reports on bills introduced into the House of Representatives. The Government's responses to these reports is apparent in the resumption of consideration of the relevant legislation by the House. Also not included are reports from the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, the House of Representatives Committee of Members' Interests, the Committee of Privileges, the Publications Committee and the Selection Committee. Responses to reports of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts are usually made in the form of Finance Minutes, which are tabled by the Committee. Government responses to reports of the Public Works Committee are normally reflected in motions for the approval of works after the relevant report has been presented and considered.
27 June 1997

BREAK.PARA: 1. The date of tabling is the date the report was presented to the House of Representatives. In the case of joint committees, the date shown is the date of first presentation to either the House or the Senate. Reports published when the House (or Houses) are not sitting are tabled at a later date.
2. If the source for the date is not the Votes and Proceedings of the House of Representatives or the Journals of the Senate , the source is shown in an endnote.
3. The time specified is three months from the date of tabling.
4. The three month period had not expired as at 27 June 1997.

5. In its paper presented to the House on 19 June 1997 (referred to hereafter as the 19 June 1997 paper) the Government indicated that it `is currently considering its response which will be tabled as soon as possible'.
6. In the 19 June 1997 paper, the Government indicated that it was `finalising a response to this report, which will be tabled at the earliest possible date'.
7. In the 19 June 1997 paper, the Government indicated that a response `is expected to be tabled during the 1997 spring sittings'.

8. The Joint Select Committee on Certain Family Law Issues recommended that the Auditor‐General conduct an efficiency audit of the Family Court of Australia. The Auditor‐General's report was tabled on 15 May 1997. The Government will finalise its response to the Joint Select Committee's report when it has given consideration to the Auditor‐General's report.

9. The former Government tabled an interim response on 29 March 1995. The 19 June 1997 paper noted that `it is anticipated that a final response to all outstanding recommendations will be tabled in 1997'.
10. The 19 June 1997 paper indicated that `consistent with the recommendations of the report, the Government response will be finalised by 31 October 1997'.
11. The Committee's report recommended that the Government give consideration to a range of technical issues. A response is under consideration and is expected to be tabled shortly.
12. The Government is giving consideration to its response. It is expected that the Government response will be tabled during the 1997 spring sittings.

13. The 19 June 1997 paper said that `a whole of government clearance process is currently in progress for the draft response. It is expected that the response should be tabled during the 1997 spring sittings'.

14. A whole of Government clearance process is currently in progress for the draft response. It is expected that the response should be tabled during the 1997 spring sittings. The Minister for the Environment has written to the Chair of the Committee reporting progress on the preparation of the response.

15. A comprehensive response is being prepared to take account of the recent positive Government initiatives such as the Green Corps, the Work for the Dole Scheme and the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia.

16. The Committee was advised that a Government response to the report would be provided after the public review of the Commonwealth's environmental impact assessment process which addressed many of the policy and procedural issues raised in the Committee's report. The Minister for the Environment has since decided to defer consideration of the outcomes of the public review until after COAG consideration of the `Review of Commonwealth‐State Roles and Responsibilities for the Environment'.
17. It is expected that the Government response will be tabled during the 1997 spring sittings following consultation with relevant ministers.
18. The 19 June 1997 paper indicated that a `final Government response will be tabled as soon as the relevant consultations are completed'.
19. The 19 June 1997 paper notes that `the Government is currently finalising its response which will be tabled at the earliest possible date'.

20. The 19 June 1997 paper said that the report `is being considered in the context of the Government's review of GBE Governance Arrangements and the response will be presented once the review outcomes are known'.
21. The 19 June 1997 paper notes that `consultations amongst ministers on a final response to the report are in progress. A final response will be presented as soon as possible'.
22. The Government indicated in its 19 June 1997 paper that its response was `under consideration'.

23. The 19 June 1997 paper said that the Government `is examining the Committee's recommendation, but the complexity of the issues involved has delayed the Government response. It may be some time before a response is finalised.
24. The 19 June 1997 paper said that `the Government does not intend to respond to this report'.

A number of the recommendations made by the Committee referred to projects that were already being undertaken, for example, the preparation of the Territory of Heard Island and McDonald Islands (HIMI) Management Plan, and the development of Criminal Procedure Ordinances for HIMI and for the Australian Antarctic Territory.

Other recommendations relate to matters which are now out of date, for example, the need to develop a tourism annex to the Madrid Protocol which the Antarctic Treaty Consultative Parties have addressed in another manner.
25. The 19 June 1997 paper said that `the Government response is still under consideration'.
26. The 19 June 1997 paper said that `the Government response will be tabled as soon as the relevant consultations are completed'.
27. The 19 June 1997 paper said that `the two reports will be addressed during the debate on amendments to the Native Title Act 1993 in the Parliament'.

28. The 19 June 1997 paper said that `this report was provided by the Procedure Committee in response to the Government's request for a review of the currency of the findings contained in ten reports presented in previous Parliaments. Final Government responses to the ten reports are provided below'.

29. Government Response, 19 June 1997. Revised arrangements for the conduct of divisions were implemented for a trial period from 18 March 1997 until the end of the 1997 autumn sittings. The trial period was extended on 26 March 1997 to continue until the end of the 1997 winter sittings. A decision regarding the longer term arrangements will be taken in the light of experience during the trial period.
30. Government Response, 19 June 1997. The Government does not propose to seek any changes to the traditional proceedings for the opening of Parliament.

31. Government Response, 19 June 1997. The recommendations of the report were implemented on 26 March 1997 for a trial period until 26 June 1997 in respect of the Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training. A decision regarding the longer term application of modern technology to committee proceedings generally will be taken in the light of experience during the trial period.

32. Government Response, 19 June 1997. Subject to consultations with the Opposition and independent members, the Government has in mind making the following amendments to standing orders in response to the report recommendations:
. standing order 303—to include a reference to sessional orders in part (d);
. standing order 308—to refer to the less severe action of suspension of sitting first;

. standing order 309—to enable a motion requiring a member to attend the House to be moved without notice, and to remove the reference to taking a member into custody which is covered by the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987;

. standing order 310—to omit the reference to taking or delivering any stranger into custody as such action is covered by the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987 and the Parliamentary precincts Act 1988, and to replace it instead with a reference to the removal of any stranger;
. standing order 311—to remove the reference to members or other persons being brought to the Bar for disciplinary action; and
. standing order 312—to require senators, when in the senators' gallery, to observe instructions concerning order issued by the Chair.
The Government also accepts the recommendation to omit standing order 313.

33. Government Response, 19 June 1997. The existing requirement for a private member to obtain a seconder in order to lodge a notice of motion is not an onerous one and ensures that a matter appearing on the Notice Paper has the support of at least one other member apart from the proponent. The Government sees no compelling reason to dispense with the requirement.

34. Government Response, 19 June 1997. The Government notes the present Committee's intention to conduct an inquiry into the structure and operation of the committee system, thereby making it unnecessary for the Government to respond to the two 1989 reports at this time.

In relation to the 1991 report, the present Committee has remarked on the severity of the minimum penalty recommended in relation to the unauthorised disclosure by a member of in camera evidence obtained during committee hearings, but has not made any alternative suggestion to this key recommendation. In the light of this and the linkages between this report and the 1989 reports the Government believes there is merit in the Committee encompassing the issue of disclosure of in camera evidence, including the level of associated penalties, in the wider inquiry to be undertaken of the committee system.

35. Government Response, 19 June 1997. The Government accepts the report's recommendation that the House provide citizens with a right of reply in appropriate circumstances along the lines of the procedure already adopted by the Senate.

36. Government Response, 19 June 1997. The Government believes that current standing orders are appropriate for the handling of petitions and does not propose to make any changes pursuant to the report.

37. Government Response, 19 June 1997. The Government believes there is merit in removing the present anomalous situation of tabled documents being treated differently by the two Houses of Parliament and will move to amend standing order 320 to extend absolute immunity in respect of all documents tabled in the House.

38. The Government does not propose to respond to this report as the issues involved will be overtaken by the Standing Committee on Communications, Transport and Microeconomic Reform's current inquiry into federal road funding.
39. The 19 June 1997 paper notes that the Government response is `expected to be tabled shortly'.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Reith) agreed to:

That the House, at its rising, adjourn until Monday, 25 August 1997, at 12.30 p.m., unless otherwise called together by the Speaker, or, in the event of the Speaker being unavailable, by the Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Industrial Relations; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALKER.NAME: Mr REITH
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the House)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That leave of absence be given to every member of the House of Representatives from the determination of this sitting of the House to the date of its next sitting.

In so moving, given the circumstances currently facing the chamber and the importance of the House having the benefit of the attendance of all of the members, I would like to say that it is appropriate in the usual circumstances of the final sitting of the chamber that this motion should be so moved. It is the circumstance facing the House that as usual we will proceed to complete the business of the chamber in the next hour or thereabouts. Upon the satisfactory conclusion of the matters before the House, the House will then rise. This motion provides for the necessary leave of absence to all members for the winter break, with the House resuming in August.
As you appreciate, under the constitution it is necessary for leave of absence to be given to all members. Otherwise, we might find ourselves constitutionally invalidated.
Mr Beazley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —By way of benign interjection, I think it might be three months.
—Three months, is it?
—Or is it two months? I am not sure. It must be a period shorter than that.
—This will be heinous news for some of our well‐known travellers.

—I was not going to say anything provocative in case someone asked for your indulgence, Mr Speaker, to provide a reply. This is the usual motion. I am delighted to see the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party, the member for Higgins (Mr Costello), now in the chamber. It is one of the few times you have been late! With those few words to meet the necessities of the circumstances now facing us, it is my pleasure to commend this motion for leave of absence to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: CLERK OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES: RETIREMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week, I informed the House of the impending retirement of the Clerk, Lyn Barlin. Although I spoke briefly at that time, I want to take this opportunity to add to those remarks and to record my admiration, respect for and gratitude to a specialist and splendid servant of this parliament, a gentleman in every sense of the word and an outstanding Australian.
—Hear, hear!

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —Lyn Barlin began his career with the Public Service Board in 1949. He joined the Department of the House of Representatives in August 1954 and served in a number of positions within the department before being appointed Serjeant‐at‐Arms in March 1969. In addition to the usual duties and responsibilities of the serjeant, on one memorable sitting day Lyn found himself called upon to demonstrate his dexterity with a pair of bolt cutters when a group of demonstrators chained themselves to the railings of the public gallery. He tackled this unusual task with the same deftness and proficiency he applies to the numerous and different challenges that come his way and, as usual, he achieved a splendid and successful outcome.

INTERJECT.PARA: In January 1977 Lyn was promoted to Clerk Assistant and in September 1982 to Deputy Clerk of the House. He then acted for a time as Secretary to the Joint House Department before a further promotion in June 1983 to Deputy Clerk of the House, level 4. He was appointed Registrar of Members' Interests in 1985. On 25 March 1991 Lyn was appointed Clerk of the House of Representatives.

He was awarded membership in the General Division of the Order of Australia in the Queen's Birthday honours list in June 1995. Over the years, Lyn has made a continuing valuable contribution to the House in particular and to the parliament in general. He was very closely involved with the planning and building of new Parliament House, at times needing to employ all his diplomatic skills and to use his vast experience and knowledge of how this place operates to steer the project through some very turbulent waters. He undertook this role in addition to his normal responsibilities.

Lyn will leave an indelible mark on the procedures of the House. He brought the 90‐second statements idea back from Canada and persuaded the Procedure Committee of its merits. He was also instrumental in the establishment of the Main Committee.

The third edition of House of Representatives Practice, which bears his name, is regarded as a valuable handbook and procedural guide in this parliament and around parliaments the world over. He has made a significant contribution in the area of members' interests, having been registrar since its inception. He has handled these responsibilities with characteristic care, tact and discretion, particularly over the past few months.

Lyn Barlin's dedication to and understanding of this institution and the needs of its members have earned him admiration and respect not only in Australia and in the adjoining Australasian and Pacific nations with which he has had a very close association but also in other countries throughout the world where he has represented the Australian parliament with distinction. He is held in the highest esteem by his peers in the United Kingdom, Canada and other Commonwealth nations. His views are widely and keenly sought on matters relating to parliamentary practice and procedures, as well as all aspects of parliamentary administration.

BREAK.PARA: For many years, he served as a member of the Society of Clerks at the Table in Commonwealth Parliaments and has been a member of the Association of Secretaries General of Parliaments since his appointment as Clerk to the House. Lyn has accompanied Australian parliamentary delegations overseas and has always acquitted himself with distinction when called upon to provide advice or assistance. He has made an outstanding contribution to the rules and procedures of the Australian Pacific Parliamentary Forum.

By the very nature of their duties, senior officers of the House do not seek to be noticed; in fact, they go to considerable lengths to ensure they are effectively hidden in the backdrop of parliamentary life. Throughout his long career, Lyn Barlin has meticulously observed this tradition.

Time and time again, the assignments Lyn has been given, the challenges he has confronted and the responsibilities he has quietly shouldered, have been far beyond those that could be reasonably expected. No matter what the magnitude or difficulty of the task or the personal strain imposed on him, the underlying strength of his character, his personal sincerity, his unfailing courtesy and patience and his unequivocal loyalty and dedication have remained evident. It is not surprising that he enjoys the confidence of and is held in the highest regard by members on both sides of this House.

Finally, I want to acknowledge the role of Beryl Barlin, who, with some of her family, is here in the gallery this afternoon. For the majority of his many years service to this parliament, Lyn has enjoyed the support and understanding of Beryl, his wife for almost 37 years. They have three sons—Philip, Russell and Mark—and a daughter, Colleen, and are elated at the prospect of spending so much more time with their four lovely grandchildren. With his approaching retirement, Lyn will have more time to spend with Beryl and their family and to pursue his other interests, including trout fishing—and I understand his stocks of trout fishing equipment have been augmented this day—field and clay target shooting and gardening.

Congratulations, Lyn, on a job well and truly done. You should be very proud of all you have achieved these past 43 years. We are sincerely grateful for your wise counsel, impartial advice, professional guidance and, particularly to me, friendship. Enjoy your retirement. You have certainly earned it. Whatever you may do in the forthcoming years, we wish you and Beryl health, happiness and our very best wishes for your future together.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reith, Peter, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Industrial Relations; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALKER.NAME: Mr REITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industrial Relations)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this House places on record its appreciation of the long and meritorious service to the parliament by the Clerk of the House, Mr L. M. Barlin AM, and extends to him and his wife and family every wish for a healthy and happy retirement.

In moving this motion, it is important to note that this is an important occasion in the life of the parliament. We today mark with respect the retirement of Lyn Barlin. As we do so, we celebrate the traditions and values of our democratic inheritance. We do so jointly because it is a fact that, as our democratic values are shared, it is in the sharing of those democratic values that gives strength to the democracy that we all enjoy. It is the shared nature of those democratic values which ultimately provide the practical reality of our democracy for all citizens.

Lyn has not only added and contributed in his own inimitable fashion to this process and to these values; he is also a living link to the very traditions that we refer to today. When he started, Menzies was in government and Frank Green was the clerk. In fact, Frank Green had been the Clerk of the House of Representatives before its move to Canberra in 1927. Lyn was here in August 1954, aged 22, a young whippersnapper, and he has seen a hell of a lot since.

He was here in 1955 when Browne and Fitzpatrick had their bags packed for them down to the Goulburn gaol. He was here in 1959 when he took on a particular interest in the work of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association and followed that up for many years involved in organising conferences in Canberra and the like. In the 1960s, he was Serjeant-at-Arms; in fact, he was promoted in March 1969 to the position of Serjeant-at-Arms. In that capacity, he was Clerk of the Committees—the only secretary to the committees. The evolution of the committee work in the House of Representatives has been something which Lyn has participated in and contributed to for a long time to give us the committee structure we have today.

As Serjeant‐at‐Arms, he was here when certain persons chained themselves to the seats in the gallery—and he was there with the bolt cutters to preserve order in the chamber! He was here at the end of the 1960s when Billy McMahon was on the phone—Tiberias on the phone—and he was here when we saw a change of government in 1972.

He was here on another occasion when Gordon Bryant was allegedly disorderly. He was ordered to be removed, but he was not in a hurry to go. So a few of the heavies on the Labor side sat around him as the Serjeant-at-Arms tentatively went across to require his removal. As he got closer, he thought to himself, `The best policy here is to cajole Gordon outside.' So he said, `Come on, Gordon, let's go for a drink,' to which Gordon loudly responded, `I don't drink!'

He was here during the 1970s: Whitlam came and went and standards were restored with the return of the conservative government. In January 1977, he was promoted to Clerk Assistant. He was here in September 1982, when he was promoted to Deputy Clerk of the House and, for the first time, Registrar of Members' Interests.

He was on the sort of forerunner of the committee involved in the establishment of this parliament, the new Parliament House, and that work was very important in the establishment and the building of this place. On 25 March 1992, he was appointed to Clerk of the House of Representatives. In June 1995, on the occasion of the Queen's birthday honours list, he was awarded membership in the general division of the Order of Australia. Of course, he was here for the changeover of government in March 1996.

All through those years he has been a symbol of consistency; in fact, he has been a mark of consistency in the conduct of the affairs of this House. That is important. The importance of that should not be understated. This parliament lies at the centre of the democratic institutions in this country, and at the heart of those democratic institutions must be due process. Due process is, of course, an essential characteristic, a valued tradition, which ultimately provides protections for people of their basic rights. Lyn has been here through all of those things. He has participated not just in the daily life of the parliament but, of course, in many innovations and changes, in various controversies and in great moments in the life of the parliament.

He was particularly responsible for the new procedures which you, Mr Speaker, have mentioned. He also oversaw the introduction of the Main Committee. The smooth introduction of that was a tribute to the work that the clerks, led by Lyn Barlin, had done. It would be fair to say that he has experienced some of the disappointments of the parliament as well. Whilst today is not a day to dwell on such things, I do say that he has been with us through the good times and the not so good.

I know there is unanimity of opinion on both sides of the House that Lyn Barlin has always placed great value on giving good advice, advice which is sound and advice which is effective and, most importantly, unbiased. So, whatever your position in the House might be, Lyn Barlin—and the clerks—has been a person to whom you can go to for sound and sensible advice.

Today I saw a little cameo performance, I suppose, in my dealings with Lyn Barlin in respect of the management of the House. We thought that the opposition might have been running a filibuster on the Aged Care Bill, the bill of the Minister for Family Services (Mrs Moylan). I talked to him about what we might do and thought of a short-cut proposition, which I advanced to Lyn. He said, `I don't want to be any trouble to you. I don't want to be difficult. In fact, I apologise for being difficult.' I said to him, and I am sure he will not mind me saying this, `It is not being difficult to give good advice. In fact, it is the one thing we look to in the clerks—to give fearless advice, to give independent advice and to require of us that we take a bit of a deep breath and ensure that we maintain good standards and that we are due and diligent in understanding the procedures of this place.'

TALK.START.PARA: —So did you drop off?
—I did drop off on the short-cut method. But I must say I still have it in my back pocket for after Lyn has gone, and subject to circumstances in which we might find ourselves later.

SPEECH.PARA: Lyn Barlin and the clerks are sphinx like: seen but not heard. In fact, it is quite a lesson to us all—a hell of a lot can be achieved in this chamber by saying nothing. As to Lyn Barlin behind the scenes, outside of this parliament, I was at a dinner last night and heard the first interjection I have ever heard from Lyn Barlin—with a bit of luck, it will be the last.

He has played a central role in the process of this parliament. Lyn, you do great honour to the office of the clerk. You rank equally with the great clerks who have preceded you—people like Frank Green, Doug Blake, whom I knew personally, Alan Browning and Jack Pettifer, just to mention some. Given the great service that we have had from the clerks, I believe that that is one of the highest compliments one can give to any clerk—that they have maintained the standards of this place.

I also add my personal thanks to your wife, Beryl, and your family. We all in this place know the extra burden suffered by spouses. We thank your family, who are in the gallery today, for the tremendous support that they have given you in the work that you have done. It is my great pleasure and great honour to commend this motion to the House.

TALKER.NAME: Mr BEAZLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have much pleasure in supporting the motion that has been moved by my successor. It is the only really decent speech he has made in the 15 months since he has had the job. You can actually agree with every line in it and, indeed, effect more than a little surprise at how erudite it was and what a very good summary it was of the history that Lyn Barlin has found himself involved with.

BREAK.PARA: This is a chamber governed by standing orders. It makes law, and it provides a sounding board for the great issues of national life. All members of this place are pretty good at the third of those aspects of this parliament. We, as parliamentarians, are pretty good at airing in this place the great issues of national life. We are not necessarily as good at making law. Indeed, most of us know very little about it in a legal, technical sense. When it comes to standing orders, basically we know nothing at all. The position of the Clerk on those latter two elements is extremely invaluable.

I had occasion to know that early when I became Leader of the House. Lyn Barlin's predecessor said to me, `There are really only 10 standing orders that you need to know.' That was news to me; I thought there were only about two. The fact that there were 10 was an advance for a Leader of the House. Of course, the Clerk has to know them all. He can be absolutely certain that the Leader of the House will know no more than 10 and that the Speaker will know no more than 12. The role that is therefore played by the Clerk is absolutely essential.

We absolutely have to be certain in this place that we pass laws correctly and that the affairs of this House are conducted within the traditions of this House and the framework of the orders put in place for that to be done. I know that most of the things that a Leader of the House does on many occasions probably stretch those standing orders to the limit to suit the convenience of the government of the day. When Leader of the House, I spent most of my time with Lyn discussing these situations. I suspect that that is not dissimilar in the experience of the current Leader of the House (Mr Reith).

However, as the opposition leader, you spend most of your time in this position: looking across the chamber at Lyn's face to see if he is as truly sphinx‐like as he was described by the Leader of the House. In particular, we look for the lift of the eyebrow, the slight curl of the lips, the slight looking down at the nose and the speed with which he turns to the Speaker. If it is very quick, the Speaker is in serious trouble; if it is a slower movement, he is in less trouble; if there is a slight smile, I am absolutely right; if he is looking down the nose, I have committed yet another crime against the traditions of the Westminster system. So it is a face that is more like a mat than a middle‐eastern statue.

The important point is this: you really want to know inside your head what it is you are doing when you are operating in this chamber. What he suggests is absolutely right. That is part of the value of a very long period of service. Lyn has been a senior officer of this parliament for near 30 years.

This is one of the great Westminster parliaments, the Australian parliament, with a lot of innovation in it, as well as a lot of tradition. The role that is played here by the senior officers of the parliament, including the clerk, is one which is bankable elsewhere through the system. Over the lengthy years of his service, the qualities which Lyn has evinced have seen him in advisory roles, have seen him involved with some of the other great parliaments, including the mother of them all, the UK parliament, and have seen him as an adviser to people who are embarking on the course of membership of the Westminster system.

Lyn has also contributed to the latest version of the bible by which we are governed—that is, the green book, which, when I first became a member in this place, was handed to me as something that I must read. It is actually a much more fascinating read than a lot of people think, but it is so important that it be right. The fact that it is authored effectively every few years—in fact, probably a little longer than that—by the clerk makes it a compendium of the wisdom of the very few officers who have served in that position in this place. I think the latest edition of it is the best, and certainly the most interesting, and I have read every single one of them on the way through.

I think Lyn has had more of a sense of innovation than most clerks. The changes that we made with the Main Committee—both sides of the House agreed with these—and the changes that have been put in place in putting in the committee structure and the really quite dramatic improvement in private members' time that has occurred over the last decade or so really has an awful lot to do with the contribution of Lyn and of other members of parliament. It is not just a question of the clerk; there are people on both sides of the House who have been very good servants of the interests of all of us in that regard. Nevertheless, an awful lot of the advice, and certainly its translation into standing orders, is most important too.

Apart from the usage of the guillotine and the fact that Leaders of the House turn their backs on him, there has been nothing that has given Lyn more grief than the changing role of the Senate over the course of the last few years. Many was the occasion when I was Leader of the House in which I would have to outrage Lyn by failing to defend the position of the House of Representatives, vis‐a‐vis the Senate, so at this time of the year and during the latter phases of the year we could actually get a piece of legislation through and accept the whole range of parliamentary manoeuvres in the Senate over the years, which have slowly, steadily and quietly whittled away the powers and prerogatives of the House of Representatives.

Suffice it to say, while he has not died in the ditch about it, it has not gone through without protest. I think it bespeaks very well of Lyn that those changes have taken place with a degree of resistance from him. It is going to be difficult for the Speaker in circumstances in which there is a considerable amount of turmoil and volatility now in the structure of the parliamentary administration to have to make the changes that he will have to preside over and on which he will have to negotiate with his counterpart in the Senate over the course of this next little while without Lyn Barlin being there. It is going to be hard for you as those events transpire, because you have had some very wise counsel over the years.

As I said at a very nice occasion organised by the government whip outside the chamber, Lyn had the good sense to marry a Western Australian. He has had the good sense, too, to develop his sporting attributes over the years. The combination of the two are going to ensure him a long, well earned and very enjoyable retirement. The Labor Party at tempted to make a small contribution to that just before we had this valedictory in the chamber.

You are going to be missed enormously, Lyn, by people on both sides of the House. You have been properly honoured by your fellow Australians with the Australian award that you have received. You will be properly honoured historically by your version of House of Representatives Practice, which will, no doubt, be succeeded in another few years.
