Whoever rewrites it, as time goes by, will probably not have had as much interest in it that has been contributed by himself or herself as you at least had the opportunity to do in the variant you produced.

As I said, you will be missed by all of us. You will be missed, in particular, by those members who have responsibility for the day-to-day administration of the House, but you do leave it a better place.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr COSTELLO
TALKER.ROLE: Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —Listening to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) talking before about the way in which the Senate has, bit by bit, whittled down the powers and prerogatives of the House of Representatives, it occurred to me that one of the presents that would make Lyn the happiest is what we are about to do in a moment, which is to reject the Senate attempt to try to amend a tax bill and send it right back to the Senate for their consideration. If you can sign off on that as one of your last acts as the Clerk of the House of Representatives, the people's house, I am sure that will give you great pleasure indeed.

SPEECH.PARA: I had the privilege of saying a few words on behalf of the clerk already this morning. I have really enjoyed having that honour because we know that the parliament is losing one of its finest people. The fact that you will be given tributes from both sides of the House in very similar terms today indicates the very special position that you hold in the esteem of all of us and the very special way in which we will miss you.

Lyn, I think you have been the clerk nearly all the period that I have been here. As the Leader of the Opposition said, it was an infallible guide to speakers' rulings to read your face. In fact, sitting over here on the frontbench, quite often we figure out that we can short‐circuit the point of order, the Speaker's ruling and the outcome by getting the wink or the nod from you before we get to our feet. It is almost like a coaching from the side stage to know whether or not a point is worth taking.

Lyn followed his older brother George here to Canberra when he was 16 or 17. He came from a dairy farm near Taree and he took up a position, first of all, with the Public Service Board and then, in what was obviously a great career move, joined the Commonwealth Treasury shortly thereafter. I have been back through all of those records from when you were in the Commonwealth Treasury, Lyn, and I am pleased to say that you were not scarred for life by that experience, which lasted for only four months.

TALK.START.PARA: —He didn't have a television screen down there to watch the Treasurer.

—Yes; in those days they did not watch the House of Representatives on television down in the Treasury. The Clerk, as he was to become, was personally picked out by Frank Green and brought up here to the House, and he began 43 subsequent years of unstinting and dedicated service to the House and the parliament, through 10 prime ministers, 18 parliaments and great parliamentary events, as Assistant to the Speaker, Serjeant‐at‐Arms, Clerk Assistant, Deputy Clerk of the House of Representatives and finally Clerk of the House of Representatives. One of the things I have figured out in politics is that, the higher you go, the shorter your title becomes, and to finish up as Clerk is of course a great tribute to Lyn and a great tribute to the parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: When you think of the words that describe Lyn, you think of the words `professionalism,' `poise,' `integrity,' `independence'—all of the things that you would like to see in a person who keeps the traditions, traditions which go back centuries in the case of clerks. You would be familiar, Lyn, with a piece that was written on clerks and members of parliament called Clerks and members of parliament: a personal view of the relationship in Australia by P.A. O'Keeffe, the Clerk Assistant, in which he quotes Chaucer:
As coy and quiet as a virgin wife
Newly espoused and sitting mum at table.

I have reason to thank you for sitting mum at table because when I made a speech earlier you interjected and, I must say, Lyn, it was far more difficult to handle than any of the interjections one ever gets from the opposition. So thank you for sitting mum at table all of those years. We even discovered earlier on that, as a result of some legislation that went through the parliament, Lyn is looking for compensation in respect of a couple of guns that he owned. Fancy sitting mum at table whilst the parliament passed legislation in respect of what in fact were some of your great hobbies, as I understand: clay shooting and fox hunting.

We will miss Lyn. We will regard this as a sad day for us and a sad day for the parliament, but we know, Lyn, that you will have put in place the structures that will continue the great traditions and that, as clerks come in and they continue the traditions, traditions go from strength to strength and they add that little bit of lustre to the parliament, that little bit of lustre that is above the daily political machinations but is so much a part of the tradition that we have become part of and that has enriched us. I agree with the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) that you will be compared with the great clerks, that they will remember you as one of the great clerks in the House of Representatives, and that in future people will be pleased to be compared with you.

The other thing that will surprise you, Lyn, is that you probably know all of the little messages that come up to those who are at the dispatch box giving instructions—and I have just received one to keep on talking.

TALK.START.PARA: —With ease.

—With ease. I want to go back and recount some of the other incidences in a more boisterous fashion that you will have been part of, Lyn. The first thing that has always amazed me about the clerks of the House is that you can sit there without showing any sense of favouritism at all. I think it was one of your predecessors, Jim Odgers, who told colleagues when he left the Senate that he was certain that he had been impartial because over 42 years of service he had been accused of being a supporter of every political party in the parliament and that guaranteed absolute independence.
—It could not possibly have included the Country Party; everybody draws a line at that.

—They did not have the One Nation party in the parliament at that stage. What takes on additional skill, of course, is that at moments of great humour and great wit in the parliament you, as the Clerk of the House of Representatives, are also forbidden from laughing. To actually laugh at particular occasions would of course show a kind of partiality. One of the things you learn when you come here whilst in opposition and one of the government ministers makes fun is that you should never laugh or appear to laugh at an opposition jibe on camera. I suppose in clerk training this advice is always given as well because I can say that, even in your comments and your demeanour and your smile and your laughter, you have taken great pains to be impartial, if I may say so. You a very impartial person when it comes to wit and witticisms in the House as well.

SPEECH.PARA: This has been not only a role which has been performed in our country over the course of the century but a role which has been performed in parliaments dating back to Westminster for nearly seven centuries. You are the keepers of the flame; you are the keepers of the tradition; you are the keepers of the propriety; you are the keepers of the process. And you are, in many respects, the keepers of the constitution because, if we should miss the procedure, as the Leader of the Opposition has said, at some particular point, then the law could be a nullity or it could be void or it could be irregular. It is the clerks that ensure that we keep within the letter of the law in the constitution. In that way you have a very deep constitutional role to play in the parliament as well.
On behalf of the Liberal Party and on behalf of all of my colleagues, I express our gratitude and our best wishes to Beryl and to you, Lyn Barlin, Clerk of the House of Representatives.
Debate interrupted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill returned from the Senate with amendments.
Ordered that the amendments be taken into consideration forthwith.
Senate's amendments—
(1) Schedule 1, item 2, page 5 (lines 6 to 13), omit the definition of Commonwealth education or training payment , substitute:

PARA.TAB: Commonwealth education or training payment means a payment by the Commonwealth, or in connection with a payment by the Commonwealth, of an allowance or reimbursement:
(a) to or on behalf of a participant in a Commonwealth labour market program; or
(b) to or on behalf of a student under:

TAB.TAB: (i) the scheme known as AUSTUDY; or
(ii) the scheme known as ABSTUDY; or
(iii) the scheme known as the Assistance for Isolated Children Scheme; or
(iv) the scheme known as the Veterans' Children Education Scheme;

PARA.TAB: in respect of a period commencing at a time when the student was at least 16 years old.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (2) Schedule 1, item 4, page 5 (lines 25 and 26), omit the item, substitute:
Repeal the subparagraph, substitute:

TAB.TAB: (i) an amount received by a student from a person or authority upon condition that the student will (or will if required) become, or continue to be, an employee of the person or authority;

(ia) an amount received by a student from a person or authority upon condition that the student will (or will if required) enter into, or continue to be a party to, a contract with the person or authority that is wholly or principally for the labour of the student;
(ib) an amount received by a student under a scholarship where the scholarship is not provided principally for educational purposes;

PROCTEXT.PARA: (3) Schedule 1, item 9, page 7 (after line 28), at the end of section 24ABZE, add:

PARA.TAB: (4) Expressions used in this Subdivision that are also used in Part 8 of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 have the same meanings as in that Part.

(5) Expressions used in a section of this Subdivision that relates to payments under a particular provision of Part 8 of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 that are also used in that provision have the same meanings as in that provision.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (4) Schedule 1, item 9, page 7 (line 30), omit "Subject to subsection (2), the", substitute "The".
(5) Schedule 1, item 9, page 7 (line 34) to page 8 (line 4), omit subsection 24ABZF(2), substitute:

PARA.TAB: (2) Payments under section 169 of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 (which deal with bereavement payments) are exempt.
(3) If a taxpayer derives a payment under section 170 of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 :

TAB.TAB: (a) so much of the sum of that payment and other payments under Part 8 of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 derived by the taxpayer during the bereavement lump sum period as is not more than the tax‐free amount calculated in accordance with subsection (5) is exempt; and
(b) the balance of the sum is not exempt.
(a) a taxpayer's partner died; and

(b) the taxpayer would have been qualified for payments under Division 10 of Part 8 of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 apart from paragraph 168(1)(f) of that Act (taxpayer's allowance increased on partner's death to such an extent that no bereavement payments); and
(c) the taxpayer derives payments of youth training allowance during the bereavement period;
then those payments are not treated under subsection (1) but are treated as follows:
(d) the supplementary amounts are exempt;
(e) so much of the balance as is more than what would have been the balance (payments less supplementary amounts) if the partner had not died is exempt;
(f) the rest of the balance is not exempt.

PARA.TAB: (5) The tax‐free amount referred to in paragraph (3)(a) is worked out as follows:

TAB.TAB: Method Statement

Work out the amount of payments under Part 8 of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 that would have been derived by the taxpayer during the bereavement lump sum period and would have been exempt if:
(a) the partner had not died; and
(b) if immediately before the partner's death the couple were an illness separated couple or a respite care couple—they were not such a couple;
the result is called the notional exempt amount for the taxpayer .

Work out the amount of payments (if any) under Part 8 of the Student and Youth Assistance Act 1973 or the Social Security Act 1991 that would have been derived by the partner during the bereavement lump sum period if the partner had not died: the result is called the notional amount for the partner .
Add up the notional exempt amount for the taxpayer and the notional amount for the partner: the result is the tax‐free amount .

PROCTEXT.PARA: (6) Schedule 1, item 11, page 8 (lines 13 to 23), omit paragraph (b), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (b) consisting of a Commonwealth education or training payment (see subsection 6(1)), except where the recipient, or the individual on whose behalf the recipient receives the payment, is an employee of any person who is entitled to a Commonwealth subsidy in respect of the employment; or

PROCTEXT.PARA: (7) Schedule 3, item 8, page 15 (lines 23 and 24), omit the item.
(8) Schedule 3, item 9, page 15 (lines 25 and 26), omit the item.
(9) Schedule 3, item 20, page 17 (lines 5 and 6), omit the item.
(10) Schedule 3, item 21, page 17 (lines 7 and 8), omit the item.
(11) Schedule 3, page 18 (after line 2), at the end of the Schedule, add:

PARA.TAB: For the purposes of the 1996‐97 financial year:

TAB.TAB: (a) a share in a company is deemed to be a qualifying share if:
(i) the first, second, third, fifth and sixth of the 6 conditions set out in section 139CD are satisfied; and
(ii) at the time the share was acquired, at least 2/3 of the permanent employees of the employer were, or at some earlier time had been, entitled to acquire:
(A) shares or rights under an employee share scheme; or
(B) shares or rights in the employer, or a holding company of the employer, under another employee share scheme; and

PARA.TAB: (b) an employee share scheme is deemed to be operated on a non‐discriminatory basis if, and only if, the following conditions are satisfied in relation to all offers during the 1996‐97 financial year to acquire shares or rights under the scheme:

TAB.TAB: (i) participation in the scheme is open to at least 2/3 of permanent employees of the employer; and
(ii) the time for acceptance of each offer is reasonable; and
(iii) the essential features of each offer are the same for at least 2/3 of permanent employees of the employer; and

PARA.TAB: (c) a scheme for the provision of financial assistance in respect of acquisitions of shares or rights under an employee share scheme is deemed to be operated on a non‐discriminatory basis if, and only if, the following conditions are satisfied in relation to all financial assistance provided during the 1996‐97 financial year under the scheme:

TAB.TAB: (i) the time for taking up each offer of assistance is reasonable; and
(ii) the essential features of each offer of assistance are the same for at least 2/3 of permanent employees of the employer.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (12) Schedule 3, page 18 (after line 2), at the end of the Schedule, add:

PARA.EMPHASIS: 27 Transitional—market value of shares and rights

PARA.TAB: For the purposes of Division 13A of Part III of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 , the market value of a share or right on a particular day on or after 28 March 1995 and before 12 December 1996 where the share or right is quoted on a share market of an approved stock exchange on that day may be determined under whichever of the following is chosen by the relevant taxpayer:

TAB.TAB: (a) section 139FA of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 as amended by this Schedule;
(b) section 139FA of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 before being amended by this Schedule.

PROCTEXT.PARA: (13) Schedule 5, item 1, page 47 (lines 3 to 5), omit paragraph (1)(a), substitute:

TAB.TAB: (a) an asset that is being used solely for the personal use and enjoyment of the individual, but not including an asset which may:
(i) appreciate in value; or
(ii) have a resale value of more than $5,000; or

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to indicate to the House that the government proposes that amendments Nos 1 to 9 and 12 be agreed to and that amendments Nos 10, 11 and 13 be disagreed to. I suggest, therefore, that it may suit the convenience of the House first to consider amendments Nos 1 to 9 and 12 and, when these amendments have been disposed of, to consider amendments Nos 10, 11 and 13. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That Senate amendments Nos 1 to 9 and 12 be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make a couple of observations on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1), referring to three areas of the bill which relate to the Senate amendments. The first of these relates to the tax exempt status of scholarships. This exemption has come under threat as a result of a tax office draft ruling. We sought to remove this threat by simply removing the provision of the act under which the ruling was made. The government opposed us on this, raising the question as to what the government's agenda might actually be. Indeed, the minister in the Senate referred to amendments to remove this threat as `offensive'. I can only hope he was joking.

SPEECH.PARA: Instead, the government did a deal with the Australian Democrats to provide a lesser degree of protection to the tax exempt status of scholarships, a deal the Democrats carefully neglected to consult relevant education organisations on. The reason for this behaviour by the Democrats is unclear. That, however, is where the matter lies. It is to be hoped that the expressed intention of the Senate of removing this threat to the tax exempt status of scholarships is in fact achieved.

A second set of Senate amendments rejected the government's attempts to weaken the status of employee share schemes by lowering the threshold of qualification for tax concession status from 75 per cent of all employees to 60 per cent of permanent employees. What has the government got against casual workers? Why shouldn't they be included in employee share schemes? I would have thought that the logic of the argument for tax concessions for such schemes would apply equally to casual employees as to other employees. Many casual employees do in fact work for long periods, sometimes many years for the one employer. Indeed, I would have thought that raising the status of casual employees would get bipartisan support in this parliament.

If the government wants to encourage employee share ownership schemes, as it says it does, why does it want to reduce the number of people in an enterprise that the scheme applies to? This signifies an elitist approach on the part of the government. It talks a lot about reducing fiscal deficits, but it always seems to find fiscal room for elitist, regressive tax concessions. The Senate's rejection of this change is to be welcomed.

Finally, I mention the amendment made to the bill to change the $5 million net business assets test on access to capital gains tax rollover relief into a net assets test. Labor amendments have ensured that the private wealth of an individual, as well as the business wealth, is taken into account in determining access to the rollover provisions. Once again, we have acted to help the government with its fiscal task in a way that is much more socially acceptable than the government intended.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

BREAK.PARA: Motion (by Mr Miles) proposed:
That amendments Nos 10, 11 and 13 be disagreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I ask that the division be called off.

—The member for Sydney has indicated that he wishes the division to be called off. We were about to divide on the question that amendments Nos 10, 11 and 13 be disagreed to. I now declare that motion carried.

BREAK.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Mr Miles) agreed to:
That Mr Billson, Mr Barresi, and the mover be appointed a committee to draw up reasons for the House of Representatives disagreeing to amendments Nos 10, 11 and 13 of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the committee appointed to draw up reasons for the House disagreeing to amendments Nos 10, 11 and 13 of the Senate, I present the reasons, which have been circulated to honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment 10 frustrates the Government's attempt to rectify a blunder by the Labor Government when enacting the principal legislation. It omitted the word "permanent" from subsection 139CD(5) so that the section refers to employees rather than permanent employees.
In newspaper reports in December 1995 the office of the then Treasurer, Mr Ralph Willis admitted the error and promised to resolve it as soon as practicable.

The House does not accept amendment 10 as it prevents that error from being corrected. Therefore employers will be required to base the employee participation requirement for each scheme on all of the employer's employees, including casual employees rather than just employer's permanent employees.

This amendment which applies for the 1996‐97 financial year, which is almost complete, seeks to impose a further requirement on schemes to qualify for concessional tax treatment. Whilst it does adopt the Government's proposal to reduce required participation to two thirds, it also requires that the scheme is non‐discriminatory in that each offer of shares must be the same in all respects to each permanent employee. This additional requirement that schemes must meet is being imposed at the end of the financial year and may deny employees and employers who expected a tax concession under the current law that concession. Accordingly the House opposes the amendment.
The first amendment seeks to include in the $5 million threshold all personal use assets of the taxpayer excluding those that may appreciate in value or have a resale value of more than $5000.

This imposes an extra condition for eligibility for rollover relief which is inconsistent with the Government's election commitment and imposes heavy compliance costs on small business taxpayers. The House accordingly opposes the amendment.
Motion (by Mr Miles) agreed to:
That the committee's reasons be adopted.

DEBATE.TITLE: CLERK OF THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES: RETIREMENT

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The opportunity to speak on the motion that recommends and commends the work of Lyn Barlin is indeed not only a great privilege but also a sad occasion because we are losing one of parliament's great men and great contributors to the way in which this House and this chamber has progressed under his leadership in the Clerk's chair.

SPEECH.PARA: It was a pleasure last night to have dinner with Lyn and Beryl in the Speaker's dining room, to talk more informally and to hear Lyn make a very erudite, witty, probing and controversial speech. He would have made a good member of this place. I guess the great tribute to Lyn is that many people would be guessing on which side he would sit had he chosen to take that course. It was a pleasure, Lyn, to be with you and Beryl last night.

A number of people have spoken of the qualities that you have brought to this office. I believe that you have brought a real stature to it. You have dignified the office in the way in which you have conducted your role, the affairs of the office and the way in which you have treated people on both sides of the parliament. There is a confidence in you. It has been referred to as the knowing winks and looks, et cetera, but it is far more the advice that we get by going directly to you about procedures that we are seeking to embrace, for which we will always get a very clear answer. If we do not get it immediately, which is seldom, then we will get it soon after, with proper thought, consideration and immediacy given to the task of follow‐up.

Lyn, you do know what you are talking about, and it is not only a great credit to you but also an asset to this parliament. The people that you have brought on under you have developed those similar qualities. In the sense that you have developed those qualities, you have also understood the importance of passing them on to your successors.

It is also leadership that places you amongst the best of the clerks that this parliament has been served by. You have been an innovator. Reference has been made to 90-second statements, which is something that you drove, and also the private member's bill, which I have been very interested in because this was an innovation that I knew very little about from the six years that I spent on the other side of the parliament.

Indeed, we recently had occasion to introduce a private member's bill, which I introduced, in relation to the car tariff issue. With the assistance of the clerks, and Lyn in particular, we produced a private member's bill which, when it was shown to the industry people to see whether anything had been left out, they could not find a fault in. It is therefore a credit to you that you have to deal with important technical questions and ensure that they get the policy prescription right. That is a very difficult task. Something that we know, as a result of many pieces of legislation having to keep coming back into this place and be amended, is that we have been able to go to you with confidence and have the private member's bill put into effect.

Reference has also been made to the great work, which was completely updated and overseen by Lyn—the House of Representatives Practice. I must admit that it is not exactly something I have read from cover to cover.

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, we know that.

—I have learnt all of the important points on the basis of experience, drawing on references from this from time to time. But this is a mighty work, and it is important that it be done. This place is an institution that operates not just on set procedures but on precedence, former rulings and practices. For someone to bring it together, to put it together in a cohesive form, is a mighty legacy to this place from you so soon before you are about to retire.

SPEECH.PARA: We have also found the interesting device of being able to use that maligned other house to get messages back to us that enable us to debate things. This, too, was used to great effect in relation to the car tariff question. But these are things that come from going to the clerks with a proposition and saying, `Can this be done?' and being prepared to work with them—not against the rules, but within the rules. That is a relationship that I believe is essential for all in the House to develop, in so far as the clerks are concerned, and it is one in terms of cooperation and response that I have not, in the time that I have held the position of Manager of Opposition Business in this House, been able to fault.

Lyn has served this parliament for 43 years. It is a long and enormously distinguished career. It is one where he has made many friends over the years. Reference has been made to the fact that he has seen 18 parliaments through, 10 Prime Ministers and, I think, 13—or maybe it was 18, I cannot remember—Speakers. But you have seen them all through. Whilst those of us who are fairly recent additions to this place are effectively seeing you through now, it is the contribution that you have made over those 43 years that will be with us for a long time into the future.

I just want to place on record my appreciation for the unstinting cooperation that I have had from you, Lyn. I have been in the parliament just over seven years—six of them in government, where the role is different because essentially, as a minister, the House is about authorising what the executive determines. It is a much different role in opposition; it is a much different role as either a backbencher or a shadow minister.

BREAK.PARA: When I was asked by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) to take on this role of Manager of Opposition Business, the first place I headed for was Lyn Barlin's office to get some understanding as to what these standing orders really meant. I said, `I don't really understand these standing orders, Lyn.' I was very frank with him. He looked at me surprised and said—and I do not think I am breaching a confidence here—`We were delighted that you got the task because you were one person that we really thought did take the place seriously and did understand the standing orders.' I said, `Well, I take the place seriously. But learning the standing orders is something, in essence, that comes from experience not just from the written word. We need to get advice from you as to what can be done in accordance with them procedurally as well as in a defensive vein.'

I therefore record my appreciation and gratitude to you for your distinguished commitment over 43 years. I also join with those who acknowledge and appreciate the presence in the gallery of Beryl and some members of Lyn's family. They are the stalwarts that stick by him. Lyn and I leave this place at 11 o'clock at night, and I know he is in very early in the morning. So there are not many hours at home. When the parliament is sitting, he is essentially not seen at home, certainly in daylight hours, from Monday through to Friday.

It is an onerous task, but it is one that must be fulfilled. It is one you have fulfilled with distinction; it is a great credit to you. I will miss you but can certainly indicate to you that any time you are around the place my door is open to you. We would welcome you in there for a coffee and a chat at any time. Of course, if Beryl is with you, she is more than welcome to join us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moylan, Judi, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mrs MOYLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I, too, would like to record today my appreciation and gratitude to the Clerk, Lyn Barlin, for the guidance and direction that he has given to me as a member of this place in general. Today is a sad day because we are losing the services of someone who has had a very distinguished career and has added immensely to the dignity of this place.

SPEECH.PARA: As a relatively new member, I have been the beneficiary on many occasions of Lyn Barlin's immense knowledge. I have been very grateful to have had the privilege of serving in this place while Lyn has been the Clerk. You have set a fine example and I have appreciated that.

Lyn is indeed an outstanding person. His influence, I suppose, comes not only with this immense integrity but also with the impartial and very professional way he has conducted himself. He has also contributed what I feel has been a quiet, dignified presence in this place. In a world of shifting values there has been a constancy, if I may say so, which is reassuring. It is a valuable attribute in the day‐to‐day workings of the parliament.

Lyn Barlin has given long and distinguished service to the Australian people by virtue of his service to this place. He has left a lasting legacy to the parliament and to the people of Australia in the traditions that he has upheld in that long and distinguished service. We will miss you, Lyn; we will miss you a great deal. I wish you and Mrs Barlin a great deal of happiness and joy in your retirement. We look forward to seeing you back here from time to time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I enter into this particular debate this afternoon when the parliament gets the opportunity to say farewell to Lyn Barlin. I have been here for nearly 13 years now. I enjoyed a period of three years as the Speaker of the House of Representatives in the last parliament. Whilst I certainly had contact with Lyn in the time leading up to when I became Speaker, it became more than contact after that time, in 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: Much has been said already by other speakers—the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley), the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello)—about Lyn Barlin the Clerk. Words like `integrity' have been used. Those are the sorts of words, Lyn, that do not quite do you justice. In my dealings as a Speaker, you were always available for discussion, for counsel for wise heads, when perhaps younger, less wise heads wanted to do certain things out of that big chair that the Speaker presently occupies. You were a friend—somebody on whose counsel anybody would be stupid not to rely. In the period that I have been here and in the time that I occupied the Speaker's position, I would like to think that you and I became good mates.

The Leader of the Opposition and perhaps one or two others have made reference to the most recent edition of the House of Representatives Practice. I have to say that when it came out I was very interested to check a couple of things in it. All of us in this place would like to think that in some way we are going to be remembered. If you happen to have been a Speaker, you would like to think you are going to be remembered for some wise and just ruling you have given from the chair at some time. You would also like to think that everyone out there—whoever reads that book—or people who subsequently come to this place believe that you arrived at that wise and just decision on your own. Without giving away too many trade secrets, those wise and just decisions more often than not came from the Clerk.

I was therefore very interested to see whether I featured. The answer was, yes, he was kind enough to include me in the redraft. But I have to say that one of the first things I went to look at in that document was Lyn's interpretation of the sub judice principle. Certainly in my time as Speaker, if there was one issue which caused some difficulty for this parliament, it was an issue involving sub judice.

I am sure my good friend and colleague the member for Fremantle (Dr Lawrence) will not mind if I refer to it briefly this afternoon inasmuch as it did affect a certain set of circumstances in which she found herself in Western Australia. She was a minister of the Keating government and there was a strong view within the government—and I think within the community—that the charges that had been brought against her were politically motivated. It became a government decision at the highest level within that government that those charges would be defended and that the House of Representatives might become, as it were, a second chamber of that defence process whilst a royal commission was under way in Western Australia.

In the two weeks in which the Prime Minister of the day decided he was going to defend the member for Fremantle in this place, the very early morning meetings that Lyn and I used to have to discuss what was coming in the course of the day became a little longer than usual—and occasionally, I might say, a little more heated than they might ever have been—when discussing whether matters could be introduced into this place or whether the sub judice principle applied.

The funny thing was—I know it really irks Lyn to hear me say this—that I actually agreed with the Clerk of the Senate on his interpretation of sub judice. Lyn and I had many discussions, both during that time and subsequently, about my interpretation of the sub judice principle at the time.

With all that background, I would have thought that at least a chapter would have been in this document about wise counsel and interpretation. Suffice to say that it does get a passing reference. Probably for all of us it is just as well that it is a passing reference, but those who were involved very intimately at the time will well remember it.

I also would like to say to Lyn that, whilst much has been said about Lyn the Clerk, there is also Lyn the person. In that very close relationship that we enjoy, I have come to know him and Beryl for the people that they are. His one great failing in that respect is that he is a Raiders supporter. In my time here I have never been able to convert him to supporting the Illawarra Steelers or an alternate team. He has been fiercely loyal to the Raiders—I might say among a dwindling band of Raiders supporters in this town, but Lyn is still there. I certainly commend him for his loyalty in that respect.

He is also a shopper of renown. He is one of the world's great shoppers, isn't he, Beryl? When I have had the opportunity to travel with him as an adviser—the member for Groom (Mr Taylor) also knows this oh so well—he was a shopper of renown, but he was also a generous person. On those occasions when I said, `Lyn, why this shop, that shop and something else?' it was always because his staff back here were being remembered. That also says something about the man.

We have heard much today already, and I am sure that we will hear more, about the respect that Lyn Barlin has from us, the present parliamentarians. If those who have gone before had the opportunity to speak, they would say much the same thing. But Lyn also enjoys the unswerving devotion and support of the staff in this place. You do not get to be in the position of boss and still retain that sort of devotion and support without being a very special individual. Lyn Barlin is that.

Lyn, I wish you all the best in retirement. I know that you, Beryl, and Lyn are just about to get on a plane this afternoon, representing the parliament of Australia, to pass on some of Lyn's 43 years of experience to a parliament in Africa. You are then coming back to tidy up some loose ends before you finally get him at home. As Lyn has remarked in your presence, Beryl, you are not quite sure what having him at home will mean for you. We have tried today to give him a couple of little things that might get him out of the house for at least a short time via fishing and whatever else. Lyn, enjoy your retirement. We will miss you. We will miss your counsel and your friendship. We will miss that quiet presence and that quiet strength that you possess. We wish you all the very best in your retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ANDERSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the opportunity to join in the parade of people who are paying tribute to you, Lyn, and the work that you have achieved, the presence that you have achieved and the role you have played in this institution for so long. I made reference this morning to you being the sort of person who really is something of a sheet anchor in a time of immense change in a fleeting and changing world. I believe that to be the case. I particularly believe it to be the case, however, in this place, where the pressures and the pace of change in that changing and fleeting world are perhaps even greater than they are outside it.

SPEECH.PARA: You have been a truly remarkable figure in Australian parliamentary history. In a parliament where issues can change at a moment's notice, extraordinary pressures can erupt without warning and members are required to make crucial decisions affecting the long-term future of the nation, Lyn Barlin has been for nearly 30 years a veritable foundation stone of strength and stability.

Australians to varying degrees but, I hope, always to a significant degree cherish their democratic system of government. We enjoy a remarkable stability and unity of purpose as a nation, for all our current uncertainties. We cannot underestimate the importance in that of a consistent, predictable system of government. Lyn has contributed more than perhaps we may ever know to the smooth operation of the House of Representatives consistent with the myriad of legal obligations arising under the Westminster system.

Many of us have had input in this parliament by offering our views and opinions and then assisting others to reach a collective viewpoint. The Clerk's role is quite different, requiring a most thorough understanding of procedures, standing orders and parliamentary history to facilitate immediate decisions on the floor of the House. I have often sat in various seats in this chamber and wondered, Lyn, how on earth you do it. I have wondered how on earth you know so much, retain it all and then convey information, advice and knowledge with such quiet dignity, so reliably and in such a non-inflammatory way every time.

Members of parliament, by contrast, usually have the luxury of being able to reflect on the content of debate, whereas you and your colleagues have to make decisions very quickly. It puts enormous pressure on you to be right first time every time. You have now operated under that pressure for three decades. We salute you for it.

Others have run through the details of your career. I will not repeat them. I make the observation that you are a familiar face to literally millions of Australians through the daily telecasts of the House of Representatives proceedings. It often surprises me, you being a man of the soil, as I said this morning, just how many people out there in the bush, when they have a wet day or whatever, do watch what happens in this place and are able to comment on it. Sometimes what they have to say is not altogether flattering, but in your case, Lyn, it is quite different. There is a warmth and affection there amongst those who know you and even those who do not which is testimony to the role that you have played.

It is fitting that today we recognise not only the contribution you have made to this House and to each one of us as members and your contribution to the operation of this, the federal parliament, but also your contribution to the best interests of all Australians. I repeat, as I said this morning, that somebody said you will find the place hard to forget and that you might miss it. But we will forget you even less and miss you more than perhaps you will miss us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLeay, Leo, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with others, particularly the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) and the Manager of Opposition Business (Mr Crean), in saying a few words to Lyn, as both the member for Watson and the Deputy Manager of Opposition Business and as a former Speaker. Frank Green might have been the person who found Lyn Barlin, but I was the person who appointed him as the Clerk of the House of Representatives. Some years ago Andrew Peacock was petitioning for him to become the Clerk when Speaker Jenkins appointed Mr Browning as the Clerk. I would have agreed with Andrew Peacock.

SPEECH.PARA: I think people will remember Lyn as a modest, decent, honourable man. There are not many people like that that you come across in your life, and I have valued knowing him. As the minister for agriculture said, there are many Australians who watch television and reckon that that bald bloke obviously knows the best thing about this place and he makes the best contributions in the House. So when he retires, if he wants to take up a talk show, at least he will be better known than most of us are to the public who watch this on television.

BREAK.PARA: I found Lyn and Beryl to be people whose company is enjoyable. When I was the Speaker, I had great difficulty encouraging Lyn to travel. With most of my colleagues, there was not much difficulty encouraging them to travel whatsoever and encouraging other people who work for the parliament to travel, because they would queue up to do it. But you could never get Lyn to go on a trip. We finally talked him into going to Africa first, to Namibia. Lyn and Beryl, and Janice and I are probably four of the few people in this parliament who have ever been to Swakopmund. We can always say that we went to the hard places—not Paris, London and Rome but Swakopmund and Tokyo. But you seem to have got the bug after that because you have travelled a lot since then. So, obviously, after being to Swakopmund once, one decides that one must see all the other places that are on the circuit.

As others have said, the advice that Lyn has given has always been good. The Leader of the House (Mr Reith) and the Leader of the Opposition have said that he is the person who will always come up with the answer you want. I must say that, when I was the Speaker, he used to come in here and say to me, `I have given that Mr Beazley some advice but I hope he doesn't take it.' Beazley would come in and wreak some terrible disaster on the parliamentary system, and all the government members would say, `We have knocked the opposition over now.' Lyn would say to me afterwards, `Do you think that was the best thing that we did there today?' I would properly nod with him and say, `No, no, it wasn't.' But the truth was they made him think it up.

Lyn has had a long history here. He has won the affection of most people. If Alan Cadman and I are supposed to be the people in the House as the whips who are supposed to know your secrets, we would really like to be able to unlock Lyn's brain and find out what is in it. There is one thing I would like to unlock even more than Lyn's brain, that is, there is a secret that Lyn keeps in this place that I do not know what he is going to do with when he retires. There is some secret evidence from the Privileges Committee in the Browne‐Fitzpatrick case which related to the father of a constituent of mine, Charlie Morgan. Charlie Morgan was the member who made some allegations, and his son has been very keen to get access to this secret evidence that was given to the Privileges Committee.

Lyn is probably the only person left alive now who has actually read that evidence. I think we all want to know: what are you going to do with it? Maybe the House ought to pass a special resolution to give you the safe and the key, and make you take it with you so that no-one can find out after you go. Lyn is not only the upholder of the ideals of the place but also the holder of a very interesting little piece of secret information that is part of the highways and byways of this place.

I would just like to say on behalf of myself and particularly on behalf of my wife that we would wish that you and Beryl have a very happy retirement, Lyn. I know that you will find things to do that will fill in your day quicker than you ever thought they would. I hope that you do not go watching question time and start to score us while you are in retirement, because one of our former leaders used to do that. He used to watch question time and he would send notes to the particular people. He used to send more to Barry and Colin Hollis than most, but Gough used to watch question time and he would write you a note saying, `I saw that contribution today. I would have done it this way' or `I would have done it that way.' Maybe you might take up a job as the Canberra Times's critic of question time and you could score us all in the Canberra Times. It would certainly do something to raise the circulation of the Canberra Times.

Could I again wish you a happy retirement, you and Beryl. I am sure that we have all profited from knowing you. The parliament has profited from having you as the Clerk of the House of Representatives. I think that not only will you go down among the great clerks—you are one of the great clerks. I hope you have a happy retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop, Bronwyn, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mrs BISHOP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Defence Industry, Science and Personnel)

TALK.START.PARA: —In rising to speak and perhaps give some accolades to the retiring Clerk of the House of Representatives, I think the way in which I first met Mr Barlin is different from the way that anybody else in this chamber first met him, because it was when I was a senator and he came to give evidence before a Public Accounts Committee hearing. It was an occasion when I remember that there were differences between the way in which the Senate is run and the House of Representatives is run.

SPEECH.PARA: It became far more apparent to me when I entered this chamber that the rules were different but that the integrity of the clerks was something that remained constant. As I came to know the Clerk more and more and be advised by him, which I quite frequently needed in the beginning, the one thing I realised in coming into this chamber here was that all members of the House of Representatives had a rather, shall we say, different view of the worth of senators. When they came down from one chamber to the next, it was necessary to learn the ways in which this House was conducted and not try to say that one was knowledgeable in the ways of procedure and try to make comparisons. So it was to the clerks that I frequently went for advice. I can only say that I was always treated in the most courteous manner—not `shouldn't you have learned that by now?' but really in a way that helped me to adapt to a chamber which I dearly enjoy serving in.

When I spoke earlier at morning tea with Mrs Barlin, she was talking about how this had been your life, how much of yourself you have given to this job and how it will be when you retire. I think we exchanged the view that said: she married you for better or for worse, but not for lunch. In other words, the ability that you have is going to be something that I know is not going to be wasted.

There is so much that you have in terms of knowledge and integrity that can be given to the wider community in Canberra, where they will be the better for the advice and the engagement that you can give them. I know that when you leave us your life will change and you will be looking for new challenges. Because of your knowledge and integrity, you have the ability to serve people as individuals simply because they are seeking your help and not in any partisan way; that is a very special quality.

You have enhanced the way that I think about members of the Public Service because you have the ability to act with those good old‐fashioned principles that say that you simply serve the government of the day, that you serve those who come to you for advice in a fair and even‐handed manner, and that you give of your best advice at all times to whomever asks it of you in a totally non‐partisan way. That is a very special ingredient in a system such as ours, which is full of the adversarial ethic. There is a need for that solid base of knowledge which can be shared in that way.

I am particularly grateful that I was able to know you in this chamber and have the benefit of your advice as I know so many others are as well. I do wish to you and Mrs Barlin every success in your coming retirement, knowing that it will be fulfilling and that every now and again you can have a lunch together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair, Ian, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am indebted to the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Jones) for allowing me to speak as I have leave to attend a seminar in Melbourne which unfortunately is arranged around my availability, so I have to leave shortly.

SPEECH.PARA: The clerk of this place is somebody with whom I have been associated in many ways for a good part of the 43 years that he has served here. I wanted to speak, but briefly, on two aspects of his career. The first is the office itself. I know many have spoken of his role and the current parliamentary practice. When I first arrived it was Erskine May that was the fount of all wisdom. While the clerks were there at the table to provide solace, it was to Erskine May and the current standing orders to which we were referred if we wanted to know the practices and the procedures and, ultimately, how we should behave. Lyn was part of the generation that saw that that was inadequate and that it was necessary for us to have our own.

Initially, Pettifer laid down parliamentary practice and was successively repeated in three editions. While it is true that Jack Pettifer, the then clerk, was one of the prime authors and the instigator—and ultimately it was his name that the publication bore—Lyn and his colleagues, the assistant clerks, all played an important part in its preparation. In terms of the office, what Lyn has advised each of us in the daily process of this place is very significantly replicated not only in this third edition of House of Representatives practice but indeed in each of the former two.

Of the second aspect, the manner of the execution of his duty, much has been said both in the way it has been administered and of the occasions when it has been really so much on the clerk; the tone, the manner and the decorum and indeed the standards have followed. It is not an easy role and much has been said of that. Having been both Leader of the House and Manager of Opposition Business over a protracted period of time and having been at the bar of the House when many of the major events of the last 35 or 37 years have occurred I can assure you that on all occasions they have been very much dependent on the advice that the clerk provides.

For those outside of the chamber the role of the clerk is a little uncertain and unknown. I suspect that it is only on this occasion that you have been the centrepiece, clerk, in the presentation of the television images of the place; normally it is on the Speaker behind you or on the speakers on either side of the chamber where the emphasis rests. There is a requirement that the forms of the parliament be preserved. If we believe in democracy, it sounds an ethos to which we can all aspire. But it means little if it is not carried out in a manner prescribed within the standing orders, which are designed to ensure that the processes are allowed to evolve and that everybody is given an adequate opportunity to express their point of view. Lyn has been outstanding in the advice he has given and in the degree to which, after the advice has been given, if you transgress he quietly admonishes you as to how it should have been conducted. I know on the several occasions in which I have been involved in the escapades of this place he has inevitably told me afterwards how I should really have conducted the affair.

BREAK.PARA: As a clerk, you will be missed, there is no doubt, but as a man even more. There has been much said of that also. Lyn is a gentleman, a delightful companion and a remarkable confidant. Together with Beryl, who I am delighted is here today, he has made a wonderful contribution not only to the parliament but also to the people of Australia. Lyn, like all others who have spoken before me I wish you and Beryl a long life, happiness and obviously excellent health. I am only sorry that the arms and the man have been separated. We learnt earlier today that Lyn did have two very excellent shotguns that regrettably, under the present laws that he saw pass through this place, are no longer his to hold. As one of those who share something of his passion for that particular sport I know something of the way he feels. Lyn, to you and Beryl the very best of wishes on behalf of Rosemary and myself. Thank you for all you have done, not only for the House but for the people of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones, Barry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We live in the age of youth and, as somebody increasingly conscious of the passage of time, it comes as a relief to find that there are people around who are older than me. The right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) provides a great sense of reassurance daily. So do my elders and betters, including the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) and the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding).

SPEECH.PARA: The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) seems much older, almost from a former geological era, but he actually is not. So it came as a surprise, and almost a relief, when looking up Who's Who in Australia to find that Lyn Barlin is actually older than me, but he glows with good health.

TALK.START.PARA: —So do you.

—Thank you for that. Obviously, there is something about being 64 that has not done us any harm. I have always learnt from the honourable member for Cunningham (Mr Martin). My knowledge of small business, for example, is largely derived from him. It came as a surprise to learn today that Lyn Barlin was one of the world's great shoppers. There is deceptive packaging in the House. The use of the Geneva gown suggests a Calvinist divine but one of unusual bonhomie and balance, not at all judgmental or seeking to send sinners into hellfire.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, Lyn has made a major intellectual contribution. The House of Representatives Practice: Third Edition is like Maimonides' The guide for the Perplexed. It is indispensable bedside reading. It is an infallible cure for insomnia. When you pick it up, stroke its pages and read some of the soothing sentences in it, you feel that essentially everything is all right, you can be reassured and you can sleep with very great confidence.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is heavy on your chest.

—True. For those who have frail wrists, perhaps a smaller paperback version could be prepared. Lyn Barlin was clerk assistant in 1977, when I was first elected. For much of 1978, he was serving in the House of Commons, so I only came to know him either later in that year or early in 1979. I think he has been one of the very great figures I have known, either sitting at that table or within Parliament House itself. His contribution has been remarkable.

SPEECH.PARA: The role of the Clerk, to which he was appointed in 1991, is vital. It has a sort of quasi‐judicial status, although he speaks oracularly through the voice of the Speaker. The role is vital, but mysterious and often largely unrecognised. It is certainly not understood in the general community. Even people with political knowledge do not know until they come here how central the role of the Clerk is.

There was some good humoured speculation earlier about what a great parliamentarian Lyn would have made and what political party he might have stood for. I must say that I think of him more as an Independent by nature—not, I would have thought, a candidate for the Shooters Party or indeed some recent forms of Independents that we have become used to.

He is a man of extraordinary independence, judgment and depth. I regard it as a privilege to have known him. He has been extraordinarily generous with advice, a great confidante and a repository of many great secrets, not least perhaps in his role as the Registrar of Members' Interests—something of very great sensitivity.

His award as a member of the Order of Australia was very much deserved and applauded by the members who he had served so well and for so long. I know I speak for so many of my colleagues when I say that we all wish Lyn and his wife, Beryl, a very long and happy life together and that, in retirement, they will not think too unkindly of us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ruddock, Philip, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr RUDDOCK
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make some brief comments to associate myself with this commendation of Lyn Barlin on his retirement. I do not gloat about my own period of service, but I suspect I am probably the most senior Liberal now. In that context, I have served in many roles. Those that have not been adverted to by others who have spoken include the short period I served on the committee that deals with members' interests and the executive of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association.

SPEECH.PARA: When you are in the committees, you find that the work you are undertaking is in a much less adversarial role. It is one in which you have a wider obligation to the parliament and its wide variety of interests. The advice you receive is one that you are not taking into battle as you gird up the loins.

In relation to the Committee of Members' Interests, for most of the time I was associated with the committee, Lyn was the registrar, even before he became the Clerk. In that context, he was advising the committee. We were dealing with difficult issues that did go to members' personal affairs and personal interests, where disclosure has some sensitivity and where at times one needs to look with some care at what factors ought to be brought forward and what the implications of those might be. His advice and counsel were very sage and important to us. The way in which we could approach him with a good deal of confidence on matters that did involve one's personal affairs is a measure of the man, and it is what we expect of all those who are involved in this role.

BREAK.PARA: In relation to the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association, equally I have had the opportunity of seeing Lyn along with many of his colleagues serving in an advisory capacity—particularly to you, Mr Speaker, and your predecessors, as you play an important role in that organisation. There are a wealth of activities outside those which members of the public see associated with the chamber in which the clerks are involved and in which their experience helps us enormously.

I, like my colleagues, have had an opportunity to get to know Lyn and I have valued his friendship, counsel and advice. I want to take the opportunity to just say thank you for that support you have given me in the way in which I have had to carry out my role. Thank you very much.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity to participate in expressing our appreciation of the contribution that Lyn Barlin, Clerk of the House of Representatives, has made to this nation, Australia. As a Whitlam child, I have worked with or near him for all of my parliamentary life and for most of his parliamentary life. There have been differing roles. I saw Norman Parkes as clerk, Jack Pettifer, Doug Blake, Alan Browning and then Lyn Barlin.

SPEECH.PARA: When I first came here to the old house, I watched the clerk sitting there and I could not understand—and I am sure a number of new members in this parliament have experienced the same thing that I felt at that time—how they could sit there amongst all of that furore, and it was almost a riot in the old house during 1975, and be so unflappable. Whenever I see Sir Humphrey in that program Yes, Minister, I think of the unflappability of the clerks. It was almost like a studied indifference. I suppose it is a bit like the duck in the duck pond: serene on the surface and paddling like hell underneath. I have come to learn of all the work that is done behind the scenes when they are out of the chamber.

But I want to say from Australia's viewpoint, as the Treasurer (Mr Costello) said earlier this afternoon, that Lyn and his support staff are the watchdogs of legislative and parliamentary procedures, but he is the one who carries the responsibility to see that the proper procedures have been followed and that the right amendments and votes have been taken at the right time. Sometimes, when I was a minister, we had a desperate rush to recast something that somebody had forgotten, or something that had been overlooked in all the rush of stuff going backwards and forwards from the Senate—to dot one `i' or to cross one `t', to put it in those kinds of terms. But he is the watchdog of parliamentary and legislative procedures.

I say on behalf of all of us that he, in his own discreet, ever so gentle, ever so unobtrusive way, has moulded and shaped us. I remember being elected as a Labor alderman to the Newcastle City Council and the Newcastle branch of the Liberal Party wanted me to address them on what it was like to be an alderman of the Newcastle City Council. I said, `I would like to do that.' I was good friends with the fellow, the president. I thought I would like to do that, but then I thought, `Hang, on, there is a bit of a problem with this.'

TALK.START.PARA: —All very broad minded.

—Of course, it is a broad church. I said, `Can you wait a little bit until I get to know a bit more about it?' This was only a few weeks after I had been elected and he said, `No, we'd like you to come and tell us what it's like before you are moulded.' There are Lyn and his predecessors in that same way ever so gently, ever so carefully—a little nudge here, a little push there—saying, `You could've done this,' or `You could've done it that way,' `It may have been better had it been pursued in this way, Minister.'

SPEECH.PARA: So we do not realise at the time the contribution he is making and the effect he is having on our lives, our performances and our contributions as members of this parliament. All of us to you, Lyn, say that we are so thankful, we are so grateful. You are very clever. You are very clever how you do it, but it has to be done and we need to have you there because of the excitement and turmoil that erupts from time to time.

Lyn sees us arrive—some of us are mature, some of us acquire maturity, some of us acquire increasing immaturity and some of us mellow. All of those mixtures are here in this chamber. He sees all of that. He notes each of us. He keeps a mental note of who is doing what, who has changed and who has not. He has provided advice and guidance to each of us. Sometimes he provided advice to me as shadow minister when there was an urgent need to respond to a bill and we had to draft an amendment to go into the bill. How the hell was I going to do that? Where was Lyn? He was unflappable. Nothing seemed to disturb him. No matter how rushed I was or how demanding I was, he was as cool as a cucumber.

At other times as a backbencher, sometimes there were questions on amendments, on questions on notice, on notices of motion, but, Mr Speaker, there remains one question, which you reminded me of today, that goes unanswered in this place, and the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) will remember this one—that is, question No. 3321. I shall say no more but, at a later time this day, I expect the Clerk of the House of Representatives will provide me with a copy of No. 3321, as we reminisce on whatever happened to it. It was engulfed in the prorogation of the parliament.

Going on from there, Lyn brings one great quality to this chamber and to his task as the clerk—that is, dignity. He brings a dignity, a sense of responsibility and a calmness to all of our proceedings and to the parliament of Australia. When you look back, there are some things that he will not tell you, but I will tell you.

Look at this cathedral like chamber, particularly from my stature. Look at this place. It is like a cathedral. Were it but a much smaller chamber, Mr Clerk, we would have more of that intimacy we used to have in the old parliament building. There was a greater camaraderie and a greater mixing of members, and they are some of the qualities that we have lost in this building. We have lost that. In 100 years time, when there are 400 members in the House of Representatives of Australia, this would be about the right size, but currently in this cathedral like building we have lost much of the atmosphere, the relationship and the intimacies.

BREAK.PARA: Were Lyn Barlin able to rethink, recontribute and not be run over by the Senate, when we have not supported him at times when he should have been supported, we might have had a chamber that was more intimate. Maybe I can say it now that we could bring those walls in a little. Maybe we could put some baffles up there, something that brings a closer intimacy.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have the Speaker's gallery on the floor.
—Yes, the Speaker's gallery on the floor. Look at all that space wasted there. Those people up there would love to be sitting down here.
—Closer to us.

—They could be closer to us and close to the proceedings. On agitated occasions, they could even participate. So all of those things have been various contributions, things that we look back on with the wisdom of the past.

BREAK.PARA: Lyn, I want to say to you from the people I represent how deeply we appreciate the support and the guidance you have given to me in my role as their representative and the contribution you have made to the parliament of Australia. This is the supreme parliament of this nation. There is no greater parliament than this parliament and this assembly, regardless of what happens in that other place over there.

I want to say to Beryl, who is sitting in the Speaker's gallery, thank you for your sacrifices; thank you for the time we have kept him away from you; thank you for the lack of patience and understanding you sometimes had because we gave him too rough a time here. To each of you, thank you very much for the wonderful contribution you have made to our nation and to our parliament. My family and I wish you a very happy, healthy and long retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nehl, Garry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In the public area on the first floor of this building, there is a copy of the most important document ever written in terms of democracy, freedom and liberty. It is a copy of the Magna Carta. It was written on vellum at the instruction of King Edward I in—my friend the member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) will correct me if I am wrong—1276. We have seen an unbroken 700‐odd years of growth and development of democracy.
—Six hundred actually—no, 700, you are right.

—I will put that in the record book. We have seen an unbroken development of democracy for 700‐odd years of which I believe this parliament is the epitome. I see the clerks of this chamber as the embodiment of everything that is involved in that democracy. The Clerk, Lyn Barlin, is at this minute the keeper of everything that has come over that 700‐odd years. I would like to say thank you very much. I could speak at enormous length, but I will not. I know you have to leave at 5 o'clock. But I can endorse everything that has been said by every other speaker.

SPEECH.PARA: There are only two points I want to make before I sit down. The House of Representatives Practice has been referred to as the bible. I want to tell you—I do not think you know this—that, without any sense of irreverence to the Almighty, in my office you are known as God. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) said that the more senior you become, the shorter your title becomes. `Clerk' is pretty short, but `God' is shorter. It is with enormous affection that we say thank you very much indeed.

The only other point I want to make is that I was very sad when you disowned the wig. I thought you looked quite magnificent sitting there with that gown, even though it may have been referred to as calvinistic. I thought the wig added something, and I was sorry to see it go. As a member of the Speaker's Panel in the previous two parliaments, and now the Deputy Speaker, I have enormous knowledge of your wisdom, and I have benefited from it incredibly. I thank you, Lyn Barlin.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I simply want to associate myself very briefly with the comments that have been made in this chamber today and in other parts of the building about Lyn Barlin and Beryl and to express to both of them my very warmest regard and affection, which they both know I hold for them. I started to list some of the particular characteristics of Lyn Barlin, and I had to stop because I was writing down all of those great human qualities that would occur to us. I heard other people who have spoken use the same expressions. I had `dedicated', `professional', `courteous', `helpful', `tolerant', `diplomatic', `dignified' and `calm'. As I have said, I could have continued to write more.

SPEECH.PARA: Some people have referred to Lyn's role as the Clerk of this magnificent institution in its historic context, and have done so admirably. Lyn, I simply want to make a personal statement about how I have found you as the most important officer of the parliament. I think it was my colleague the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris) who referred to this as being the supreme parliamentary institution of the nation. I would add that this chamber is the supreme chamber of this parliament and that you, Sir, have been the supreme officer of this chamber. You have made an enormously significant contribution.

I was genuinely surprised to hear your genuine expression today that you were overwhelmed by the way in which the members of the parliament have responded to your impending retirement. That should not have been so, Lyn. All of those responses—so spontaneous—were also very genuine.

I am one of the senior members of the parliament and am going to end my term in this parliament at the end of the term in which you resign. Some people might say, `Brownie, are you going because the Clerk is disappearing as well?' That could well be so. But I am sure there will be other people who will continue the great traditions to which you have made your own very effective contribution.

What you have done for the structures of this parliament, for the procedures of this parliament and for its traditions and, I would add, its efficiency and its effectiveness have also been referred to. We are all so very grateful to Hansard, who make us such good spellers, such good grammarians, and who convince the world that we are just so articulate. Lyn, your contribution to this parliament has made it possible for us to perhaps sometimes live down the perceptions that the community has about us because you have contributed to the efficiency and the effectiveness of this place.

I would say that all of my colleagues on both sides of the chamber would like those people closest to us, when we all retire, to say that he or she has been a good and honourable person. Lyn, your spouse, Beryl, and your family will always be able to take great pride in the knowledge that you are a good and honourable man who gave his best shot and did it so admirably. You and Beryl take with you into your retirement my very best personal wishes and my very warm affection.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Lyn, I have known you since I arrived in this place. I want to thank you for your promotion and guardianship of democracy as it works in Australia, because you are a steadying hand on the attitudes that can develop in the chamber. You have been through some hard times in the House and some very difficult times for our type of democracy. You have an attitude of goodwill but firmness, you have an attitude that accepts quality performance, and you encourage a quality performance from those around you.

SPEECH.PARA: I guess there is only one regret that I have with your leaving us—that is, that you were unable to see through the restoration of equitable balance between the Senate and the House of Representatives. I think it is completely inappropriate that the Senate receives 56 per cent of the resources with half the number of members in that place. I think the restoration of a proper balance and care for the members of the House of Representatives—I know this is close to the Speaker's heart and close to your heart too—is the one thing that we have missed out on. I would have enjoyed joining you in that battle to see a restoration.

I also look forward to the collapsing of the five parliamentary departments into a single department, or at the most two, because to me it is crazy to have five permanent heads running this place. There is no wonder that at times we have confusion. I know that was a goal of yours. I am sorry to see that you have not been able to fulfil that goal. A few of us will carry that banner on. Thank you for your service to this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Filing, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make a few comments. Firstly, Lyn is also known for some other form of shooting. Some may not know that he is a bit of an expert in video photography. In recent times he has engaged in some big game shooting with his video camera. If you want any advice on the best sort of video camera to purchase, Lyn Barlin is the person to speak to. Apparently, he has researched digital and analogue video photography to the nth degree and is almost a font of knowledge on it. I certainly hope that in your retirement years, Lyn, you get a chance to shoot a bit more big game with your video cameras now that you have lost your shotguns, which is obviously a shame.

SPEECH.PARA: As an Independent member, I wish to say how important the Clerk of the House of Representatives is to the functioning of one's duties as a member. Obviously without the benefit of having a fairly large party organisation within the House of Representatives to assist you, you rely more and more heavily on the clerk's advice, in particular in relation to the procedures of the House, and also to the question of being fully informed as to the progress of particular bills at any particular time. Naturally, if one is tied up in a committee—

TALK.START.PARA: —But you could ring me and I would tell you.

—If you were tied up in a committee, coming to a division in the chamber requires a fairly instant decision in relation to a bill that may be being debated at the particular time. The honourable member for Watson would be the last person I would ask.

SPEECH.PARA: The question which arose at the beginning of this particular parliament was in relation to the record number of Independent members in the House of Representatives. I think it is the largest number since about 1912. There was a need to resolve the problem of how one came to settle the way in which the speaking opportunities were arrived at, and questions and the like. Knowing that Lyn Barlin felt that he did not have a role to play in the question of the actual resolution of those particular issues, his advice was nonetheless very useful and helpful. At a stage when we had a large number of Independents, a number of whom were new to the place and who obviously were unfamiliar with the procedures, that advice was very helpful indeed.

I also reflect on one other issue that the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl) and a number of other members were touching on—that is, the question of the role of the Clerk in relation to the development of the parliamentary democracy or our institution of parliamentary government. One of the great dilemmas or conflicts in this place over, I suppose, all of its life has been the conflict between the executive and the parliament. We have seen more and more in recent years the way in which the executive, under either side of politics, unfortunately, has come to view parliament as being a bit of an inconvenience in its program of legislating.

There has been a tendency on both sides, although it is not quite as bad under this particular government as under the previous one, for the executive government to try to trammel over the rights of individual members in its pursuit of what it considers to be the interests of governance in the nation's interest. I am sure—and I am more and more convinced now after seven years in this place—that had it not been for the fact that Lyn Barlin was the Clerk of the House of Representatives, that process would have accelerated. I mean that in the sense that I am sure that the unbiased, independent, calm and wise advice provided by Lyn Barlin to both sides of politics has ensured that, in fact, both sides have been better informed to be able to prevent the greater trammelling of the rights of individual members by the executive.
