In congratulating Lyn Barlin on his period as Clerk of the House of Representatives, on his career and his contribution to the parliament, I am sure he will be known as one of the great defenders of our system of parliamentary democracy. I would like to wish him and Beryl a long and happy retirement together, and wish them well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Andrew, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that time is of the essence. I will, therefore, try to avoid repeating anything that has been said. In fact, it could be said that there is nothing that any of us can say now that will be new or original. But I would say, Mr Barlin, that I would find it regrettable if, simply because of the constraints of time, I was unable to rise and indicate to you how much I have been grateful for your wise counsel, grateful for your friendship and grateful for your impartiality.

SPEECH.PARA: They are sentiments that everyone in this chamber will share with me. Not all of them, however, will know the same degree of gratitude that I know as a member of the Speaker's Panel and all other members of the Speaker's Panel know—gratitude that the clerks are there and that you are leading them and that, when we are occupying that lonely chair, the advice is never far away and that advice is always absolutely correct.

You have been painted, Sir, as someone who is quite implacable in your occupancy of the Clerk's chair, and that, I guess, has been a fair illustration. It should be added, however, that it would be unfair to paint you as a retiring Clerk who has been humourless. While those of us who are in the Speaker's chair often want in one way or another out of party loyalty to participate in the debate and are unable to do so, we would not know whether or not the clerks wanted to participate because there has been no indication from any of them that they felt any particular passion at all about the debate.

To leave, however, the impression that the Clerk has been quite without emotion would be wrong, because there have been occasions when a very clever, comical exchange across the chamber has produced a wry smile from the Clerk's face, just as it has from everyone else's. I note with interest that I have never seen the clerks smile, participate, be at all amused or in fact be prepared to be engaged in any of the sorts of exchanges that involve the scorn and derision that we all wish were not part of the chamber of the House of Representatives. So I pay tribute to the way in which you have done all you could to raise the standards of this place. I trust that we have not disappointed you too much when, in the heat of the moment, some of us have failed to meet the same standards as you would have wanted us to emulate.

BREAK.PARA: Can I simply thank you very much for your personal friendship, for the affinity that I have always felt for a capacity to have a conversation with you and for the way in which you have made us all feel very much welcome in your office. I add to that the degree to which there has always been, in spite of that welcome, a deferential approach, which we have not felt necessary but you clearly have and which has made the Clerk's role that much more meaningful. I wish you and your wife all the best in your retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins, Harry, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In making my contribution to this debate, I would like to in particular make a contribution based on my association with Lyn Barlin, firstly, during the 36th Parliament as a member of the panel of temporary chairmen of committees, now known as the Speaker's Panel; during the 37th Parliament as the last Deputy Speaker and Chairman of Committees and then Deputy Speaker; and of course during this parliament as the second Second Deputy Speaker.

SPEECH.PARA: Much has been said by those who have stood up as frontbenchers about the facial expressions of Lyn Barlin and the assistance that they may have given as an inkling to what was going on. The view of those who occupy the chair is of course on the basis of the back of his head, but can I say that you can read the back of his head—sometimes the gentle wiggling of an ear was enough to know that something was about to happen. Unlike the Deputy Speaker, I am quite relieved that the wigged are now unwigged because it assists us in being able to sense those signals.

In talking about Lyn's decision to no longer wear the wig, can I say that it goes with a number of the other innovations in the wider sense of the parliament. He was acutely aware of his responsibility as Clerk to make the workings of the House of Representatives equate to the developments that were being made in contemporary Australian society. I think that is important. We have to understand that we operate in a society that develops and is changing, that we are continually challenged to make what we do here relevant to the people who observe us. We have had to do a lot of things. Perhaps Lyn, like a number of us, would believe that the televising of parliament has so changed the nature of the way debates are conducted—and not necessarily in a positive manner.

The Treasurer (Mr Costello) made mention of Senate Clerk Odgers's statement that he thought that he could go into retirement with people thinking that he was impartial on the basis that everybody had accused him from time to time of being biased in all political directions. I think that Lyn can go into retirement knowing that people think that he is impartial on the basis that nobody has accused him—no‐one that I can remember—of being on anybody's side in that sense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—I think that is a tribute to the way in which he has carried out his duties. Much of what needed to be said in this debate has already been said. I value the advice that I have received from Lyn Barlin and his friendship. In an intergenerational sense, I would like to place on record in this debate the views of my predecessor, who I hope that Lyn realises held him in very high regard.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish Lyn, Beryl and the rest of the Barlin family a very enjoyable retirement. May you get the type of enjoyment that you deserve.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vaile, Mark, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —My remarks will be very brief. My association with Lyn Barlin has been a very warm one since my entry into this parliament four years ago but, more importantly, I am the third member for Lyne who has served in this place under the tutelage, guidance, assistance and advice of Lyn Barlin. That is important because Lyn Barlin originated from the electorate of Lyne, and the electorate of Lyne, in its many different manifestations over the years, has been centred around Taree—Taree being originally Lyn Barlin's home town. So I would expect that from time to time I would enjoy some support from the Barlin family, and one of my predecessors used to maintain that the Barlin family gave him his majority in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: When I entered the parliament, I was welcomed by Lyn Barlin. It was interesting to note at the time that there had continued to be over a number of years a number of products of Taree High School in this place. There was the former member for Hughes, whom we do recall, in the last parliament and for many years; me, a product of Taree High School; my predecessor, Mr Bruce Cowan, a product of Taree High School; and the Clerk of the House of Representatives, a product of Taree High School. We all have a great deal of pride about that because we often read about a lot of the more high profile private schools and the products they have produced who have become members of this place. We take a great deal of pride that three people who work in this place—that is, until this evening—are the products of Taree High School: the Clerk of the House of Representatives, Mr Lyn Barlin; me as the member for Lyne; and the now member for Griffith (Mr McDougall), who was also educated at Taree High School.

I would like to extend my best wishes to Lyn and his wife, Beryl, in their retirement, and congratulate Lyn on the service that he has provided to this parliament and to Australia. I am sure that in the future we will see Lyn back in the electorate of Lyne from time to time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Stephen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to associate myself with the remarks that honourable members have made to mark the retirement of the Clerk of the House of Representatives. We all come to this place with our different life experiences. Part of my life experience before here was to be the principal private secretary to the former Attorney‐General of Western Australia, Joe Berinson, who is a former member for Perth, a former Deputy Speaker of this House and a person whom I know the Clerk has a warm and high view of. One of the things I had to do in that capacity was to deal with parliamentary counsel and issue instructions for the drafting of legislation. If you find a quality parliamentary counsel, you find a person who is clear thinking, has sharp intellect, is committed to high professional standards and, at a personal level, is a fundamentally decent person full of integrity, dignity, confidence and calmness. They are also committed to the sanctity of their process, which is the law. They are committed to the sanctity of the process not only because they are professional but also because they understand the importance of their ultimate product to society.

SPEECH.PARA: Clerks and people who work in the Clerk's office are obviously chips off that same block. They are absolutely committed to the sanctity of the process, which is the parliamentary process. They are committed to that not just because it is a process but also because they understand the importance of parliament as an institution and the importance of this institution to the fabric of our democracy and to the fabric of our society.

My experience with Lyn Barlin has been somewhat different from the experiences of many members who have spoken previously. I think most of the members who have spoken previously have been in this House for a number of years. I have been here since 1993, a relatively short period, in two capacities: from 1993 to 1996 as a government backbencher and since 1996 as a member of the opposition's frontbench. My contact with Lyn as a government backbencher, as has no doubt been the experience of government backbenchers today, has been somewhat limited—the odd piece of advice, which was always clear, always precise and always well worth following.

My contact since our change of status has been somewhat much more extensive, somewhat much more fruitful and, from a personal point of view, somewhat much more rewarding. That has been in two capacities. Firstly, that contact has been as a member of the opposition frontbench, where part of my brief is to cause as much grief as I possibly can to the government without, as the Clerk would have it, causing any grief to the House or the institution.

Secondly, I found time to have more time to devote to private members business. Whether that has been with the euthanasia legislation or in my endeavours to get the House to adopt a select committee with respect to HMAS Sydney, I have often found myself wandering to the Clerk's office seeking the Clerk's fearless advice.

It is the quality and the importance of that advice which marks a qualitative difference that I now regard myself as going through. We all come to this place as politicians; not all of us leave as parliamentarians. There is a qualitative difference. I would be the last to argue that it requires you to serve some time on this side of the House to make that difference. But to make that difference, you have to spend some time with the Clerk and the Clerk's office. Only by spending time with the Clerk will you have an opportunity of understanding how the parliament historically and now works. That is an important thing to leave with from your time in this chamber.

This is in very many respects a sad day, but it is also a significant day. It is significant because in very many respects all the contributions that have been made by honourable members either here or outside have reflected very much the things that we all have in common rather than the things that divide us or over which we disagree. What things do we have in common in our view of Lyn Barlin? Fundamentally, he has our respect and regard as a decent human being. But he also has our respect, our regard and our thanks for the contribution that he has made to the fabric of parliament as an institution and to the importance of the parliament to our society.

I will very quickly give a couple of anecdotes, which all members have. Whether I was traipsing through the Clerk's office trying to stop the Leader of the House (Mr Reith) having euthanasia debated in the Main Committee or to find some inventive way of getting the government to discuss sugar, I was in his chambers. I would often say to him, `Lyn, all I need is an arguable case,' to which on many occasions the Clerk would say, `I know, Stephen, but, I'm sorry, it's not arguable.'

The book has been mentioned. Very many of us, when we got the book in our rooms, went to the footnotes to see whether we were in the footnotes. In my case, I was. It required that, together with the member for Werriwa (Mr Latham), I blew up the Main Committee and ran two dissent motions simultaneously in the Main Committee and in this House. I do not think I am breaching a confidence when I say that, on one occasion, when I went to seek advice as to what I should have done next, I left the Clerk with him having said to me, `On the scale of ambushes, this was a good ambush.'

Most of us in this place end up as footnotes. It is the rare individual who gets to write the book or to help write the book. Lyn Barlin has helped write the book. That is a measure of his contribution as a fundamentally decent human being, a man of great integrity and dignity, a person whom this institution will miss and a person to whom this parliament and our nation owes a great deal of gratitude. We wish him well in his retirement. I personally thank him for the contribution that he has made in helping to turn me from being a politician into, hopefully at some point in the process, a parliamentarian.

TALK.START.PARA: —Time is getting to be a significant issue. Before calling the honourable member for Kooyong, I entreat all subsequent speakers to be as brief but as pertinent as they possibly can be.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georgiou, Petro, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to be able to associate myself with this motion. I will keep my comments brief, since I do not think it is fair, having done so much to Lyn, that we should hold him up at the last moment. I believe that we politicians are very different, but there are some rare moments of convergence and unanimity, and one of these is about Lyn Barlin.

SPEECH.PARA: The first thing that we agree on is that we hold him in the highest esteem and, secondly, we place a great deal of trust in him.
My sideways look at politics has been through working for political leaders. Politicians, particularly political leaders, tend to be a bit suspicious of things—it probably goes with the territory.

It is a mark of Lyn's quite exceptional qualities that the political leaders I have worked for, knowing full well that their opponents are doing the same, have gone to Lyn for advice—probably about the same things, probably about the same time but from different perspectives. They have got advice of the highest calibre, in the full knowledge that this advice would remain confidential. As I said, politicians are not the most trusting people in the world, and that to me is a mark of very great calibre.

I just want to make a couple of other observations. Because of Lyn's capacity, commitment and—I have thought about this a bit—what I think is best described as an apparent quality of serenity, which is particularly noticeable in the parliament's febrile and sometimes feral atmosphere, he has strengthened the institution of the parliament and the people that work in it. I believe he has embodied parliament's true spirit of the commitment to advancing Australia and that he has strengthened Australian democracy.

Those parliamentarians who follow us will have access to his wisdom through the third edition of the House of Representatives Practice—a superb contribution to Australian parliamentary democracy. But I do not believe that it will compare with talking to Lyn directly.
I have known Lyn for almost a quarter of a century, since I had long flowing hair, and I would like to thank him very sincerely for his guidance and counsel over the years.
I wish him and Beryl the very best for their retirement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis, Colin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief, Mr Speaker. I know that time is limited. As one of the members of the Speaker's Panel, I would like to endorse what other members have said about the great support that the clerks have always given to us. Sometimes we occupy that position for only a couple of hours, say two hours a week. Unlike you—you are there so much more than we are—we do not have the knowledge of all the standing orders. But we can always rely on the clerks, especially Lyn Barlin when he is there, to advise us.

SPEECH.PARA: You always hope when you are in the chair for an hour that everything will run very smoothly. Occasionally it does not. Occasionally—shock, horror—the House `blows up' and you are in the unfortunate position of being in the chair. As one of the Speaker's Panel, the greatest compliment you can receive is when Lyn Barlin says to you, ever so quietly, `You handled that very well, Mr Hollis.' That is the greatest compliment.

BREAK.PARA: I have been fortunate to have been on an overseas delegation with Lyn and Beryl. He is a wonderful travelling companion. I thank you not only for your friendship but also for the great assistance you have always given me during the time that I have been in the chair and during the time that I have been in this parliament. I wish you and Beryl well in your retirement.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Chief Opposition Whip will be pleased to know that I have just arrived from Queensland at his direction. I have been listening to the radio, hoping I would get here in time just to say to you, Lyn, `Thank you.' I have been here a few years now and I must say that when your retirement was announced I was surprised because I thought you were timeless. For all the reasons that all the members have stated, and from my own personal position, I thank you for your warmth and for welcoming me into this place from the day I arrived until this evening. I very much wanted to publicly associate myself with the comments that have been made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brough, Mal, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As one of the new members, the one comment I would like to make is that many of my more senior colleagues will have forgotten that, when you first arrive in this place, it can be rather awe‐inspiring and quite often you do not know the questions to ask. When that happens, you go to Lyn, the Clerk. You would not even ask a colleague because you might be embarrassed by the sneer or the innuendo that you did not know what you were referring to. That is not something that any of us, no matter what we have ever gone to the Clerk for, have experienced.

SPEECH.PARA: The stature that he has shown in this place leaves me enriched by the experience. I genuinely mean that. I thank you very much for your contribution and the fact that you always show the utmost respect to all of us, regardless of your inward feelings in some cases. In those instances, not only this place but everyone is enriched from the experience of having known you.

On behalf of all the new members—although it is probably beyond my call to say that—I thank you for the time that you spent with us when introducing us to this parliament. We wish you and your family all the best for the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his own inimitable way, and true to respecting the procedures of the House as he always has, Lyn has asked me to pass on the following message: my sincere thanks and that of my wife Beryl to all members for their kind remarks and the generosity extended to us both. It is very, very much appreciated.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Fisheries Legislation Amendment Bill implements the government's election promise to provide secure long‐term access rights for fishing operators under federal jurisdiction. I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As honourable members would be aware, Newcastle is a major port and has off its shores major fishing grounds. It has a very strong fishing fleet. I join with colleagues from both sides of the House to recognise and support this legislation. I also point out that the fishermen of Newcastle are all small businessmen. There are no big fishing organisations in Newcastle; they are all small business people—and they all need protection.

SPEECH.PARA: I am sure it is of great interest to our fishing community that one of the speakers in the debate on the Fisheries Legislation Amendment Bill was the member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin). In his speech, he referred to a parliamentary report called Managing Commonwealth fisheries: the last frontier, as did many other speakers. That appears to be a very good report. The member for Paterson went to some length to point out how he had been involved in that inquiry and to point out his contribution. In fact, he has also written a dissenting report.

I find that quite fascinating because the member for Paterson is also a member of the House of Representatives Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, which produced a report on fair trading. He never came to a hearing. We went all over the country and the member for Paterson did not turn up anywhere—except at one, which was by accident, in Parliament House.

TALK.START.PARA: —By accident?

—By accident. So the small business people in my electorate, particularly the fishermen, would wonder where he was. We were hoping that he would speak in the debate on this report, because the report was tabled over a month ago. We have tried to discuss it for a month. We got gagged out of the Main Committee yesterday. It has been pushed off the agenda today. I can understand the government being worried about the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) and trying to defend him—he needs some defending.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The member for Newcastle is well aware that the member for Paterson has been unable to speak on this bill because he has been representing the Australian government in New Zealand. He should also be well aware that this is well off the topic—
—There is no point of order. The honourable member for North Sydney will resume his seat.

—I was not aware that the member for Paterson was in New Zealand. I thought he was here like us. He and the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) both go off and do other things when we are sitting. We arrange our programs to be at work when work is on—and that is when the parliament sits. I am surprised to find that the member for Paterson is off somewhere else when we are here working on a Friday afternoon—and perhaps all night.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact is that the fishermen of Australia welcome these amendments, as do the parliamentarians of Australia. There is no opposi tion across the table. But what the fishermen of Australia also welcome is a fair trading environment where they have some protection, where they will be able to trade in a reasonable environment, which they currently do not have.

The fishermen of Australia would share the concerns of other small businesses in Australia and have a lack of confidence in the minister for small business, who, amongst other things, rang up his brother and said, `Write to Nick Greiner.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. The member for Newcastle has gone back to debating the fair trading report—not the fisheries legislation. A number of us have agreed not to speak on this at the end of the debate to allow people to get away. Now we have the member for Newcastle speaking on fair trading not on the fisheries report. His colleague the member for Lyons was in New Zealand as well. So if you are going to make accusations about our colleagues you should make them about yours as well.

—There is no point of order. The member for Eden-Monaro will resume his seat. Of course the honourable member for Newcastle must refer to the items on the bill, but I do not believe he has strayed unduly from that.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, a mirage has appeared. He is not in New Zealand. I am absolutely confused. I thought he was in New Zealand.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. He has not only strayed from the topic but also misrepresented the House. I did speak on the fisheries bill yesterday.
—That is not a point of order, and there are other forms of the House in which to make those sorts of comments.

—I did not misrepresent the House at all. I pointed out that the member for Paterson had spoken on the fishing legislation. I want him to speak on small business. He took part in two inquiries. In one he put in a dissenting report and he refers to it in his speech.
—Order! The honourable member for Newcastle is reminded that we are dealing with the fishing bill and not fair trading.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am dealing with the speech from the member for Paterson on the fishing legislation.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a further point of order. The information contained in that report is only summarised in my speech. But the legislation that he is supposed to be debating is not of that report that was tabled this week in the House.
—I have already advised the member for Newcastle that he must speak on the fishing legislation. I am sure he is about to move in that direction.
—I would like to quote the member for Paterson to indicate how this debate has ranged. The member for Paterson says:

SPEECH.PARA: Fisheries bring a lot of money to Australia.
In his speech on this legislation he also talks about exports and tourism. If he can, why can't I? The fact is I can. You know it and I know it, and I am going to.

Fishing security is extremely important. How we manage our fishing grounds is vital to a lot of small businessmen and businesswomen—they are called fisherpeople, fishermen, call them what you will, but they fish off our coast. They require security. They require, as much as any other small business person, the security of legislation to back them up when they are in difficulties. They require security when they borrow money from the banks. All these issues are covered in a report called Finding the balance, which the member for Paterson absented himself from.

The issue that we have been involved in for the last two or three days of the government manipulating the agenda so that we could not talk about small business at all has been a disgrace to this parliament. We can talk about fishing—

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. If I could read the outline to this legislation, it says that it has proposed amendments to seek to rectify minor anomalies to the management of fisheries. It is very narrow. The member for Newcastle has come back to the fair trading report, and I ask you to tell him to stick to the minor anomalies in the management of fisheries, which is what this legislation is all about.

—I thank the honourable member for Eden‐Monaro for his advice, but it is always the accepted practice of the House that in second reading debates members can cover the general area dealt with by the bill. So, as long as the member for Newcastle relates his remarks to the fishing legislation, he will be in order.

—I was not aware that the member for Eden‐Monaro had in fact declined to speak. As far as I could see, he was on the speakers list. They were going to get this debated but we were not going to get other things debated.

BREAK.PARA: The other part of this is the tourist industry. The member for Paterson in his speech made a very valid point and a very important point to all of us with fisheries. Tourism is one of our most important industries. The security of the fishing stocks is fundamental to our tourist industries up and down the coast on both sides of the continent.

We thought a few weeks ago we were going to get some more people involved in tourism and possibly in fishing through an announcement by the government and the member for Paterson of a program of $2 million to help train long‐term unemployed into the work force. I was shocked, as were most people in the region, to discover this week that the Hunter Regional Tourist Organisation has refused the money. So the future fishermen are not going to become fishermen.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: BALDWIN

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker, I bring to your attention standing order 85, which reads:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Speaker, or the Chair, after having called the attention of the House, or of the Main Committee, to the conduct of a Member, who persists in irrelevance, or tedious repetition of either his or her own arguments, or the arguments used by other members . . .
I put to you that not only is he tedious and repetitious but boring and irrelevant.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I am sure the honourable member knows that that is not a reasonable point of order. I would remind him of the standing order about frivolous points of order.

—I can understand the member for Paterson being somewhat sensitive, because he made a big fanfare about how this $2 million was going to help solve the problems caused by the BHP situation. What he is saying now is that they are going to hawk this $2 million around the community to find somebody else who might take the money.

BREAK.PARA: It is unprecedented for any organisation to turn down $2 million of Commonwealth funds to train long‐term unemployed to get jobs. We had possible future fishermen in that program, we had possible future workers in fishing based tourism. The organisation the money was offered to has said it will not work. The government's offer is not able to be taken up; it is non‐viable. Who put it forward? The member for Paterson, our self‐declared fisherman with a self‐declared interest in game fishing, a self‐declared lack of interest in fair trading and small business and a confused interest in unemployment.

TALK.START.PARA: —A point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker—
—The honourable member for Paterson will resume his seat.
—I have a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker.
—I warn the honourable member for Paterson about frivolous points of order.
—This is not a frivolous point of order. The member for Newcastle has just stated that I declared no interest in small business or fair trading. That is misleading, and I demand that he withdraw it.
—There is no point of order, and I am sure you would be aware that, if you disagree with the comments made by the member, there are procedures of the House to deal with that.

—I have been trying to be careful and you have been, Mr Deputy Speaker, and we understand the standing orders moderately well, though not as well as Mr Barlin and some others. The member for Paterson has now caused me some difficulty because of his interjections. I now need to explain something that was not clear. The Commonwealth government, with the member for Paterson, announced a $2 million program about a month ago for long‐term unemployed based on tourism. The biggest tourist attraction in my area, the Hunter, is fishing. Fishing is the major recreation in that region. We draw literally tens of millions of dollars of income from the fishing industry and the tourism industry combined. That $2 million was turned down this week by the Hunter Regional Tourist Organisation because the government has made the program non‐viable by reducing the amount per person and by the way it is paid. I needed to explain that because the member for Paterson has now taken this a step further.

BREAK.PARA: The point I was trying to make was that we in this House can agree on the need for fishing security, and we have. Speakers on both sides—and I have read all their speeches—have spoken of the importance of managing our fishing stocks well. We all understand what happened with the orange roughie and we all understand what happened with a range of fish stock which were not well managed. We understand that. We had enormous difficulty, off the coast of Newcastle and further north, with the gemfish problem. My electorate's fishing fleet suffered greatly with that. We had enormous difficulty with the issue of prawning licences. My fishing people suffered greatly from that. So we are aware of those things and we agree on those things.

In amongst all this, people who fish are also in business: they have to borrow money, they have got to take out security, they also suffer unemployment, they also need training. All those things come into this issue and many of them are touched on in the report by the parliamentary committee referred to by the member for Paterson in his speech. So I am talking about the report that he referred to. Small business and access and fairness come into all those things.

I was really disappointed yesterday when in the Main Committee we tried to talk about issues which affect the fishing fleet, people in small business who rely on fishing, who rely on finance, who rely on government to give them a fair go, to discover that we were not able to. Here we are at the end of the session and I am now being told that members have dropped off the speakers list to go home early or whatever. I did not know that, to be honest. As far as I knew, we were told in the week we are here till midnight or whatever. That is what I have had to program for.

In the month since we have tabled the report on fair trading about small business, including fishermen and fisherwomen and tourist operators and those who work in the tourism industry—all those people—we have not been able to have it discussed. It was gagged off the Main Committee yesterday; it has been pushed off the agenda today. One of the people helping to push it off was the member for Paterson, a member of the committee who did not come to one hearing other than the one in Parliament House which he did not know was a hearing. He did not come to a committee meeting for six months, and his lack of support for small business, as shown by his performance in that inquiry, is appalling.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are a liar. You are an absolute liar. You are a liar.
—Order! The honourable member for Paterson will withdraw that remark.
—No, I won't, Mr Deputy Speaker. He's a liar.
—I am ordering you to withdraw that remark.
—I won't withdraw it, because he's a liar.
—This is my final warning, or I will name you. I name the honourable member for Paterson.

BREAK.PARA: Motion (by Mr Abbott) agreed to:
That the member for Paterson be suspended from the service of the House for 24 hours.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The member for Paterson thereupon withdrew from the chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, he wanted to go home early. What a set‐up. I am sorry that I got sucked into it. I did not really mean to offend him so much that he would go home early. Bye, bye. I wish that we could say, `Bye, bye' to the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser). We will say that in August, because he will be gone by then.

BREAK.PARA: This legislation is important. My fishing fleet has just relocated from the harbour foreshores around Honeysuckle. There is a new fishing fleet and a new property being built there that I am sure will be extremely successful. I want to make sure that the people in this government and the department understand and appreciate how critical these issues are. We can all agree across the chamber, but it is what happens on the ground and under the water that is more important. Issues of environmental degradation, pollution and fishing management and the way that the department operates are vital.

I call on those in this parliament who clearly support, as we all do, these amendments and the need for well-managed fisheries to make sure that our departmental staff carry those good wishes through. In doing so, I issue a call to all small business people—people who fish and rely on tourism; all the interactions of those businesses that are so vital to so many of our regional economies—to write to their local member, particularly the member for Paterson, and tell them that they want the government to adopt the report of the fair trading inquiry. It should be unanimously adopted across the chamber, as this legislation is.

Just as we all agree on the fishing legislation, we on the back bench all agree on the fair trading inquiry. We want it brought on in August and endorsed by the government to help the fishing fleets and the tourist operators. The recommendations should be adopted, particularly recommendation 6.1, which is about unfair trading. The victims of unfair trading are often fishermen. They are small, often not well educated and do not have substantial financial assets. They are often caught in situations where they are the victims of unfair trading practices. They want protection and help. That help is available in the Finding a balance report. It is there at recommendation 6.1.

The chairman of the committee is in the chamber. He knows how good it is. It is a great report. It is one of the best in this parliament in my time. It is important that tourist operators and fishing communities across the country write to their federal member, particularly if that member is in government. They should write to them, ring them or go and see them. They should tell them, `We are pleased that you agree on the legislation for fishing, but we also want you to agree on the complete recommendations of the fair trading inquiry.' They should tell them that they want them adopted soon, because, with every week that goes by, small business people are going broke. Fishermen are going broke because they do not have the protection that they need. It is available, and the formula is there. The chairman of the committee, the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid), helped to draft it. He has put it forward and endorsed it. The back bench endorsed it. All it needs is the government to endorse it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the government, I simply thank all members who have contributed to the debate on this bill. There has been extensive debate in the Main Committee, which was contributed to by the members for Lyons (Mr Adams), O'Connor (Mr Tuckey), Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) and Petrie (Ms Gambaro). They all made very high quality contributions. I suspect that they were of a rather higher quality than the speech we just heard from the member for Newcastle (Mr Allan Morris). I commend the bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Abbott) read a third time.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: JENKINS

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order under standing order 277, which relates to unresolved questions having to come back to the chamber for consideration. The Fisheries Legislation Amendment Bill was subject to an unresolved question yesterday. The report was considered 24 hours ago, which allowed for the second reading debate. It is my understanding that there are seven outstanding reports from the Main Committee, which include unresolved questions. One of them goes to the report that appears to be contentious, which is the fair trading report. I am aggrieved that I have not been able to discuss that report, but that is not my point.

INTERJECT.PARA: As part of that debate, there is an unresolved question relating to a dissent motion about a ruling of Deputy Speaker Mossfield. I believe that it would be wrong for us to have that dissent motion hanging and not resolved over the winter recess. I had hoped that there would be an opportunity at least to endeavour to have those who sponsored the dissent motion to reconsider it and withdraw it, because I do not think anything is served by continuing with it. There will be a great difficulty if we do not resolve those questions that have been returned for deliberation by the chamber from the Main Committee, especially when we have this one, which is a dissent motion—a very serious motion—before the Main Committee that is not yet resolved.

TALK.START.PARA: —On indulgence, I thought it had been agreed upon to attempt to deal with that matter today. If you give me a few minutes, I will make some inquiries about the agreements between the various parties concerned. If we have the introduction of the two bills, we can have our discussions in the meantime.
—I thank the Leader of the House. It was not my intention to delay the House. I had not been told. I think it is something that we need to clarify.

TITLE.XREF: HEALTH INSURANCE COMMISSION (REFORM AND SEPARATION OF FUNCTIONS) BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Abbott and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill provides for the separation of Medibank Private from the Health Insurance Commission, HIC, and the creation of a new Medibank Private corporation. Through the separation, the government will ensure that Medibank Private cannot be perceived to have any competitive advantage over other private health funds through its association with Medicare or other government program functions of the HIC. It reinforces the government's commitment to the principle of competitive neutrality.

The new Medibank Private corporation, after a transitional period in which it will operate as a wholly-owned subsidiary of the HIC, will remain in public ownership. The bill therefore provides for the HIC initially to hold shares in the nominated company and to seek registration of that company as a registered health benefits organisation under the National Health Act 1953. The HIC may not transfer any of its shares or voting rights attached to the shares before the date on which the shares are transferred to the Commonwealth. Any change to these ownership arrangements can only be made by parliamentary amendment of this legislation.

The new company, once it is operating as Medibank Private, will not be limited by the current provisions of the Health Insurance Commission Act to determine the range of activities that may be carried out by the company. This will ensure that Medibank Private, to all intents and purposes, will be able to compete on an even footing with other private health insurers. The bill provides for the transfer of the fund and its business to the `nominated company'—not yet formed—which will operate Medibank Private. The Health Insurance Commission is specifically empowered by the bill to facilitate that transfer. The transfer scheme will be published in the Gazette.

Provision for the transfer of assets, contracts—including the splitting of contracts between the HIC and the nominated company in some cases—and liabilities to Medibank Private by ministerial declaration are specifically covered in the bill. Gazettal of any related determinations and a number of other determinations necessary to effect separation will ensure the transparency of transactions.

Staff affected by the transfer will be treated fairly. Where an employee is transferred under these provisions, their terms and conditions of employment, and other rights and entitlements defined in the bill, have been preserved. The bill does not, of course, prevent variations at a later date under any law, award, determination or agreement, but the interests of staff will be taken into account by the government.

Transferred employees will not be entitled to any termination payment by leaving HIC employment, but re-transfer provisions will give considerable flexibility for staff transfers back to the HIC for a period of 12 months from the date on which the Commonwealth assumes ownership of the Medibank Private company.

Minor provisions in the bill include stamp duty exemption for designated matters necessary to carry out the separation, the capacity to transfer pending legal proceedings to the new company where appropriate, the transfer of records in accordance with the Archives Act 1983, provision for the company not to be taken legally as an agency of the Commonwealth, for the minister to be represented at corporations law meetings by the chairman or the secretary, and delegations. The bill also permits any complaints or investigations under the Ombudsman Act 1976 or the Privacy Act 1988, and requests under the Freedom of Information Act 1982, which may have been or have been made prior to the Medibank Private fund-transfer day, and which relate to Medibank Private, to be completed.

In order to meet the requirement for Medibank Private to operate on an equal footing with its competitors, these enactments will not apply to Medibank Private thereafter, other than in this transitional sense. The company will, however, continue to operate within the spirit of these regimes—as it does today where the Medibank Private business is not prescribed under these enactments. Medibank Private will, like its competitors, remain subject to the complaints investigations powers of the Private Health Insurance Complaints Commissioner.

The bill also makes a number of consequential changes to the Health Insurance Commission Act 1973, other acts and the Health Insurance Commission Regulations. The government stresses that the provision of Medicare services will be maintained as a core HIC function, and the HIC will be expected to continue to strive for excellence in delivering quality claims and related services to the public. Other existing government programs functions, including the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, will also continue to be performed by the HIC.

Additionally, the bill also recognises a widening role for the HIC in the delivery of health payments services and information to support health sector initiatives. The HIC may, in future, provide health information and payments support services to state governments as well as to the Commonwealth. For this reason, the bill permits consultation with the states and territories as to their possible representation on the HIC board. Other minor corporate governance changes and transitional arrangements are also made by the bill.
I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Peter Baldwin) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Abbott, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abbott, Tony, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr ABBOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The Health Insurance (Pathology Services) Amendment Bill 1997 gives effect to several government initiatives relating to Medicare benefits for pathology services. This bill would allow the Governor‐General to make regulations to give the Health Insurance Commission power to directly impose penalties for the less serious infringements relating to pathology. It is envisaged that the proposed system of penalty notices, operating in a similar manner to traffic infringement fines, would enable the Commission to deal more efficiently and expeditiously with these infringements.

The bill also makes an amendment to the licensing scheme for the collection of pathology specimens. It introduces a requirement that the owner of a licensed collection centre must at all times display a notice clearly visible from the outside, to let the public know that the centre is licensed. The bill increases the maximum penalty for infringements from $100 to $1000, to be in line with other penalties relating to collection centres. The intention of this is to provide a deterrent to the operation of unlicensed collection centres and to protect consumer interests.

Currently, the act restricts pathology providers from entering into arrangements for the occupation of premises with medical practitioners or entrepreneurs, except for the establishment of licensed collection centres, accredited laboratories or the rendering of professional services. The aim is to prevent arrangements that constitute inducements to medical practitioners. An amendment in this bill clarifies the wording of the provision to establish beyond doubt that professional services must be performed by the pathologist in person. In other words, the arrangement cannot be one where the medical practitioner receives payment for providing, for example, storage space to a pathologist.

BREAK.PARA: The bill also seeks to streamline administration of approvals for accredited pathology laboratories, approved pathology practitioners and approved pathology authorities. These are renewed annually, or every three years in the case of the laboratories. Currently, Medicare benefits are not payable where these approvals lapse simply as a result of administrative carelessness on the part of the pathology provider, for example, posting the application forms a few weeks after they are due. This can result in major financial losses to the pathology provider and in patients being deprived of Medicare benefits. The amendment will allow backdating of approvals in limited circumstances to ensure that Medicare benefit payments are not disrupted in instances that do not warrant it.

The measures we are introducing in this bill are important to the maintenance of the pathology agreement, which was introduced in the 1996‐97 budget and which limits pathology expenditure under Medicare to pre‐determined levels. They will strengthen the agreement by reducing inappropriate practices which undermine its basis. They have the support of the pathology profession.
I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Mr Lee) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALKER.NAME: Mr WARWICK SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

This bill amends the Broadcasting Services Act 1992 to create a new class of licence—a temporary community broadcasting licence. The legislation will empower the Australian Broadcasting Authority to allocate the licences for a maximum period of one year with out recourse to the act's planning provisions. The bill also provides for consequential amendments to the Radiocommunications Act 1992 to enable the new Australian Communications Authority to issue transmitter licences to these licensees.

No provision exists under the act for temporary community broadcasting licences. The ABA has, instead, provided for test transmissions of 90 days per aspirant per year, by making spectrum available to providers of open narrowcasting services and issuing temporary apparatus licences, a power delegated to it under the Radiocommunications Act. The situation is far from satisfactory. The ABA has not been able to impose conditions that apply to community broadcasting licensees, for example, community access provisions, and sponsorship announcements limited to four minutes per hour.

Test transmissions have done much to foster the overall development of the community broadcasting sector. There are currently over 140 aspirant community broadcasters seeking a long‐term licence. But limited periods of test transmission have meant that it has become increasingly difficult for these non‐profit aspirants to maintain support from volunteers, sponsors and the local community. Some aspirants may be forced to disband before the ABA has completed the planning process, and allocated long‐term licences.

I am aware that honourable members from both sides of the House have registered growing concern at the delays in the planning and allocation process. Indeed, I have complained myuself. The ABA expects that licence area planning will not be completed before 1999—a 3½‐year slippage. Many markets have no long‐term community broadcasting licensees and many markets have aspirants who have been seeking long‐term licences for over a decade.

The amendments proposed are consistent with the objects of the act: to promote the availability of a diverse range of services; and to promote the role of broadcasting services in developing and reflecting a sense of Australian identity, character and cultural diversity.

BREAK.PARA: The integrity of the current planning process will be maintained. Long‐term licenses will not be allocated to community broadcasters before the formal planning process has been completed. After each licence area has been planned, the amendments will ensure that aspirants can continue broadcasting, in accordance with the new provisions, ahead of any further process of varying the licence area plan which may result in more long‐term licences. The primary purpose of these amendments is, however, to enable the introduction of continuous transmissions by aspirants ahead of formal planning.

Many aspirant groups will have the opportunity to commence full‐time broadcasting. It is anticipated that the majority of suitable aspirants will benefit, with access made available to as many as possible. In areas where there is competition for limited spectrum, it is intended that continuous transmissions be made possible through spectrum sharing.

The conditions, content rules and remedial and enforcement mechanisms which apply to long‐term community broadcasting licensees will apply to temporary community broadcasting licensees. The ABA will also have the power to specify the times and the total number of days during which broadcasting will be permitted by the terms of the licence.

Under this bill, temporary licence holders will not have enhanced rights to the allocation of a community broadcasting licence—there will be no mechanism for converting a temporary community broadcasting licence into a community broadcasting licence. The likelihood of an aspirant eventually gaining a long‐term licence will vary from area to area, depending on a number of factors, including both the spectrum made available by the ABA in the planning process and the subsequent evaluation of the merits of applicants in the allocation process conducted by the ABA in accordance with part 6 of the act.
These amendments are not expected to have a significant impact on Commonwealth expenditure or revenue.
I commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to this bill.
Leave granted for second reading debate to continue forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lee, Michael, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the day and the hour, I will not be speaking for a long time on this particular piece of legislation. I simply wish to state that, given the opposition's support for community broadcasting and given the extended delays in the ABA being able to complete the licence area plans, the opposition supports the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Warwick Smith) read a third time.
Message received from the Senate acquainting the House that the Senate does not insist on its amendment disagreed to by the House and has agreed to the amendment made by the House in place thereof.
Message received from the Senate acquainting the House that the Senate does not insist upon its amendments Nos 10, 11 and 13 disagreed to by the House.

TITLE.XREF: ENVIRONMENT, SPORT AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1997

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the Senate, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALKER.NAME: Mr WARWICK SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

To facilitate the passage of the bill through the House, rather than read into the record the six‐page second reading speech, I seek leave to table it, given that it is an omnibus bill. I also present the signed explanatory memorandum.
Leave granted.
Leave granted for second reading debate to proceed forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerr, Duncan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will make up for the omission of the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment (Mr Warwick Smith) by actually discussing the bill. The Environment, Sport and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill is a technical bill which amends some 15 acts of this parliament. It improves some administrative processes under the act, brings Commonwealth legislation into line with resolutions of the 16th Consultative Meeting of Contracting Parties to the London Convention on the Prevention of Marine Pollution by Dumping Wastes and Other Material and corrects a number of drafting areas.

SPEECH.PARA: The opposition will support the bill, but only after the government amends clause 40—which it has done—dealing with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act. In its original form, the bill sought to amend that act to remove the Australian Defence Force or the defence force of a foreign country from the application of an offence of waste discharge on the Great Barrier Reef. We opposed that amendment and had the government not indicated that it would amend the bill to delete clause 40—so our own defence forces and those of visiting countries would not be able, without penalty, to discharge waste on the reef—we would have been moving amendments. But that has been done by the government. I am pleased it has taken that course, because the Great Barrier Reef is a highly sensitive world heritage area that demands strict environmental controls on waste disposals, whether they be from commercial, private or defence vessels.

I might indicate simply in my more parochial role as the member for Denison that the amendments that are included in this legislation to the legislation around the London dumping convention facilitate the continuation of an arrangement which the previous government entered into when Senator Faulkner was the environment minister. It allowed EZ to continue to dump at sea some jarosite wastes until the end of 1997.

At the time, there was some concern amongst the environment movements of this country regarding that extension, and that concern was quite rightly raised. It is pleasing that the most recent report I have received from EZ is that their co‐treatment process they pledged to spend millions of dollars on developing in Port Pirie will shortly be in operation. Therefore, this time has been put to good use, and the employment base and the economic base of that firm in Tasmania has been maintained but without environmental cost.

I am told there is a disposition to conclude this debate quickly. I will therefore refrain from the lengthy remarks I was intending to make regarding the relationship of this bill to the underfunding of the Natural Heritage Trust—

TALK.START.PARA: —It would have brought the government down.

—It would have brought the government down. I also will not mention the inadequacy of the government's response to greenhouse matters and the need to deal with land clearance in Queensland. Given the hour and given the view of the House that this matter be resolved quickly, I will allow those matters to await another time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Warwick, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Sport, Territories and Local Government; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games

TALKER.NAME: Mr WARWICK SMITH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Sydney 2000 Games)

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—I thank the member for Denison (Mr Kerr) for the support that has been indicated by the opposition for these series of amendments. I thank him for truncating his remarks and look forward to his contribution when we return on another opportunity that I am sure will present itself. I also note his remarks about the jarosite issue, which I know is important to Tasmania.
—I was going to speak just briefly about this omnibus bill by agreement between the whips.
—Madam Deputy Speaker, on a point of order: unfortunately, the minister has closed the debate.

—I would apologise for that. I did call the minister. The agreement was, I understand, that the opposition spokesperson had to complete the debate. I then called the minister to close the second reading. The question before the House is that the bill be read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Leave granted for third reading to be moved forthwith.
Bill (on motion by Mr Warwick Smith) read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be agreed to.
At this stage, there is no need for me to add to the comments which I made with regard to these amendments earlier this day in the House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the Senate acquainting the House that the Senate does not insist upon its amendments Nos 2, 6 and 7, disagreed to by the House, and insists upon its amendments Nos 3, 4 and 5, disagreed to by the House.

BREAK.PARA: Ordered that the message be taken into consideration forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles, Chris, MP

TALKER.NAME: Mr MILES
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary [Cabinet] to the Prime Minister)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments insisted on by the Senate be agreed to.

The effect of these amendments to the bill will be that the book bounty will now finish on 31 December 1997, as set down in the current act, rather than on 30 June 1997, as had been sought in the original bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crean, Simon, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —We are pleased that the government has finally accepted what we were saying all along on the books bounty. I might remind the House that the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid) and the member for Ballarat (Mr Ronaldson) voted against this very proposition as recently as last Wednesday in this chamber. It is only Labor that has delivered the books bounty for the people of Maryborough and for the people of Adelaide.

SPEECH.PARA: This is one of four bounties abolished by this government, despite election promises to the contrary, and we have succeeded in the restoration of three of them. Unfortunately, the Senate has not continued to insist the computer bounty be retained, but we will persist with the issue of the computer bounty when we finally get released to us the Goldsworthy report into the information technology industry. So this is a great win for the people in the book publishing industry. It is a great win for the people of Maryborough. It is a great win for the people of Adelaide.

It is interesting that, in relation to this issue, the Productivity Commission recommended that the bounty be retained to the end of the year. Finally, that is the position the government has adopted. This is a position that the Productivity Commission recommended but which the government ignored. It is also interesting to note that the Productivity Commission is yet to release its final report on machine tools and robots as well as its final report on book bounties. It is very interesting that this is a government that chooses to hide the Productivity Commission reports and keep them away from this parliament for debate.

BREAK.PARA: The Productivity Commission report on the textile, clothing and footwear industries is another case in point. It is going to be released on Monday, but it is something that we know should have been debated in this House. The future of the textile, clothing and footwear industries is going to be a major issue, one on which a new battle ground will be opened up. Why Monday? Because parliament is not sitting. Does this sound familiar? It is exactly what the government did in relation to the car industry. It did not release the report of the Productivity Commission until after parliament got up, and it is doing the same here. In relation to machine tools and robots, it has done exactly the same thing.

Only last week the report for the textile, clothing and footwear industries was due for release today, but that was when it was considered that parliament would have got up yesterday. So the intention was always to have the report come out the day after parliament got up. Why? Because the Treasurer (Mr Costello) leaned on the Productivity Commission to delay the release of the report. The Treasurer is clearly hiding the report and, once again, he will not allow it to be released until parliament rises, just as he did in the case of the car industry.

We have this Treasurer carrying on about a charter of budget honesty, but he will not release the Productivity Commission reports which are in his charge. I think that PC, in relation to the Productivity Commission, is now about Peter's concealment. There is this so-called new openness of government and the waxing lyrical by the Treasurer about how we are going to introduce new standards and new access, and they hide the Productivity Commission reports. They do not want the debate in this place.

This report holds major concern for the workers within the textile, clothing and footwear industry. If it turns out that this report of the Productivity Commission into the textile, clothing and footwear industry has learnt nothing from the decision in cars, then its recommendations will place at risk thousands of jobs within that industry. It will put at great risk the people in that industry, who, from all the studies that have been done, are very hard to place in alternative industries. Their futures will be made far less secure, and the impact on regions will be incredible.

Let me just say this: Labor will be responding to the outcome from the report of the Productivity Commission into the textile, clothing and footwear industry to make sure that there is a commitment not just to securing existing jobs but to new jobs, new investment and increased exports. We would like to have had the opportunity for debate in this House rather than have the report hidden from us. This is a government that wants to hide everything of significance. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

Commonwealth Vehicles (Registration and Exemption from Taxation) Bill 1997

In accordance with standing order 280A, the matter is set down for consideration at a later hour this day.
